questions.scenario: A healthcare organization is launching a new patient data management system. During the initiation phase, the project manager discovers that the organization's data retention policy (OPA) conflicts with new HIPAA regulations (EEF). The policy requires keeping patient records for 3 years, while HIPAA requires 6 years. The steering committee is pressuring the team to proceed with the project using the internal policy to avoid storage costs.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Document the compliance gap and work with legal/compliance to update the OPA before proceeding
distractors: Follow the internal OPA policy since it takes precedence in organizational governance
Proceed with the 6-year retention and absorb the additional storage cost within the project budget
Document the issue in the risk register and continue with the 3-year policy

answers.text: Document the compliance gap and work with legal/compliance to update the OPA before proceeding
Follow the internal OPA policy since it takes precedence in organizational governance
Proceed with the 6-year retention and absorb the additional storage cost within the project budget
Document the issue in the risk register and continue with the 3-year policy

remediation.coreLogic: Laws and regulations (EEF external) always trump organizational policies (OPA internal). When a conflict exists, the organization must adapt its policies to comply with legal requirements. The project manager must ensure compliance rather than making unilateral decisions.
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance is non-negotiable. The PM acts as a compliance advocate, not a decision-maker on regulatory interpretation. Legal/compliance has authority here.
remediation.theTrap: Following internal OPA seems logical from a governance perspective, but fails when the law requires otherwise. This is a common exam pattern where the "organization's way" conflicts with legal requirements.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Compliance vs. Standards vs. Policy hierarchy

questions.scenario: A software development project has a charter with the following success criteria: "Launch by Q4 with 99.9% uptime." Midway through execution, the team realizes that achieving 99.9% uptime will require a failover architecture that was not budgeted for. The sponsor suggests lowering the success criterion to 99% to stay within budget, but this change would impact the business case presented to the portfolio board for approval.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Present the impact to the steering committee for approval before modifying the success criteria
distractors: Update the project charter to reflect 99% uptime since the sponsor has approved the change
Proceed with the 99.9% target and request additional funding through the change control process
Document the variance in the issue log and continue planning for 99% to maintain the schedule

answers.text: Present the impact to the steering committee for approval before modifying the success criteria
Update the project charter to reflect 99% uptime since the sponsor has approved the change
Proceed with the 99.9% target and request additional funding through the change control process
Document the variance in the issue log and continue planning for 99% to maintain the schedule

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria defined in the charter are governance guardrails. When they need modification, it's not a simple change control issue—it requires governance body (steering committee) approval because the business case that justified the project has changed.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages within approved tolerances. Changes that affect the business justification and strategic value require governance escalation, not just documentation or unilateral adjustment.
remediation.theTrap: Accepting sponsor approval alone seems reasonable, but when success criteria tied to the business case change, the governance body that approved the business case must be involved.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - Measurable Success Criteria and PM Authority Levels

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is working on a financial services product. During Sprint Review, the Product Owner announces that two features completed in the sprint must be removed due to a new regulatory requirement that was discovered mid-sprint. The team is frustrated because they worked hard on those features. The Scrum Master needs to decide how to handle this situation.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action the Scrum Master should take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion with the Product Owner about when and how the regulatory requirement was identified
distractors: Immediately update the product backlog to remove the features and notify stakeholders
Escalate to the steering committee to challenge the regulatory requirement
Document the wasted effort in the retrospective and plan to recover the velocity

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion with the Product Owner about when and how the regulatory requirement was identified
Immediately update the product backlog to remove the features and notify stakeholders
Escalate to the steering committee to challenge the regulatory requirement
Document the wasted effort in the retrospective and plan to recover the velocity

remediation.coreLogic: In Agile governance, system demos and sprint reviews serve as governance checkpoints. Regulatory requirements discovered mid-execution indicate a gap in compliance identification during initiation. The Scrum Master facilitates process improvement.
remediation.pmiMindset: Agile governance focuses on empirical process control and continuous improvement. The issue isn't the removed features—it's why a regulatory requirement wasn't identified earlier in the process.
remediation.theTrap: Immediately removing the features seems action-oriented, but fails to address the governance gap. The real issue is process failure in compliance identification, not the scope change itself.

questions.scenario: A project manager is assigned to lead a cross-functional initiative involving three departments. Each department has its own PMO with different templates and approval processes. The marketing PMO requires a 15-page charter, while IT requires a 3-page agile charter. The project manager needs to decide which governance framework to follow.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST approach for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Consult the organizational PMO to determine which template or hybrid approach is appropriate for this initiative
distractors: Use the marketing department's charter since they are the primary customer for the project
Create two separate charters, one for each department's PMO requirements
Use the IT department's agile charter to reduce administrative overhead

answers.text: Consult the organizational PMO to determine which template or hybrid approach is appropriate for this initiative
Use the marketing department's charter since they are the primary customer for the project
Create two separate charters, one for each department's PMO requirements
Use the IT department's agile charter to reduce administrative overhead

remediation.coreLogic: When multiple governance frameworks conflict, the organizational PMO provides the authoritative guidance on methodology tailoring. The PMO exists specifically to resolve these types of cross-project governance questions.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM doesn't arbitrarily choose between conflicting standards—they seek authoritative guidance from the body responsible for governance standards (the PMO).
remediation.theTrap: Choosing one department's framework seems pragmatic, but creates governance risk. The PMO is designed to provide consistency across the organization.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - PMO Types and Methodology (Tailoring) Services

questions.scenario: A hybrid project uses a phased approach with quarterly gates for strategic milestones and 2-week sprints for tactical delivery. At a gate review, the steering committee approves continuation but adds a requirement for bi-weekly status reports to the PMO. The development team argues this violates Agile principles and adds administrative overhead. The project manager is caught between the governance requirement and team concerns.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST APPROPRIATE action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Work with the PMO to automate reporting from existing sprint artifacts rather than creating new reports
distractors: Push back to the steering committee on behalf of the team to reject the reporting requirement
Require the team to produce the bi-weekly reports as a condition of governance compliance
Escalate to the sponsor to mediate between the steering committee and the development team

answers.text: Work with the PMO to automate reporting from existing sprint artifacts rather than creating new reports
Push back to the steering committee on behalf of the team to reject the reporting requirement
Require the team to produce the bi-weekly reports as a condition of governance compliance
Escalate to the sponsor to mediate between the steering committee and the development team

remediation.coreLogic: Hybrid governance balances strategic oversight with team autonomy. The PMO can serve as a servant leader by using existing artifacts (sprint reports, burndown charts) to satisfy governance needs without adding overhead.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM acts as a facilitator who finds solutions that satisfy both governance requirements and team efficiency. This is servant leadership in action—removing impediments while maintaining compliance.
remediation.theTrap: Pushing back on behalf of the team seems to support Agile values, but ignores the governance body's legitimate need for visibility. Automation is the win-win solution.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - PMO as Servant Leader and AI-Enabled PMO services

questions.scenario: A construction project charter states: "Complete building by December 31 with zero safety incidents." During execution, a subcontractor has a near-miss accident that violated safety protocols. The project manager stops work on that activity. The subcontractor argues that stopping work will cause the project to miss its December 31 deadline.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST response from the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the work stoppage in place until root cause analysis and corrective actions are verified
distractors: Allow work to resume with increased oversight to maintain the schedule target
Document the incident and continue while planning additional safety training
Escalate to the sponsor to decide whether schedule or safety takes priority

answers.text: Keep the work stoppage in place until root cause analysis and corrective actions are verified
Allow work to resume with increased oversight to maintain the schedule target
Document the incident and continue while planning additional safety training
Escalate to the sponsor to decide whether schedule or safety takes priority

remediation.coreLogic: Safety is non-negotiable and supersedes all other project objectives. When "zero safety incidents" is a success criterion in the charter, any safety violation—near-miss or actual—triggers immediate corrective action regardless of schedule impact.
remediation.pmiMindset: Safety and legal compliance always win. The PM doesn't trade safety for schedule. A near-miss is a warning that requires systemic correction, not just documentation.
remediation.theTrap: "Increased oversight" seems like a reasonable middle ground, but fails to address the root cause. The choice to stop work is not optional when safety success criteria are at risk.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Ethical Compass and Safety Violation scenarios

questions.scenario: A project manager discovers that the organization's procurement policy (OPA) requires competitive bidding for all contracts over $50,000. The project needs a specialized consultant that only one vendor can provide, with an estimated cost of $75,000. Going through a competitive bid process would delay the project by 6 weeks. The sponsor suggests splitting the contract into two $37,500 contracts to avoid the bidding requirement.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ETHICAL action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Document the sole-source justification and seek a formal waiver from the procurement governance body
distractors: Follow the sponsor's suggestion to split the contract to maintain the project schedule
Proceed with the single vendor and document the urgency as justification after the fact
Issue a competitive bid anyway despite knowing only one vendor can fulfill the requirement

answers.text: Document the sole-source justification and seek a formal waiver from the procurement governance body
Follow the sponsor's suggestion to split the contract to maintain the project schedule
Proceed with the single vendor and document the urgency as justification after the fact
Issue a competitive bid anyway despite knowing only one vendor can fulfill the requirement

remediation.coreLogic: Procurement policies exist to ensure fair competition and prevent fraud. Circumventing them by splitting contracts violates PMI's ethical value of honesty and fairness. The proper path is a formal waiver with documented justification.
remediation.pmiMindset: Ethical compliance is non-negotiable. The PMI code of ethics requires honesty and fairness. When a policy conflicts with project needs, follow the proper exception process rather than subverting the control.
remediation.theTrap: Following the sponsor's suggestion to split the contract seems like practical problem-solving, but is actually circumventing internal controls for fraud prevention.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - The Four Values in Action (Honesty, Fairness)

questions.scenario: A product development team using Kanban has a work-in-progress (WIP) limit of 3 items per column established during startup. The product owner is pressuring the team to increase WIP limits to "get more work through the system" because a key competitor just launched a similar feature. The team is concerned about quality and flow efficiency.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner about the trade-offs between WIP limits, cycle time, and delivery predictability
distractors: Increase the WIP limits temporarily to accommodate the product owner's request
Maintain the current WIP limits and inform the product owner that the team has decided not to change
Escalate the decision to the steering committee as a governance conflict

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner about the trade-offs between WIP limits, cycle time, and delivery predictability
Increase the WIP limits temporarily to accommodate the product owner's request
Maintain the current WIP limits and inform the product owner that the team has decided not to change
Escalate the decision to the steering committee as a governance conflict

remediation.coreLogic: WIP limits in Kanban are a governance mechanism established by the team for flow control. Changing them requires understanding the systemic impact. The Scrum Master's role is to educate stakeholders on the consequences of changing governance parameters.
remediation.pmiMindset: In Agile, teams self-organize within strategic guardrails. The Scrum Master facilitates understanding between the product owner and team rather than making unilateral decisions or escalating prematurely.
remediation.theTrap: Increasing WIP limits seems responsive to business needs, but actually reduces flow efficiency and predictability—the opposite of what the product owner wants.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Agile Governance Principles and Trust-Based approach

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has a charter with the following measurable success criteria: "Launch with 90% user adoption within 90 days." Six months after launch, adoption is at 65%. The steering committee is demanding an explanation. The project manager reviews the benefits realization plan and discovers that no one was assigned ownership of the adoption metrics post-launch.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT lesson for the project manager to apply to future projects?
questions.correctAnswer: Ensure the charter includes assignment of benefits ownership and measurement responsibility
distractors: Request additional budget for post-launch marketing to drive adoption to 90%
Revise the success criteria to reflect 65% as the new target
Document this as a lessons learned and move on to the next project

answers.text: Ensure the charter includes assignment of benefits ownership and measurement responsibility
Request additional budget for post-launch marketing to drive adoption to 90%
Revise the success criteria to reflect 65% as the new target
Document this as a lessons learned and move on to the next project

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must be measurable AND owned. When success extends beyond project closure (like adoption rates), governance must assign post-project ownership. The charter should have specified who was responsible for driving adoption.
remediation.pmiMindset: Value delivery requires end-to-end ownership. A project can't be declared successful if benefits weren't realized because no one was assigned to realize them.
remediation.theTrap: Requesting marketing budget seems solution-oriented, but the root cause is governance failure—no one was assigned responsibility for the adoption metric.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - Benefits Tracking service and Value-Driven PMO

questions.scenario: A government agency project requires compliance with new accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1 AA). The project charter was approved before these standards became law. The agency's PMO has not yet updated its templates to reference the new requirements. The project manager needs to determine how to proceed.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the project's quality management plan to incorporate WCAG 2.1 AA requirements and inform the PMO of the template gap
distractors: Proceed with the old accessibility standards since the charter predated the new law
Submit a change request to update the charter to reflect the new compliance requirements
Wait for the PMO to update its templates before incorporating the new requirements

answers.text: Update the project's quality management plan to incorporate WCAG 2.1 AA requirements and inform the PMO of the template gap
Proceed with the old accessibility standards since the charter predated the new law
Submit a change request to update the charter to reflect the new compliance requirements
Wait for the PMO to update its templates before incorporating the new requirements

remediation.coreLogic: New laws apply immediately to all active projects regardless of when they were initiated. The charter sets overall guardrails, but the execution plan (quality management plan) must adapt to new legal requirements. The PMO should also be informed of the template gap.
remediation.pmiMindset: Regulatory compliance is immediate and non-negotiable. The PM doesn't wait for governance artifacts to catch up—they implement requirements and help improve organizational process assets.
remediation.theTrap: Waiting for the PMO to update templates seems procedural, but delays necessary compliance work. The project must comply now while helping the organization improve.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - The Retroactive Rule and Compliance Radar

questions.scenario: During a project status review, the PMO director questions why a project has exceeded its schedule variance threshold of ±10% for three consecutive weeks. The project manager explains that the sponsor verbally approved continuing without corrective action because "the team is making good progress." The PMO director states that verbal approvals don't count and the project should have been escalated.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take going forward?
questions.correctAnswer: Follow the documented escalation path in the charter when thresholds are exceeded, regardless of verbal sponsor assurances
distractors: Request that the PMO update its policy to allow sponsor discretion in threshold enforcement
Document the sponsor's verbal approval and continue monitoring without escalation
Ask the sponsor to send written confirmation of the verbal approval to satisfy the PMO

answers.text: Follow the documented escalation path in the charter when thresholds are exceeded, regardless of verbal sponsor assurances
Request that the PMO update its policy to allow sponsor discretion in threshold enforcement
Document the sponsor's verbal approval and continue monitoring without escalation
Ask the sponsor to send written confirmation of the verbal approval to satisfy the PMO

remediation.coreLogic: Governance escalation paths and thresholds exist for transparency and early intervention. Verbal approvals bypass governance mechanisms designed to protect the organization. The charter's escalation procedures should be followed as written.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance requires documented trails and accountability. Verbal approvals create audit gaps and risk. The PM follows the established governance process even when a sponsor offers flexibility.
remediation.theTrap: Seeking written confirmation seems like a reasonable compromise, but the issue is that escalation thresholds were exceeded—governance requires visibility, not just post-facto documentation.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - PM Authority Levels and Escalation procedures

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is developing a medical device application. The Product Owner has identified 50 features in the product backlog with no clear prioritization framework. When asked which features are most critical for regulatory approval, the Product Owner responds "they're all important." The team is struggling to plan sprints without clear success criteria.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a workshop with stakeholders to define Minimum Viable Product (MVP) criteria and regulatory dependencies
distractors: Direct the team to implement the features in the order they appear in the backlog
Escalate to the steering committee to demand prioritization from the Product Owner
Have the team estimate all 50 features and start with the smallest ones to maximize velocity

answers.text: Facilitate a workshop with stakeholders to define Minimum Viable Product (MVP) criteria and regulatory dependencies
Direct the team to implement the features in the order they appear in the backlog
Escalate to the steering committee to demand prioritization from the Product Owner
Have the team estimate all 50 features and start with the smallest ones to maximize velocity

remediation.coreLogic: Agile governance requires clear product vision and success criteria. When the Product Owner hasn't defined what "done" looks like for regulatory approval, the Scrum Master facilitates definition of MVP and dependencies rather than allowing arbitrary prioritization.
remediation.pmiMindset: The Scrum Master serves the team by removing impediments to planning. Lack of prioritization is a governance gap that prevents the team from executing effectively.
remediation.theTrap: Starting with smallest features seems pragmatic for velocity, but building the wrong features wastes effort. Governance requires understanding what's actually needed for success.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - Agile Chartering and Vision Statement

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing the change control log and notices that 15 change requests have been approved in the past month, each within the project manager's approval authority of $10,000. Collectively, these changes represent a $120,000 budget impact that was never presented to the Change Control Board or steering committee. The project manager's authority was intended for minor adjustments, not cumulative scope changes.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Immediately notify the steering committee and CCB of the cumulative impact and request formal approval
distractors: Continue approving changes within authority since each individual request was within the $10,000 limit
Stop approving any further changes and request a charter revision to clarify approval authority
Update the risk register to note the budget overrun and continue with remaining changes

answers.text: Immediately notify the steering committee and CCB of the cumulative impact and request formal approval
Continue approving changes within authority since each individual request was within the $10,000 limit
Stop approving any further changes and request a charter revision to clarify approval authority
Update the risk register to note the budget overrun and continue with remaining changes

remediation.coreLogic: Approval authority exists for decentralized decision-making, but cumulative impacts that fundamentally change the project baseline require governance review. The "death by a thousand cuts" pattern undermines governance intent.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance is about intent as well as rules. The PM exercises judgment when individual actions, while technically compliant, collectively violate the spirit of governance controls.
remediation.theTrap: Continuing within individual authority limits seems technically correct, but ignores that governance bodies deserve visibility into cumulative impacts that change the project's nature.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and CCB authority

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has established an escalation threshold: any issue that impacts the project schedule by more than 2 weeks must be escalated to the sponsor. A critical vendor delays delivery by 10 days. The project manager calculates that through fast-tracking, the team can recover 5 days, leaving a net impact of 5 days—within the threshold. However, fast-tracking requires adding overtime which exceeds the budget's contingency reserve.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST APPROPRIATE action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Escalate to the sponsor since the recovery method requires exceeding contingency reserves
distractors: Implement the fast-tracking plan without escalation since the net schedule impact is within threshold
Request additional budget from the PMO to cover the overtime costs
Accept the 10-day delay and escalate since it exceeds the 2-week threshold

answers.text: Escalate to the sponsor since the recovery method requires exceeding contingency reserves
Implement the fast-tracking plan without escalation since the net schedule impact is within threshold
Request additional budget from the PMO to cover the overtime costs
Accept the 10-day delay and escalate since it exceeds the 2-week threshold

remediation.coreLogic: Escalation thresholds should be interpreted broadly, not literally. When the recovery method impacts other baselines (budget contingency), the governance intent—protecting the overall project—is triggered. Escalation provides visibility into trade-offs.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance thresholds are tripwires for stakeholder visibility, not rules to be technically navigated around. The PM provides transparency when significant trade-offs are required.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - PM Authority Levels and Escalation procedures

questions.scenario: A project charter specifies "reduce customer support call volume by 30%." At project closure, the project manager reports success because call volume decreased by 35%. Three months later, the operations manager discovers that call volume actually increased, but the project team had measured a different metric (call duration instead of call count) to show success.
questions.questionText: What is the PRIMARY governance failure in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: The success criteria in the charter were not defined with specific, measurable metrics
distractors: The project manager should have involved operations earlier in the measurement process
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports during execution
The PMO should have provided a template for post-implementation measurement

answers.text: The success criteria in the charter were not defined with specific, measurable metrics
The project manager should have involved operations earlier in the measurement process
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports during execution
The PMO should have provided a template for post-implementation measurement

remediation.coreLogic: Measurable success criteria are a governance foundation. "Reduce call volume by 30%" seems specific but actually allows ambiguity in measurement method. Good governance defines exactly what will be measured and how.
remediation.pmiMindset: Success criteria must be unambiguous to prevent gaming or misinterpretation. SMART criteria (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) require specifying the measurement method.
remediation.theTrap: Focusing on who was involved (operations) or reporting frequency misses the root cause—the charter itself allowed ambiguous interpretation of success.

questions.scenario: A product owner for a financial application wants to collect user behavioral data to train a machine learning model. The development team raises concerns about GDPR consent requirements. The product owner argues that since the data is internal and the model improves the product, explicit consent isn't needed. The Scrum Master is unsure who has authority to interpret GDPR requirements.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Pause the feature and request guidance from legal/compliance on GDPR interpretation
distractors: Allow the product owner to proceed since they are accountable for product decisions
Conduct a team vote on whether the feature complies with data privacy requirements
Document the team's concerns in the sprint backlog and proceed with development

answers.text: Pause the feature and request guidance from legal/compliance on GDPR interpretation
Allow the product owner to proceed since they are accountable for product decisions
Conduct a team vote on whether the feature complies with data privacy requirements
Document the team's concerns in the sprint backlog and proceed with development

remediation.coreLogic: Regulatory interpretation is not within a Scrum team's or product owner's authority. When compliance questions arise, the proper governance action is to pause and seek authoritative guidance from legal/compliance.
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance requirements are non-negotiable constraints on Agile delivery. The team has autonomy on HOW to build, but not on WHETHER to comply with regulations.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Data Privacy & AI section and GDPR compliance

questions.scenario: A project manager receives a change request that requires a $25,000 budget increase. The charter specifies that changes under $50,000 can be approved by the project manager. However, this change would also push the project completion date by 3 weeks, missing a contractual deadline with penalties. The project manager is unsure if they have authority to approve a schedule-impacting change.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST course of action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Escalate to the steering committee since the change impacts a contractual milestone
distractors: Approve the change since the budget impact is within the $50,000 authority threshold
Reject the change because it misses the contractual deadline
Request that the change submitter modify the request to avoid schedule impact

answers.text: Escalate to the steering committee since the change impacts a contractual milestone
Approve the change since the budget impact is within the $50,000 authority threshold
Reject the change because it misses the contractual deadline
Request that the change submitter modify the request to avoid schedule impact

remediation.coreLogic: PM authority in the charter typically references budget thresholds, but contractual obligations represent external governance that exceeds the PM's approval authority. Missing contractual deadlines triggers penalties and legal implications beyond project-level decision-making.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages within the project's governance envelope. External commitments (contracts) create governance obligations that exceed the PM's authority and require escalation.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project uses a stage-gate governance model with formal reviews at the end of each phase. At the end of the Design phase, the gate review committee approves the deliverables but adds a requirement: "All future design changes must be reviewed by the enterprise architecture board." The project manager argues this adds significant overhead and wasn't in the original charter.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST APPROPRIATE action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the project management plan to reflect the new governance requirement and communicate to the team
distractors: Push back on the requirement since it wasn't in the original charter
Document the requirement but implement it only for "major" design changes to minimize overhead
Request that the steering committee clarify whether this requirement applies to this project

answers.text: Update the project management plan to reflect the new governance requirement and communicate to the team
Push back on the requirement since it wasn't in the original charter
Document the requirement but implement it only for "major" design changes to minimize overhead
Request that the steering committee clarify whether this requirement applies to this project

remediation.coreLogic: Stage gates are governance checkpoints where requirements can be added based on evolving understanding. The gate committee has authority to impose new constraints. The PM's role is to implement, not challenge, legitimate governance decisions.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance is dynamic, not static. Stage gates exist specifically to allow course correction based on new information. The PM adapts rather than resisting governance decisions.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance vs. Management and Stage Gates

questions.scenario: A multinational project spans three countries with different data privacy laws. The PMO provides a standard privacy policy template based on GDPR (European Union regulations). However, the project also processes data from California (CCPA) and China (PIPL), which have different consent requirements. The project manager needs to determine how to handle the conflicting requirements.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST approach for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Work with legal/compliance to develop a consolidated privacy approach that meets the strictest requirements across all jurisdictions
distractors: Follow the GDPR template since it's the PMO standard and represents the most comprehensive regulation
Create separate privacy approaches for each jurisdiction and document this in the risk register
Request that the PMO update the template to account for multi-jurisdictional projects

answers.text: Work with legal/compliance to develop a consolidated privacy approach that meets the strictest requirements across all jurisdictions
Follow the GDPR template since it's the PMO standard and represents the most comprehensive regulation
Create separate privacy approaches for each jurisdiction and document this in the risk register
Request that the PMO update the template to account for multi-jurisdictional projects

remediation.coreLogic: When multiple jurisdictions apply, governance must satisfy the strictest requirements across all. PMO templates provide a starting point but may need legal tailoring for specific contexts. Legal/compliance has authority for interpretation.
remediation.pmiMindset: Templates are guidance, not substitutes for compliance judgment. When standard OPAs don't fit the situation, seek authoritative interpretation rather than improvising or selectively applying.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Data Privacy & AI and Key Regulations Reference Table

questions.scenario: A Scrum team's velocity has dropped 40% over three sprints. The product owner demands that the Scrum Master "fix the team's performance" and threatens to replace team members. The Scrum Master's analysis reveals that the drop is caused by the product owner adding spike stories to research a complex technical requirement, but these spikes are being counted in velocity calculations without delivering value.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Coach the product owner on the difference between delivery velocity and research spikes, and adjust metrics accordingly
distractors: Accept the product owner's demand and pressure the team to increase velocity
Remove the spike stories from velocity calculations without telling the product owner
Escalate to the steering committee that the product owner is misusing agile metrics

answers.text: Coach the product owner on the difference between delivery velocity and research spikes, and adjust metrics accordingly
Accept the product owner's demand and pressure the team to increase velocity
Remove the spike stories from velocity calculations without telling the product owner
Escalate to the steering committee that the product owner is misusing agile metrics

remediation.coreLogic: Velocity is a governance metric for forecasting delivery capacity. Spikes (research) don't deliver customer value and shouldn't be counted in velocity. The Scrum Master coaches stakeholders on proper metrics rather than gaming the system.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance metrics should measure what they intend to measure. When metrics are misused, the solution is education, not manipulation or escalation. The Scrum Master serves as a process coach.

questions.scenario: A project charter includes the success criterion: "Achieve ISO 27001 certification by Q3." During planning, the project manager discovers that ISO certification requires a 12-month audit trail, but the project timeline is only 9 months. The project manager raises this issue to the sponsor, who responds: "Just get as much of the certification process done as possible. We'll figure out the rest later."
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Request that the steering committee reassess the success criteria given the certification timeline constraint
distractors: Proceed with the 9-month plan and document the timeline constraint in the assumptions
Extend the project timeline to 12 months to accommodate certification requirements
Pursue a different certification that can be achieved within 9 months

answers.text: Request that the steering committee reassess the success criteria given the certification timeline constraint
Proceed with the 9-month plan and document the timeline constraint in the assumptions
Extend the project timeline to 12 months to accommodate certification requirements
Pursue a different certification that can be achieved within 9 months

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must be achievable. When a criterion (ISO certification in 9 months) is factually impossible, continuing with an unrealistic goal sets the project up for failure. The governance body (steering committee) must reassess.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM identifies when success criteria are unachievable and escalates for governance decision rather than quietly adjusting or accepting impossible targets.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - Measurable Success Criteria and Charter constraints

questions.scenario: A project manager learns that a functional manager is pressuring a team member to work on a non-project task during project hours. The charter explicitly authorizes the project manager to "assign and reassign team members within the project" but doesn't specifically address protecting team time from functional requests. The functional manager argues that the charter gives the PM authority over the project, not the team member's time.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Work with the functional manager and sponsor to clarify resource allocation governance in the charter
distractors: Redirect the team member to ignore the functional manager's request based on charter authority
Report the functional manager to the PMO for violating project governance
Allow the team member to split time and adjust the project schedule accordingly

answers.text: Work with the functional manager and sponsor to clarify resource allocation governance in the charter
Redirect the team member to ignore the functional manager's request based on charter authority
Report the functional manager to the PMO for violating project governance
Allow the team member to split time and adjust the project schedule accordingly

remediation.coreLogic: Charter authority ambiguity is a governance gap. Rather than interpreting the charter unilaterally or escalating punitively, the PM works collaboratively to clarify governance. Resource allocation conflicts are common and require clear rules of engagement.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance gaps are opportunities to improve clarity, not win power struggles. The PM collaborates to resolve ambiguity rather than asserting questionable authority.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - PM Authority Levels and Resource Commitment

questions.scenario: A project is chartered to "replace the legacy accounting system." Six months into execution, the steering committee learns that a new accounting standard will take effect before the project completes, requiring significant changes to requirements. The committee asks the project manager to assess the impact, but also notes that the charter's success criteria didn't specify compliance with the new standard since it wasn't known at initiation.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST response from the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the project scope to incorporate the new standard and present the impact to the steering committee for decision
distractors: Note that the charter doesn't require compliance with the new standard, so continue with the original scope
Request a charter amendment to add the new standard to the success criteria
Pause the project until the steering committee clarifies whether to incorporate the new standard

answers.text: Update the project scope to incorporate the new standard and present the impact to the steering committee for decision
Note that the charter doesn't require compliance with the new standard, so continue with the original scope
Request a charter amendment to add the new standard to the success criteria
Pause the project until the steering committee clarifies whether to incorporate the new standard

remediation.coreLogic: The retroactive rule means new regulations apply immediately regardless of charter timing. The PM's role is to assess impact and present options to the governance body, not debate whether the charter requires compliance.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM provides information and recommendations to governance bodies, not decisions about whether to comply. The steering committee decides based on the impact assessment.

questions.scenario: A product owner for a healthcare app adds a user story: "As a patient, I want to message my doctor directly." The development team raises concerns that this feature may create HIPAA compliance issues because messages would contain protected health information. The product owner argues that competitors have this feature and it's critical for market competitiveness.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner and compliance/legal to determine if the feature can be implemented compliantly
distractors: Allow the team to implement the feature since the product owner has prioritized it
Remove the story from the backlog until the product owner provides compliance documentation
Have the team implement the feature with basic security and defer full HIPAA compliance to a later sprint

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner and compliance/legal to determine if the feature can be implemented compliantly
Allow the team to implement the feature since the product owner has prioritized it
Remove the story from the backlog until the product owner provides compliance documentation
Have the team implement the feature with basic security and defer full HIPAA compliance to a later sprint

remediation.coreLogic: Compliance concerns require authoritative input, not team or product owner judgment. The Scrum Master facilitates a conversation between the product owner (business need) and compliance/legal (constraints) to find a compliant solution.
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance is a constraint on product development, not an optional quality attribute. The team doesn't make compliance decisions—legal/compliance does.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - HIPAA in Key Regulations Reference Table

questions.scenario: A project manager discovers that the organization's gift policy prohibits accepting items over $50 in value. A vendor sends the project manager a $200 gift basket as a "thank you" for smooth project execution. The project manager's peers suggest keeping the gift since "everyone does it" and the vendor won't know if it's returned.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ETHICAL action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Return the gift to the vendor with a polite explanation of the gift policy
distractors: Accept the gift but disclose it in the project's next status report
Share the gift with the entire project team so no individual receives the full value
Donate the gift to a charity and claim the tax deduction

answers.text: Return the gift to the vendor with a polite explanation of the gift policy
Accept the gift but disclose it in the project's next status report
Share the gift with the entire project team so no individual receives the full value
Donate the gift to a charity and claim the tax deduction

remediation.coreLogic: PMI's ethical value of honesty requires following organizational policies on gifts and vendor relationships. Accepting prohibited gifts violates ethics regardless of disclosure, sharing, or donation. The correct action is return, not rationalization.
remediation.pmiMindset: Ethical decisions aren't situational. A violation is a violation regardless of whether "everyone does it" or whether the vendor finds out.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's charter specifies that scope changes impacting the schedule by more than 2 weeks require steering committee approval. The team discovers a more efficient technical approach that would reduce the schedule by 3 weeks but requires a scope change. The project manager argues that since the impact is positive (schedule reduction), it doesn't require escalation.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Present the approach to the steering committee since the scope change threshold was exceeded
distractors: Approve the scope change internally since the impact is beneficial to the project
Implement the change incrementally to avoid triggering the 2-week threshold on any single change
Request clarification from the PMO on whether positive impacts require the same approval process

answers.text: Present the approach to the steering committee since the scope change threshold was exceeded
Approve the scope change internally since the impact is beneficial to the project
Implement the change incrementally to avoid triggering the 2-week threshold on any single change
Request clarification from the PMO on whether positive impacts require the same approval process

remediation.coreLogic: Governance thresholds exist for transparency and oversight, not just risk management. Significant scope changes—whether positive or negative—deserve governance visibility. The threshold is about impact magnitude, not impact direction.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM provides transparency to governance bodies even when news is good. Oversight isn't just about catching problems—it's about understanding project evolution.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - PM Authority Levels and Escalation procedures

questions.scenario: A government project includes the charter requirement: "Maintain CMMI Level 3 certification throughout the project." The organization loses its CMMI certification due to issues in other departments, though this project remains compliant. The sponsor suggests keeping the requirement in the charter since "we'll recertify soon."
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?

distractors: Keep the requirement in the charter since the project itself is CMMI compliant
Document the gap between charter and reality in the risk register
Request an exception from the steering committee to maintain the requirement despite organizational status

answers.text: Update the charter to reflect the actual certification status and communicate to stakeholders
Keep the requirement in the charter since the project itself is CMMI compliant
Document the gap between charter and reality in the risk register
Request an exception from the steering committee to maintain the requirement despite organizational status

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must be accurate. When a criterion becomes factually impossible through no fault of the project, maintaining it in the charter misleads stakeholders and sets up failure. The charter must reflect reality.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM ensures project documentation accurately represents reality. Continuing with an unachievable success criterion violates honest communication.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/05-initiation/project-charter.md - Measurable Success Criteria must be achievable

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is working on a project that must comply with SOC 2 Type II certification. During sprint planning, the security officer demands that all user stories include detailed security acceptance criteria. The product owner argues this slows down the team and that security can be "tested in" later. The Scrum Master is caught between the security requirement and velocity concerns.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Support the security officer's requirement since SOC 2 compliance is a non-negotiable constraint
distractors: Facilitate a compromise where security is tested in every other sprint
Ask the security officer to attend sprint reviews rather than planning
Escalate to the product owner's manager to resolve the conflict

answers.text: Support the security officer's requirement since SOC 2 compliance is a non-negotiable constraint
Facilitate a compromise where security is tested in every other sprint
Ask the security officer to attend sprint reviews rather than planning
Escalate to the product owner's manager to resolve the conflict

remediation.coreLogic: Certification requirements are constraints on how work is done, not negotiable features. SOC 2 Type II requires demonstrating consistent security practices, which means building security in from the start, not "testing it in later."
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance constraints override velocity optimization. The Scrum Master protects the team from pressure to cut corners on requirements that are non-negotiable.

questions.scenario: A project charter authorizes the project manager to "approve expenditures up to $15,000 without additional approval." The project manager has been consistently approving purchases at the $14,500 level to avoid triggering additional oversight. A new PMO auditor questions this pattern and suggests it may violate procurement governance principles.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Review the intent of the approval threshold and adjust practices to align with governance principles
distractors: Continue the current practice since each individual approval is within the $15,000 authority
Request that the PMO clarify the threshold in writing
Bundle purchases to stay under the threshold while meeting project needs

answers.text: Review the intent of the approval threshold and adjust practices to align with governance principles
Continue the current practice since each individual approval is within the $15,000 authority
Request that the PMO clarify the threshold in writing
Bundle purchases to stay under the threshold while meeting project needs

remediation.coreLogic: Governance thresholds exist for oversight, not to be technically navigated around. Consistently approving at $14,500 when the limit is $15,000 suggests exploiting the threshold rather than respecting its intent.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM follows the spirit of governance, not just the letter. Consistent patterns just under thresholds signal avoidance of oversight rather than legitimate decentralized decision-making.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - PMO Types (Controlling) and audit services

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's success criteria include "Achieve net promoter score of 50+ within 90 days of launch." At launch, the product is excellent, but the operations team fails to implement the customer feedback collection system specified in the project plan. Ninety days later, no NPS data exists, so success cannot be measured. The steering committee asks the project manager why this wasn't escalated.
questions.questionText: What is the PRIMARY governance failure in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: The success criteria should have assigned ownership of post-launch metrics to a specific role
distractors: The project manager should have escalated the operations team's failure to implement the collection system
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports on NPS collection
The PMO should have provided better oversight of the transition to operations

answers.text: The success criteria should have assigned ownership of post-launch metrics to a specific role
The project manager should have escalated the operations team's failure to implement the collection system
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports on NPS collection
The PMO should have provided better oversight of the transition to operations

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria that extend beyond project execution require assigned ownership for achievement and measurement. Without specifying who is responsible for post-launch metrics, the criteria is unenforceable.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance requires accountability assignment. Success criteria without ownership is wishful thinking, not a measurable target.

questions.scenario: A project manager is leading a pharmaceutical trial project. The charter requires FDA compliance at all stages. During execution, a team member suggests a faster testing approach that would accelerate the timeline but doesn't fully align with FDA guidelines. The scientific lead supports the approach as "scientifically valid" even if not explicitly FDA-approved.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Reject the approach until FDA compliance is verified through the appropriate channels
distractors: Allow a small pilot to test the faster approach while seeking FDA guidance
Escalate to the steering committee to decide between speed and compliance
Document the team member's suggestion in the risk register and continue with the FDA-approved approach

answers.text: Reject the approach until FDA compliance is verified through the appropriate channels
Allow a small pilot to test the faster approach while seeking FDA guidance
Escalate to the steering committee to decide between speed and compliance
Document the team member's suggestion in the risk register and continue with the FDA-approved approach

remediation.coreLogic: Regulatory compliance in high-stakes domains (pharmaceuticals) is non-negotiable. The PM doesn't have authority to approve deviations from regulatory requirements, regardless of scientific opinion or steering committee input.
remediation.pmiMindset: Safety and compliance are absolute. The PM stops work when compliance is in question rather than allowing "pilot tests" of regulatory gray areas.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Compliance hierarchy and laws taking precedence

questions.scenario: A product owner wants to use customer photos in marketing materials. The development team notes that the terms of service don't explicitly grant this right. The product owner argues that since customers uploaded the photos, implicit consent exists. The Scrum Master is concerned about privacy compliance.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Request legal review of whether the terms of service permit the proposed marketing use
distractors: Support the product owner since standard terms usually permit marketing use
Ask the product owner to obtain explicit consent from customers before using their photos
Add a user story to update the terms of service for future uploads

answers.text: Request legal review of whether the terms of service permit the proposed marketing use
Support the product owner since standard terms usually permit marketing use
Ask the product owner to obtain explicit consent from customers before using their photos
Add a user story to update the terms of service for future uploads

remediation.coreLogic: Data privacy compliance requires legal interpretation of terms and consent. The product owner and team don't have authority to determine whether implicit consent is sufficient—legal does.
remediation.pmiMindset: Privacy requirements are non-negotiable constraints on product development. The PM/Scrum Master facilitates legal review rather than making compliance decisions.

questions.scenario: A project charter includes the success criterion: "Reduce carbon emissions by 25% compared to baseline." At project closure, the project manager reports 26% reduction and declares success. However, an external audit reveals that the baseline measurement was calculated incorrectly, and actual reduction was only 18%. The project manager argues that the charter defined the baseline, so the project succeeded by that definition.
questions.questionText: What is the PRIMARY governance issue in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: The charter should have specified how the baseline would be measured and verified
distractors: The external auditor should have been involved at charter development to define the baseline
The steering committee should have required third-party verification of the baseline
The PMO should have provided a standard template for environmental metrics

answers.text: The charter should have specified how the baseline would be measured and verified
The external auditor should have been involved at charter development to define the baseline
The steering committee should have required third-party verification of the baseline
The PMO should have provided a standard template for environmental metrics

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must include measurement methodology. "Reduce by 25%" is meaningless without defining how the baseline and reduction are calculated. Governance failure occurred at charter creation by not specifying measurement approach.
remediation.pmiMindset: SMART criteria require defining not just what success looks like, but how it will be measured and verified. Ambiguous measurement enables gaming or misinterpretation.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has a directive PMO that requires all projects to use its standardized status report template. The project manager finds that the template doesn't capture Agile metrics like velocity and cycle time that are relevant to this project. The project manager considers submitting two reports—the PMO template plus an Agile supplement.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Work with the PMO to incorporate Agile metrics into the standard template for hybrid projects
distractors: Submit both the required PMO template and the Agile supplement report
Use only the PMO template since directive PMO requirements are mandatory
Ask the steering committee to exempt this project from the PMO template requirement

answers.text: Work with the PMO to incorporate Agile metrics into the standard template for hybrid projects
Submit both the required PMO template and the Agile supplement report
Use only the PMO template since directive PMO requirements are mandatory
Ask the steering committee to exempt this project from the PMO template requirement

remediation.coreLogic: Directive PMOs have authority over reporting standards, but the PM can suggest improvements to templates that don't fit current methodologies. Working with the PMO to improve the template serves both governance compliance and project needs.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM follows mandatory standards while also serving as a feedback mechanism for process improvement. Submitting unsupplemented reports or creating shadow processes bypasses governance.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - Directive PMO characteristics and PMO Services

questions.scenario: A project charter authorizes the project manager to approve scope changes "with schedule impact under 2 weeks." A requested change would delay the schedule by 12 days (under 2 weeks), but the project manager knows this will push the project past a key stakeholder's desired date. The stakeholder is pressuring the project manager to reject the change to protect their timeline.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Approve the change since it's within the chartered authority, and communicate the schedule impact to all stakeholders
distractors: Reject the change to accommodate the stakeholder's preferred timeline
Escalate to the steering committee to decide between the change and the stakeholder's timeline
Negotiate with the requestor to reduce the change's scope to fit within the stakeholder's timeline

answers.text: Approve the change since it's within the chartered authority, and communicate the schedule impact to all stakeholders
Reject the change to accommodate the stakeholder's preferred timeline
Escalate to the steering committee to decide between the change and the stakeholder's timeline
Negotiate with the requestor to reduce the change's scope to fit within the stakeholder's timeline

remediation.coreLogic: The charter grants approval authority for a reason—decentralized decision-making. If the change meets the criteria (under 2 weeks), the PM should exercise their granted authority rather than escalating or rejecting based on a stakeholder preference.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM makes decisions within granted authority and communicates transparently. Stakeholder preferences don't override the governance framework established in the charter.

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is working on a product that processes payments. During a retrospective, the team discovers they've been storing payment card data in violation of PCI DSS requirements. The product owner was unaware of this requirement and argues that fixing it would delay planned features. The Scrum Master needs to decide how to handle this compliance gap.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Stop work on all other features until the PCI DSS violation is corrected
distractors: Add a user story to address PCI DSS compliance in the next sprint
Escalate to the steering committee to decide whether to fix the violation or continue with planned features
Document the violation in the risk register and continue with planned features

answers.text: Stop work on all other features until the PCI DSS violation is corrected
Add a user story to address PCI DSS compliance in the next sprint
Escalate to the steering committee to decide whether to fix the violation or continue with planned features
Document the violation in the risk register and continue with planned features

remediation.coreLogic: PCI DSS compliance is non-negotiable for payment processing. Storing card data improperly creates legal liability. This is a stop-work situation, not a prioritization decision. Compliance violations are corrected immediately, not scheduled.
remediation.pmiMindset: Safety and compliance violations trigger immediate corrective action regardless of impact to planned work. The PM doesn't trade compliance for feature delivery.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Compliance Radar and Safety Violation scenarios

questions.scenario: A project manager learns that a team member is the sibling of a vendor being considered for a major contract. The team member offers to recuse themselves from the decision, but the project manager has the final authority on vendor selection per the charter. The project manager considers allowing the team member to participate since they've offered to recuse if needed.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ETHICAL action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Require the team member to recuse themselves from all vendor selection activities
distractors: Allow participation but require the team member to disclose the relationship before providing input
Document the relationship and allow participation since the team member offered to recuse
Escalate to the PMO for guidance on whether recusal is necessary

answers.text: Require the team member to recuse themselves from all vendor selection activities
Allow participation but require the team member to disclose the relationship before providing input
Document the relationship and allow participation since the team member offered to recuse

remediation.pmiMindset: Ethical governance requires preventing the appearance of bias, not just managing actual bias. The PM ensures conflicts are eliminated, not just documented.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's charter specifies a $1M budget with 10% contingency. At 80% complete, the project has spent $920K including $80K of contingency. The remaining work requires an additional $150K, which would exceed both the original budget and the contingency. The project manager considers re-baselining the budget.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Present the situation to the steering committee with options for re-baselining or scope reduction
distractors: Use the remaining contingency to cover as much of the overrun as possible
Re-baseline the budget without steering committee approval since the project is 80% complete
Request additional funds from the PMO as a simple budget transfer

answers.text: Present the situation to the steering committee with options for re-baselining or scope reduction
Use the remaining contingency to cover as much of the overrun as possible
Re-baseline the budget without steering committee approval since the project is 80% complete
Request additional funds from the PMO as a simple budget transfer

remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages within the authorized budget envelope. When that envelope is exceeded, the governance body that authorized the budget must decide how to proceed.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and Major Funding decisions

questions.scenario: A project charter includes the success criterion: "Achieve customer satisfaction score of 4.5/5.0." Declare the project a failure since the criterion wasn't met
Require a new customer satisfaction survey to be administered

answers.text: Acknowledge the external factor and consider whether the success criterion remains appropriate under the circumstances
Adjust the satisfaction score to 4.5/5.0 to reflect the actual project quality delivered
Declare the project a failure since the criterion wasn't met

remediation.pmiMindset: Governance is about evaluating value delivery, not rigid adherence to metrics that may be skewed by uncontrollable factors. The governance body exercises judgment.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/pmo-role.md - Benefits Tracking and value-driven governance

questions.scenario: A product owner for a fitness app wants to sell user workout data to insurance companies. The development team notes that the privacy policy says user data "will never be sold." The product owner argues that the policy can be updated and users can opt-out. The Scrum Master is concerned about retroactively changing privacy terms.

remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Data Privacy principles and GDPR/CCPA requirements

questions.scenario: A project manager learns of a new environmental regulation that will affect the project's waste disposal practices. The regulation takes effect in 2 months, but the current project phase won't generate waste for 4 months. The project manager considers waiting to address the regulation until it becomes applicable.

Continue with current practices since the regulation doesn't apply to current project work
Request clarification from the environmental agency on how the regulation applies to the project

answers.text: Update the project management plan now to incorporate the new requirements before they take effect
Document the regulation in the risk register and address it when waste disposal begins
Continue with current practices since the regulation doesn't apply to current project work
Request clarification from the environmental agency on how the regulation applies to the project

remediation.coreLogic: Proactive compliance planning is more efficient than reactive correction. Even though the regulation doesn't apply immediately, updating the plan now ensures compliance when the time comes and prevents rework.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM proactively manages compliance requirements rather than waiting until they become urgent. Good governance is anticipatory, not reactive.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - The Retroactive Rule and proactive compliance

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's charter includes the success criterion: "Deliver 100 user stories." Update the charter to reflect "value delivered" rather than "story count" as the success criterion

Update the charter to reflect "value delivered" rather than "story count" as the success criterion

questions.scenario: A project manager receives an email from a vendor offering a "consulting fee" if the project manager selects their product. The email notes that "this is standard industry practice" and that the fee would be paid personally, not to the company. The project manager is tempted by the extra income.

questions.correctAnswer: Decline the offer and report the vendor's solicitation to the procurement department
distractors: Decline the offer but do not report the vendor to maintain a good relationship
Accept the offer since it's personal income, not a company payment
Disclose the offer to the sponsor and ask for guidance

Decline the offer but do not report the vendor to maintain a good relationship
Accept the offer since it's personal income, not a company payment

remediation.coreLogic: PM authority in the charter typically references budget thresholds, but contractual obligations represent external governance that exceeds PM approval authority. Missing contractual deadlines triggers penalties and legal implications.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages within the project's governance envelope. External commitments (contracts) create governance obligations requiring escalation.
remediation.theTrap: Focusing only on the budget threshold ($25,000 is under $50,000) misses that schedule impact triggers contractual consequences beyond PM authority.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and external commitments

questions.scenario: A project manager is preparing a project charter and needs to define success criteria. distractors: Accept the sponsor's criteria since the sponsor has authority over the charter and can interpret them during execution
Document the vague criteria in the charter and add specific metrics in the project management plan
Ask the compliance department to provide standard success criteria for this type of project

answers.text: Push back on the vague criteria and work with the sponsor to define specific, measurable compliance metrics (e.g., "zero regulatory violations," "100% training completion")
Accept the sponsor's criteria since the sponsor has authority over the charter and can interpret them during execution
Document the vague criteria in the charter and add specific metrics in the project management plan
Ask the compliance department to provide standard success criteria for this type of project

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria in the charter must be measurable to enable governance assessment. Vague criteria undermine governance and prevent objective assessment of project success.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM ensures project artifacts are fit for purpose. Unmeasurable success criteria create governance failure—success can't be objectively assessed.
remediation.theTrap: Accepting vague criteria seems respectful of sponsor authority, but creates governance failure—compliance can't be objectively verified.

questions.scenario: A project charter includes the success criterion: "Reduce carbon emissions by 25% compared to baseline." However, an external audit reveals that the baseline measurement was calculated incorrectly, and actual reduction was only 18%. The project manager argues that the charter defined the baseline, so the project succeeded by that definition.
questions.questionText: What is the PRIMARY governance issue in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: The charter should have specified how the baseline would be measured, verified, and audited
distractors: The external auditor should have been involved at charter development to validate the baseline methodology
The steering committee should have required third-party verification of the baseline measurement
The PMO should have provided a standard template for environmental metrics with validated calculation methods

answers.text: The charter should have specified how the baseline would be measured, verified, and audited
The external auditor should have been involved at charter development to validate the baseline methodology
The steering committee should have required third-party verification of the baseline measurement
The PMO should have provided a standard template for environmental metrics with validated calculation methods

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must include measurement methodology. "Reduce by 25%" is meaningless without defining how the baseline and reduction are calculated and verified.

questions.scenario: A Scrum team discovers that a third-party library they've been using has a critical security vulnerability. questions.correctAnswer: Stop using the vulnerable library immediately, even if it means reducing the sprint commitment to address security
distractors: Continue using the library for this sprint and plan to fix it in the next sprint
Escalate to the product owner's manager to get approval for an immediate fix
Add the security fix as a high-priority item in the next sprint backlog

answers.text: Stop using the vulnerable library immediately, even if it means reducing the sprint commitment to address security
Continue using the library for this sprint and plan to fix it in the next sprint
Escalate to the product owner's manager to get approval for an immediate fix

remediation.pmiMindset: Security and safety are non-negotiable. Sprint commitments don't override the obligation to address critical security issues immediately.
remediation.theTrap: Planning to fix in the next sprint treats this as normal prioritization, but critical vulnerabilities are immediate risks, not scheduled work items.

questions.scenario: A project manager receives an email from a vendor offering a "consulting fee" if the project manager selects their product. The project manager is tempted by the extra income and considers that this might just be a standard commission.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ETHICAL action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Decline the offer and report the vendor's solicitation to the procurement department
distractors: Decline the offer but do not report the vendor to maintain a good business relationship
Accept the offer since it's personal income, not a company payment
Disclose the offer to the sponsor and ask for guidance on whether to accept

answers.text: Decline the offer and report the vendor's solicitation to the procurement department
Decline the offer but do not report the vendor to maintain a good business relationship
Accept the offer since it's personal income, not a company payment
Disclose the offer to the sponsor and ask for guidance on whether to accept

questions.scenario: A hybrid project uses a directive PMO that requires all projects to use its standardized status report template.
