questions.correctAnswer: Work with the PMO to incorporate Agile metrics into the standard template for hybrid projects
distractors: Submit both the required PMO template and the Agile supplement report
Use only the PMO template since directive PMO requirements are mandatory
Ask the steering committee to exempt this project from the PMO template requirement

answers.text: Work with the PMO to incorporate Agile metrics into the standard template for hybrid projects
Submit both the required PMO template and the Agile supplement report
Use only the PMO template since directive PMO requirements are mandatory
Ask the steering committee to exempt this project from the PMO template requirement

remediation.coreLogic: Directive PMOs have authority over reporting standards, but the PM can suggest improvements to templates that don't fit current methodologies. Working with the PMO serves both governance compliance and project needs.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM follows mandatory standards while also serving as a feedback mechanism for process improvement. Submitting unsupplemented reports or creating shadow processes bypasses governance.

questions.scenario: A project manager learns of a new environmental regulation that will affect the project's waste disposal practices. The project manager considers waiting to address the regulation until it becomes applicable to avoid "wasting time" on requirements that aren't immediately needed.

questions.correctAnswer: Update the project management plan now to incorporate the new requirements before they take effect
distractors: Document the regulation in the risk register and address it when waste disposal begins in 4 months
Continue with current practices since the regulation doesn't apply to current project work

answers.text: Update the project management plan now to incorporate the new requirements before they take effect
Document the regulation in the risk register and address it when waste disposal begins in 4 months
Continue with current practices since the regulation doesn't apply to current project work
Request clarification from the environmental agency on how the regulation applies to the project timeline

remediation.coreLogic: Proactive compliance planning is more efficient than reactive correction. Updating the plan now ensures compliance when the time comes and prevents rework.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM proactively manages compliance requirements rather than waiting until they become urgent. Good governance is anticipatory, not reactive.
remediation.theTrap: Waiting until the regulation applies seems efficient, but may require rework if current planning doesn't account for the new requirements.

questions.scenario: A product owner for a financial application wants to use customer transaction data to train a machine learning model for fraud detection. Conduct a team vote on whether the feature complies with data privacy requirements
Document the team's concerns in the sprint backlog and proceed with development

answers.text: Pause the feature and request guidance from legal/compliance on whether existing consent covers ML training use
Allow the product owner to proceed since they are accountable for product decisions and customer benefit
Conduct a team vote on whether the feature complies with data privacy requirements

remediation.coreLogic: Regulatory interpretation is not within a Scrum team's or product owner's authority. When compliance questions arise, pause and seek authoritative guidance from legal/compliance.
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance requirements are non-negotiable constraints on Agile delivery. The team has autonomy on HOW to build, but not on WHETHER to comply with regulations.
remediation.theTrap: Allowing the product owner to decide seems to respect Agile autonomy, but regulatory compliance is a strategic guardrail that exceeds product owner authority.

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing the change control log and notices that 15 change requests have been approved in the past month, each within the project manager's approval authority of $10,000. Collectively, these changes represent a $120,000 budget impact that was never presented to the Change Control Board or steering committee. The project manager's authority was intended for minor adjustments, not cumulative scope changes.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Immediately notify the steering committee and CCB of the cumulative impact and request formal approval
distractors: Continue approving changes within authority since each individual request was within the $10,000 limit
Stop approving any further changes and request a charter revision to clarify approval authority
Update the risk register to note the budget overrun and continue with remaining changes

Stop approving any further changes and request a charter revision to clarify approval authority

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has an escalation threshold: any issue that impacts the project schedule by more than 2 weeks must be escalated to the sponsor. However, fast-tracking requires adding overtime which exceeds the budget's contingency reserve.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST APPROPRIATE action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Escalate to the sponsor since the recovery method requires exceeding contingency reserves
distractors: Implement the fast-tracking plan without escalation since the net schedule impact is within threshold

Accept the 10-day delay and escalate since it exceeds the 2-week threshold

answers.text: Escalate to the sponsor since the recovery method requires exceeding contingency reserves
Implement the fast-tracking plan without escalation since the net schedule impact is within threshold
Request additional budget from the PMO to cover the overtime costs
Accept the 10-day delay and escalate since it exceeds the 2-week threshold

remediation.coreLogic: Escalation thresholds should be interpreted broadly. When the recovery method impacts other baselines (budget contingency), the governance intent is triggered. Escalation provides visibility into trade-offs.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance thresholds are tripwires for stakeholder visibility, not rules to be technically navigated around. The PM provides transparency when significant trade-offs are required.
remediation.theTrap: Triggering the technical interpretation (net 5 days is under 2 weeks) avoids escalation but hides the budget impact from governance oversight.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and escalation intent

questions.scenario: A project manager discovers that the organization's gift policy prohibits accepting items over $50 in value. The project manager's peers suggest keeping the gift since "everyone does it" and the vendor won't know if it's returned, or sharing it with the team so no individual receives the full value.

questions.correctAnswer: Return the gift to the vendor with a polite explanation of the gift policy
distractors: Accept the gift but disclose it in the project's next status report

Donate the gift to a charity and claim the tax deduction

questions.scenario: A Scrum team's velocity has dropped 40% over three sprints. The product owner demands that the Scrum Master "fix the team's performance" and threatens to replace team members. questions.scenario: During a project status review, the PMO director questions why a project has exceeded its schedule variance threshold of ±10% for three consecutive weeks. questions.scenario: A project manager learns that a functional manager is pressuring a team member to work on a non-project task during project hours. questions.scenario: A product owner wants to use customer photos in marketing materials. The development team notes that the terms of service don't explicitly grant this right. questions.scenario: A project manager is assigned to lead a cross-functional initiative involving three departments. Each department has its own PMO with different templates and approval processes. questions.scenario: A project manager discovers that the organization's procurement policy (OPA) requires competitive bidding for all contracts over $50,000. questions.scenario: A Scrum team is working on a project that must comply with SOC 2 Type II certification. questions.scenario: A project manager is managing a global project. In Country A, "facilitation payments" (small payments to expedite routine government actions) are legal and customary. questions.scenario: A hybrid project uses a phased approach with quarterly gates for strategic milestones and 2-week sprints for tactical delivery. questions.questionText: What is the MOST APPROPRIATE action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the project management plan to reflect the new governance requirement and communicate to the team
distractors: Push back on the requirement since it wasn't in the original charter
Document the requirement but implement it only for "major" design changes to minimize overhead
Request that the steering committee clarify whether this requirement applies to this project

answers.text: Update the project management plan to reflect the new governance requirement and communicate to the team
Push back on the requirement since it wasn't in the original charter
Document the requirement but implement it only for "major" design changes to minimize overhead
Request that the steering committee clarify whether this requirement applies to this project

remediation.coreLogic: Stage gates are governance checkpoints where requirements can be added based on evolving understanding. The gate committee has authority to impose new constraints. The PM implements, not challenges.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance is dynamic, not static. Stage gates exist specifically to allow course correction based on new information. The PM adapts rather than resisting.
remediation.theTrap: Pushing back seems to protect the team, but stage gates are designed for governance adaptation. The committee has authority to add requirements.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance vs. Management and Stage Gates

questions.scenario: A project manager is preparing the project charter and needs to define success criteria for sustainability. The sponsor suggests: "Minimize environmental impact and maximize social benefit." The project manager is concerned these aren't measurable and suggests specific metrics like "reduce carbon emissions by 20%" and "source 50% of materials from certified sustainable suppliers."
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Advocate for the specific, measurable metrics and explain to the sponsor that vague criteria prevent objective assessment of sustainability success
distractors: Accept the sponsor's vague criteria since sustainability is difficult to measure and can be interpreted during execution
Document the sponsor's vague criteria in the charter and add specific metrics in the project management plan
Ask the sustainability department to provide standard metrics for this type of project

answers.text: Advocate for the specific, measurable metrics and explain to the sponsor that vague criteria prevent objective assessment of sustainability success
Accept the sponsor's vague criteria since sustainability is difficult to measure and can be interpreted during execution
Document the sponsor's vague criteria in the charter and add specific metrics in the project management plan
Ask the sustainability department to provide standard metrics for this type of project

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria must be measurable to enable governance assessment. Vague sustainability criteria undermine governance and prevent objective verification of ESG commitments.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM ensures project artifacts are fit for purpose. Unmeasurable success criteria create governance failure—sustainability claims can't be verified.
remediation.theTrap: Accepting vague criteria seems flexible, but creates governance failure where "success" is subjective and unverified.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - ESG compliance and measurable success criteria

questions.scenario: A product owner for a healthcare app adds a user story: "As a patient, I want to message my doctor directly." The development team raises concerns that this feature may create HIPAA compliance issues because messages would contain protected health information. The product owner argues that competitors have this feature and it's critical for market competitiveness, so the team should figure out how to make it compliant.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner and compliance/legal to determine if the feature can be implemented compliantly
distractors: Allow the team to implement the feature since the product owner has prioritized it and the business need is clear
Remove the story from the backlog until the product owner provides compliance documentation
Have the team implement the feature with basic security and defer full HIPAA compliance to a later sprint

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion with the product owner and compliance/legal to determine if the feature can be implemented compliantly
Allow the team to implement the feature since the product owner has prioritized it and the business need is clear
Remove the story from the backlog until the product owner provides compliance documentation
Have the team implement the feature with basic security and defer full HIPAA compliance to a later sprint

remediation.coreLogic: Compliance concerns require authoritative input, not team or product owner judgment. The Scrum Master facilitates a conversation between the product owner (business need) and compliance/legal (constraints).
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance is a constraint on product development, not an optional quality attribute. The team doesn't make compliance decisions—legal/compliance does.
remediation.theTrap: Implementing with "basic security" seems pragmatic, but partial HIPAA compliance doesn't exist—either the feature is compliant or it isn't.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - HIPAA in Key Regulations Reference Table

questions.scenario: A project manager receives a whistleblower complaint that a team member is falsifying safety inspection reports to avoid delays. The team member admits to falsifying the reports but claims the safety issues were minor and "didn't matter." The project manager considers whether to report this to HR or handle it internally to protect the team member's career.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ETHICAL action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Report the falsification to HR, the safety officer, and the sponsor, and ensure the safety inspections are properly re-conducted
distractors: Handle it internally by requiring the team member to re-conduct the inspections correctly and document the coaching
Report to the safety officer only, to keep the issue within the safety function and protect the team member
Document the incident but allow the team member to continue since the safety issues were minor

answers.text: Report the falsification to HR, the safety officer, and the sponsor, and ensure the safety inspections are properly re-conducted
Handle it internally by requiring the team member to re-conduct the inspections correctly and document the coaching
Report to the safety officer only, to keep the issue within the safety function and protect the team member
Document the incident but allow the team member to continue since the safety issues were minor

remediation.coreLogic: Falsifying safety reports is a serious ethical and legal violation that cannot be handled internally. Whistleblower complaints and safety violations require formal reporting and investigation.
remediation.pmiMindset: PMI's ethical value of Responsibility requires protecting the organization and profession. Safety falsification is never minor and cannot be "coached away" internally.
remediation.theTrap: Handling internally seems compassionate, but falsification is a firing offense and potential legal liability—not a coaching opportunity.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Ethical Compass and Safety Violation scenarios

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has a controlling PMO that requires all projects to use its risk register template. The project manager finds the template doesn't accommodate Agile-specific risks like "team burnout from excessive sprint velocity" or "technical debt accumulation." The project manager considers maintaining two risk registers—the PMO template for reporting and an Agile register for internal use.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Use the PMO template but add Agile-specific risk categories in the "notes" or "custom fields" sections
distractors: Maintain two separate risk registers to satisfy both PMO and Agile needs
Use only the PMO template since controlling PMO requirements are mandatory
Request an exemption from the PMO to use a custom risk register template

answers.text: Use the PMO template but add Agile-specific risk categories in the "notes" or "custom fields" sections
Maintain two separate risk registers to satisfy both PMO and Agile needs
Use only the PMO template since controlling PMO requirements are mandatory
Request an exemption from the PMO to use a custom risk register template

remediation.coreLogic: Controlling PMOs mandate specific templates, but most templates include flexibility (custom fields, notes) for project-specific needs. The PM works within the framework rather than creating parallel systems.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM adapts to mandatory governance standards while finding ways to capture project-specific information within the framework.
remediation.theTrap: Maintaining two registers creates administrative overhead and data inconsistency. Working within the template is more efficient.

questions.scenario: A project charter specifies that the project manager "has authority to approve changes costing under $10,000." A change request comes in with an estimated cost of $9,500, but the project manager suspects the estimate is artificially low to avoid the $10,000 threshold. The actual cost will likely be $12,000, which would require escalation.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Reject the estimate as insufficient and require a more detailed cost analysis before approval
distractors: Approve the change since the submitted estimate is under the $10,000 threshold
Escalate to the CCB given the suspicion that the true cost exceeds the threshold
Approve with a note that additional funding will be required if costs exceed $10,000

answers.text: Reject the estimate as insufficient and require a more detailed cost analysis before approval
Approve the change since the submitted estimate is under the $10,000 threshold
Escalate to the CCB given the suspicion that the true cost exceeds the threshold
Approve with a note that additional funding will be required if costs exceed $10,000

remediation.coreLogic: Approval authority is based on informed decision-making. If the estimate appears artificially low to bypass thresholds, the PM requires better information rather than approving questionable estimates or escalating prematurely.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM exercises judgment within authority, not blind adherence to submitted numbers. Governance requires quality information, not just formal compliance.
remediation.theTrap: Escalating seems cautious, but the PM can first require better information. Not every suspicion requires escalation.

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is working on a product that must comply with GDPR's "right to be forgotten." During sprint planning, the product owner adds a user story for user profile deletion. A developer notes that while they can delete the profile from the primary database, the data has already been copied to a data warehouse for analytics, and there's no automated deletion process there. The product owner argues that manual deletion from the data warehouse is sufficient.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion with legal/compliance on whether manual deletion from the data warehouse satisfies GDPR's "right to be forgotten" requirement
distractors: Allow the story to proceed since the product owner has determined that manual deletion is acceptable
Block the story until an automated deletion process is implemented for the data warehouse
Add a technical debt story to build automated deletion and proceed with manual deletion in the meantime

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion with legal/compliance on whether manual deletion from the data warehouse satisfies GDPR's "right to be forgotten" requirement
Allow the story to proceed since the product owner has determined that manual deletion is acceptable
Block the story until an automated deletion process is implemented for the data warehouse
Add a technical debt story to build automated deletion and proceed with manual deletion in the meantime

remediation.coreLogic: GDPR compliance requires legal interpretation of whether "right to be forgotten" is satisfied by manual processes or requires automation. The product owner doesn't have authority to make this determination.
remediation.pmiMindset: Regulatory compliance requires authoritative interpretation. The Scrum Master facilitates legal review rather than allowing product owner or team judgment on regulatory questions.
remediation.theTrap: Blocking the story seems privacy-conscious, but the actual question is legal (does manual deletion satisfy GDPR?), not technical.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - GDPR requirements and Right to be Forgotten

questions.scenario: A government agency project requires compliance with new accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1 AA). The project charter was approved before these standards became law. The agency's PMO has not yet updated its templates to reference the new requirements. The project manager needs to determine how to proceed given the charter doesn't mention the new standard.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the project's quality management plan to incorporate WCAG 2.1 AA requirements and inform the PMO of the template gap
distractors: Proceed with the old accessibility standards since the charter predated the new law
Submit a change request to update the charter to reflect the new compliance requirements
Wait for the PMO to update its templates before incorporating the new requirements

answers.text: Update the project's quality management plan to incorporate WCAG 2.1 AA requirements and inform the PMO of the template gap
Proceed with the old accessibility standards since the charter predated the new law
Submit a change request to update the charter to reflect the new compliance requirements
Wait for the PMO to update its templates before incorporating the new requirements

remediation.coreLogic: New laws apply immediately to all active projects regardless of when they were initiated. The charter sets overall guardrails, but the execution plan must adapt to new legal requirements.
remediation.pmiMindset: Regulatory compliance is immediate and non-negotiable. The PM doesn't wait for governance artifacts to catch up—they implement requirements and help improve organizational assets.
remediation.theTrap: Waiting for the PMO to update templates seems procedural, but delays necessary compliance work. The project must comply now.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - The Retroactive Rule and proactive compliance

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's success criteria include "Achieve net promoter score of 50+ within 90 days of launch." At launch, the product is excellent, but the operations team fails to implement the customer feedback collection system specified in the project plan. Ninety days later, no NPS data exists, so success cannot be measured. The steering committee asks the project manager why this wasn't escalated.
questions.questionText: What is the PRIMARY governance failure in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: The success criteria should have assigned ownership of post-launch metrics to a specific role
distractors: The project manager should have escalated the operations team's failure to implement the collection system
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports on NPS collection
The PMO should have provided better oversight of the transition to operations

answers.text: The success criteria should have assigned ownership of post-launch metrics to a specific role
The project manager should have escalated the operations team's failure to implement the collection system
The steering committee should have required more frequent status reports on NPS collection
The PMO should have provided better oversight of the transition to operations

remediation.coreLogic: Success criteria that extend beyond project execution require assigned ownership for achievement and measurement. Without specifying who is responsible, the criteria is unenforceable.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance requires accountability assignment. Success criteria without ownership is wishful thinking, not a measurable target.
remediation.theTrap: Focusing on escalation misses that no one was actually assigned responsibility for the NPS system—it fell through governance design gaps.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Success criteria ownership and benefits tracking

questions.scenario: A project is chartered to "implement a new ERP system." Eighteen months into a 24-month project, a competing ERP vendor releases a significantly better product at lower cost. The project manager considers whether to recommend switching vendors mid-project, which would require writing off 18 months of investment but might deliver better long-term value.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Present a business case analysis to the steering committee comparing continued execution vs. switching vendors
distractors: Continue with the current vendor since the charter authorized this approach
Immediately switch vendors to deliver better value for the organization
Request a vendor comparison from the procurement department

answers.text: Present a business case analysis to the steering committee comparing continued execution vs. switching vendors
Continue with the current vendor since the charter authorized this approach
Immediately switch vendors to deliver better value for the organization
Request a vendor comparison from the procurement department

remediation.coreLogic: Major strategic decisions like switching vendors mid-project are governance decisions, not PM decisions. The PM provides analysis and recommendations, but the steering committee decides.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages execution within the strategic direction set by governance. When external changes make the current direction questionable, the governance body reassesses strategy.
remediation.theTrap: Continuing with the current vendor seems loyal to the charter, but charters don't obligate organizations to pursue bad strategies when better options emerge.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and strategic decisions

questions.scenario: A product owner wants to implement a feature that collects user location data for personalized recommendations. The development team notes that GDPR requires explicit consent for location data collection. The product owner argues that since users can opt out later in settings, implicit consent during onboarding is sufficient. The Scrum Master needs to ensure proper GDPR compliance.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Request legal guidance on whether the proposed consent flow satisfies GDPR's explicit consent requirement for location data
distractors: Support the product owner's approach since opt-out provides user control and many apps use this pattern
Block the feature until explicit opt-in consent is implemented during onboarding
Add a user story to implement explicit opt-in consent and proceed with the product owner's approach in the meantime

answers.text: Request legal guidance on whether the proposed consent flow satisfies GDPR's explicit consent requirement for location data
Support the product owner's approach since opt-out provides user control and many apps use this pattern
Block the feature until explicit opt-in consent is implemented during onboarding
Add a user story to implement explicit opt-in consent and proceed with the product owner's approach in the meantime

remediation.coreLogic: GDPR requires explicit consent for certain data types (location is often considered sensitive). The product owner and team don't have authority to interpret whether opt-out satisfies this requirement.
remediation.pmiMindset: Regulatory interpretation is not within team or product owner authority. The Scrum Master facilitates legal review rather than making compliance decisions.
remediation.theTrap: Blocking seems privacy-conscious, but the actual question is legal (does opt-out satisfy GDPR for location data?), not ethical.

questions.scenario: A project charter includes the success criterion: "Zero safety incidents throughout the project." During execution, a subcontractor has a near-miss accident that violated safety protocols but resulted in no injuries. The project manager stops work on that activity until root cause analysis is complete. The subcontractor argues that since no one was hurt, this doesn't count as a "safety incident" per the charter.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST response from the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain the work stoppage until root cause analysis and corrective actions are verified, as near-misses are safety incidents
distractors: Allow work to resume with increased oversight since no one was injured and the charter only counts actual incidents
Document the near-miss in the risk register and continue with additional safety briefings
Escalate to the sponsor to decide whether a near-miss counts as a safety incident under the charter

answers.text: Maintain the work stoppage until root cause analysis and corrective actions are verified, as near-misses are safety incidents
Allow work to resume with increased oversight since no one was injured and the charter only counts actual incidents
Document the near-miss in the risk register and continue with additional safety briefings
Escalate to the sponsor to decide whether a near-miss counts as a safety incident under the charter

remediation.coreLogic: Safety is non-negotiable and supersedes all other objectives. Near-misses are safety incidents that require immediate corrective action regardless of whether injury occurred. They're warnings that require systemic correction.
remediation.pmiMindset: Safety and legal compliance always win. The PM doesn't trade safety for schedule or debate whether near-misses "count"—they're treated as incidents.
remediation.theTrap: "Increased oversight" seems like a reasonable middle ground, but fails to address root cause. Near-misses are treated seriously, not minimized.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Safety Violation scenarios and zero-tolerance policies

questions.scenario: A hybrid project's charter specifies a $1M budget with 10% contingency. At 80% complete, the project has spent $920K including $80K of contingency. The remaining work requires an additional $150K, which would exceed both the original budget and the contingency. The project manager considers re-baselining the budget to the new reality without steering committee approval since the project is almost done.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Present the situation to the steering committee with options for re-baselining or scope reduction
distractors: Use the remaining contingency to cover as much of the overrun as possible and document the variance
Re-baseline the budget without steering committee approval since the project is 80% complete
Request additional funds from the PMO as a simple budget transfer

answers.text: Present the situation to the steering committee with options for re-baselining or scope reduction
Use the remaining contingency to cover as much of the overrun as possible and document the variance
Re-baseline the budget without steering committee approval since the project is 80% complete
Request additional funds from the PMO as a simple budget transfer

remediation.coreLogic: Exceeding the total budget (including contingency) is a baseline change that requires governance approval. Re-baselining is a steering committee decision, not a PM action.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM manages within the authorized budget envelope. When that envelope is exceeded, the governance body that authorized the budget must decide.
remediation.theTrap: Re-baselining unilaterally seems practical for a project that's 80% complete, but exceeds the PM's authority and bypasses governance oversight.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Governance Decision Matrix and Major Funding decisions

questions.scenario: A project manager is leading a project that will process user data to train AI models. The project manager learns that the engineering team has been using a public AI tool (like ChatGPT) to help debug code, and in doing so, has pasted snippets of production data that may contain user information. The team member didn't realize this was a privacy violation.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Immediately stop the data sharing, notify IT/security of the potential data breach, and educate the team on data privacy requirements
distractors: Document the incident as a lesson learned and remind the team not to share production data
Report the team member to HR for violating data privacy policies
Ask the team to use a different AI tool that doesn't store data

answers.text: Immediately stop the data sharing, notify IT/security of the potential data breach, and educate the team on data privacy requirements
Document the incident as a lesson learned and remind the team not to share production data
Report the team member to HR for violating data privacy policies
Ask the team to use a different AI tool that doesn't store data

remediation.coreLogic: Sharing production data with public AI tools is a data breach requiring immediate containment and security notification. The PM stops the practice, manages the breach response, and educates to prevent recurrence.
remediation.pmiMindset: Data breaches require immediate response, not just documentation or coaching. The PM ensures breach protocols are followed while also educating the team.
remediation.theTrap: Documenting as a lesson learned seems appropriate, but fails to treat this as the data breach it is—security must be notified immediately.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Data Privacy & AI section and data breach response

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is developing a product that uses AI to screen job candidates. During sprint review, the team demonstrates that the AI is 95% accurate at predicting good hires. However, a stakeholder asks whether the AI has been tested for demographic bias. The product owner admits that bias testing hasn't been conducted yet, and the team wants to focus on accuracy first.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Prioritize bias testing as a compliance requirement before the AI is used for actual hiring decisions
distractors: Allow the team to continue focusing on accuracy since bias testing can be added later
Escalate to the steering committee to decide whether accuracy or bias testing should be prioritized
Add bias testing to the product backlog as a lower priority item

answers.text: Prioritize bias testing as a compliance requirement before the AI is used for actual hiring decisions
Allow the team to continue focusing on accuracy since bias testing can be added later
Escalate to the steering committee to decide whether accuracy or bias testing should be prioritized
Add bias testing to the product backlog as a lower priority item

remediation.coreLogic: AI bias testing is a compliance requirement for hiring tools in many jurisdictions and an ethical imperative. Using an untested AI for hiring decisions creates legal liability and ethical risk.
remediation.pmiMindset: Compliance and ethics are non-negotiable. The Scrum Master ensures the team doesn't deploy AI tools without proper bias testing, regardless of accuracy metrics.
remediation.theTrap: Treating bias testing as a lower priority backlog item misses that it's a compliance requirement, not an optional feature.
remediation.sourceLink: guide/02-strategic/compliance-governance.md - Responsible AI & Data Ethics section and bias testing

questions.scenario: A construction project manager receives a formal change request from the client to upgrade the building automation system from standard to premium. The change control board approved the request with a budget increase of $150,000 and a schedule extension of 3 weeks. The project manager has a signed change order from the client but has not yet updated the performance measurement baseline or informed the procurement team about the new equipment requirements. The procurement team is preparing to release the RFP for automation system suppliers next week using the original specifications.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action the project manager should take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the cost and schedule baselines to reflect the approved change before proceeding with procurement activities
distractors: Instruct the procurement team to include both standard and premium specifications in the RFP to accommodate the change
Schedule a team meeting to communicate the approved change and its impact on project objectives
Document the change approval in the change log and file the signed change order in the project records

answers.text: Update the cost and schedule baselines to reflect the approved change before proceeding with procurement activities
Instruct the procurement team to include both standard and premium specifications in the RFP to accommodate the change
Schedule a team meeting to communicate the approved change and its impact on project objectives
Document the change approval in the change log and file the signed change order in the project records

remediation.coreLogic: In predictive methodology, approved changes must be integrated into baselines BEFORE execution proceeds. The procurement team cannot issue accurate RFPs using outdated specifications. Updating baselines ensures the Work Authorization System releases work based on current requirements.
remediation.pmiMindset: Baseline integrity first. Never execute work or authorize procurements against outdated baselines. The change control process concludes with baseline updates, not CCB approval.
remediation.theTrap: Communicating to the team seems proactive, but baselines must reflect reality first. Procurement cannot proceed correctly without updated specifications and budget authority.

questions.scenario: During a weekly status meeting, a key stakeholder asks why their requested change to add emergency backup power generators has not been implemented. The stakeholder submitted the request 6 weeks ago through the formal change control system. The change control board analyzed the request and determined it would increase the budget by $500,000 with no corresponding increase in business value, given the existing UPS infrastructure. The decision was to reject the change, but the stakeholder claims they were never informed of the decision. The project manager's change log shows the rejection was documented 5 weeks ago.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT root cause the project manager should address?
questions.correctAnswer: The change control process lacks a formal communication mechanism to ensure requesters receive timely status notifications
distractors: The stakeholder did not follow up on their change request after submitting it through the proper channel
The change control board should have provided more detailed justification for rejecting the business case
The change log should be shared with all stakeholders at weekly meetings to ensure transparency

answers.text: The change control process lacks a formal communication mechanism to ensure requesters receive timely status notifications
The stakeholder did not follow up on their change request after submitting it through the proper channel
The change control board should have provided more detailed justification for rejecting the business case
The change log should be shared with all stakeholders at weekly meetings to ensure transparency

remediation.coreLogic: Change control requires closed-loop communication. When stakeholders submit changes, they deserve notification of the decision and rationale. Without formal communication, the process fails stakeholder expectations and undermines trust in the change control system.
remediation.pmiMindset: Process integrity requires stakeholder service. A rejected change still requires respectful communication to maintain relationships. Silence is not an acceptable outcome.
remediation.theTrap: Blaming the stakeholder for not following up is victim-blaming. The process owner must ensure notification. Sharing the entire log is inefficient compared to targeted notification.

questions.scenario: A software development project in the execution phase has a performance measurement baseline with 500 planned requirements. The change control board approves a change request to add 50 new requirements based on a regulatory change, with a budget increase of $200,000 and a 4-week schedule extension. The project manager's implementation plan includes: updating the requirements traceability matrix, revising the WBS, adding tasks to the schedule, and issuing work authorization documents. However, the technical lead has already begun coding the new requirements based on an email from the product manager, before the work authorization was issued.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST immediate action for the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Halt the unauthorized work and reinforce that approved changes must await formal work authorization before implementation begins
distractors: Accept the completed work since the change was approved and the requirements are valid
Require the technical lead to document what was completed and update the work authorization retroactively
Discuss with the product manager why they bypassed the change control communication protocols

answers.text: Halt the unauthorized work and reinforce that approved changes must await formal work authorization before implementation begins
Accept the completed work since the change was approved and the requirements are valid
Require the technical lead to document what was completed and update the work authorization retroactively
Discuss with the product manager why they bypassed the change control communication protocols

remediation.coreLogic: The Work Authorization System is critical in predictive projects. Even approved changes cannot be implemented until the WAS formally authorizes the work. Preemptive implementation undermines configuration status accounting and baseline integrity.
remediation.pmiMindset: Process discipline protects the project. Good intentions (valid requirements) don't justify skipping controls. The project manager must enforce the WAS to prevent scope creep and unauthorized work.
remediation.theTrap: Accepting the work because it's correct undermines the process. Retroactive documentation is still after-the-fact authorization. The issue is not the product manager's communication but the technical lead's bypass of WAS.

questions.scenario: An infrastructure project manager has implemented 8 approved changes over the past quarter, including material substitutions, schedule adjustments, and scope modifications. During a project audit, the quality manager discovers that while the cost baseline was updated for all changes, the scope statement and WBS were only updated for 3 of the 8 changes. The project manager's explanation is that cost and schedule were the only affected baselines, and the scope documents didn't need updates because the scope statement doesn't include detailed specifications. The project management plan was never revised to reflect the cumulative impact of these changes.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT corrective action?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the scope statement, WBS, and project management plan to reflect all implemented changes and ensure configuration alignment
distractors: Create a change impact analysis template to ensure all baseline updates are identified for future changes
Document the audit findings as a lesson learned and require baseline verification before closing future changes
Review the 5 inconsistent changes to determine if scope baseline updates are truly necessary

answers.text: Update the scope statement, WBS, and project management plan to reflect all implemented changes and ensure configuration alignment
Create a change impact analysis template to ensure all baseline updates are identified for future changes
Document the audit findings as a lesson learned and require baseline verification before closing future changes
Review the 5 inconsistent changes to determine if scope baseline updates are truly necessary

remediation.coreLogic: Configuration management requires all baselines to remain synchronized. If cost changed, scope documents must reflect what was purchased. If schedule changed, the WBS must show the activities. Inconsistent baselines corrupt Earned Value Management and prevent accurate performance measurement.
remediation.pmiMindset: Baseline integrity is absolute. Partial updates create a false project reality. Documentation must reflect actual execution, or measurement becomes meaningless.
remediation.theTrap: Future process improvements don't fix the current misalignment. The 5 changes cannot remain half-documented; they must be fully reconciled. The scope statement always updates when approved changes affect deliverables.

questions.scenario: A project manager is facilitating a change control board meeting for a defense contract with strict configuration requirements. Three change requests are under review: Request 1 would add a safety feature but delay delivery by 2 months, Request 2 would substitute materials with equivalent specifications at 10% cost savings, and Request 3 would upgrade testing equipment for better quality data at 15% cost increase. The CCB must approve or reject each request. The procurement director verbally states that Request 2 is acceptable and the vendor has already been notified. The project manager has not yet documented the CCB decisions or obtained written approval for any of the requests.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST response to the procurement director?
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledge the verbal indication but require formal written approval before implementing any change, including Request 2
distractors: Allow Request 2 to proceed since the procurement director has authority and the vendor is already engaged
Document Request 2 as conditionally approved pending written confirmation while the other requests await full CCB decisions
Pause vendor notification on Request 2 until all three requests receive written CCB approval to process them together

answers.text: Acknowledge the verbal indication but require formal written approval before implementing any change, including Request 2
Allow Request 2 to proceed since the procurement director has authority and the vendor is already engaged
Document Request 2 as conditionally approved pending written confirmation while the other requests await full CCB decisions
Pause vendor notification on Request 2 until all three requests receive written CCB approval to process them together

remediation.coreLogic: In predictive projects with formal change control, verbal approval is insufficient. All changes require documented CCB decisions before implementation proceeds. Even well-intentioned verbal authorization must be formalized to maintain auditability and prevent misunderstandings.
remediation.pmiMindset: Formality protects the project. Verbal directions become disputed memories. Documentation is the only reliable evidence of change control decisions in regulated environments.
remediation.theTrap: Holding all three requests hostage to one incomplete process is inefficient. The issue is not whether Request 2 proceeds, but whether proper documentation exists before vendor engagement.

questions.scenario: A project manager receives an email from a functional manager requesting that a technical resource be reassigned from the current project to another project starting next week. The email states that the other project has encountered delays and needs additional support. The current project is 70% complete, and this resource is scheduled to complete critical design activities in the next 3 weeks. The functional manager indicates this is a temporary adjustment and does not require formal change control because it's a resource management decision. No change request form has been submitted.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST response from the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Explain that resource reassignment requires a formal change request with impact analysis, as it affects schedule, cost, and risk baselines
distractors: Acknowledge the request and ask for a written confirmation that the resource will return after 3 weeks
Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the functional manager's request should be honored
Analyze the schedule impact and propose an alternative resource who could fill the gap during the reassignment period

answers.text: Explain that resource reassignment requires a formal change request with impact analysis, as it affects schedule, cost, and risk baselines
Acknowledge the request and ask for a written confirmation that the resource will return after 3 weeks
Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the functional manager's request should be honored
Analyze the schedule impact and propose an alternative resource who could fill the gap during the reassignment period

remediation.coreLogic: Any change that affects baselines (schedule, cost, risk) requires formal change control. Resource removal affects all three baselines. The project manager cannot bypass the change control process regardless of who initiates the change or how it's characterized.
remediation.pmiMindset: The process applies to everyone equally. Functional managers do not have override authority for baseline changes. The project manager protects baselines by requiring all changes to enter the formal system.
remediation.theTrap: Finding alternative resources is problem-solving before establishing the process. Escalation is premature without attempting to enforce process. Written confirmation does not replace change control.

questions.scenario: A manufacturing project has 23 change requests in various stages of the change control process. The project manager maintains a change register tracking status: 5 approved (3 implemented, 2 pending), 8 under analysis, 6 rejected, and 4 awaiting CCB review. During the monthly steering committee meeting, the sponsor expresses frustration that they cannot determine the total impact of all approved changes on the project budget and completion date. The project manager presents detailed analysis for each individual change but has not aggregated the approved changes to show the cumulative effect on the baselines.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT improvement to the change status reporting?
questions.correctAnswer: Add cumulative baseline impact analysis showing the total effect of all approved changes on budget and schedule
distractors: Reduce the number of change requests allowed to be in-flight at any time to simplify reporting
Provide the detailed change register to the steering committee instead of a summary presentation
Implement a requirement that all changes be analyzed individually rather than allowing batch reviews

answers.text: Add cumulative baseline impact analysis showing the total effect of all approved changes on budget and schedule
Reduce the number of change requests allowed to be in-flight at any time to simplify reporting
Provide the detailed change register to the steering committee instead of a summary presentation
Implement a requirement that all changes be analyzed individually rather than allowing batch reviews

remediation.coreLogic: Stakeholders need to understand the aggregate impact of change. Individual change analysis answers whether each change is justified, but not how the changes collectively affect the project. Cumulative reporting shows whether the project is still viable after incorporating all approved changes.
remediation.pmiMindset: Stakeholders need the big picture. Reporting should answer the question: What is the new project reality after all changes? The sum of changes often exceeds the sum of individual impacts due to compounding effects.
remediation.theTrap: Reducing in-flight changes limits project agility. The detailed register is too much information for high-level decision-making. Individual analysis is already occurring; the gap is aggregation.

questions.scenario: A project manager receives a change control board decision approving a change request to replace the HVAC system with a more energy-efficient model. The decision memo specifies: budget increase of $85,000, schedule extension of 2 weeks, and requirement for updated commissioning documentation. The project manager implements the change by purchasing the new equipment, revising the schedule baseline, and directing the installation contractor to proceed. Three months later, during project closeout, the closeout auditor notes that the commissioning documentation was never updated to reflect the new system's specifications and testing requirements.
questions.questionText: What was the MOST LIKELY cause of this documentation gap?
questions.correctAnswer: The project manager viewed the change implementation as complete upon equipment installation and failed to verify all specified deliverables
distractors: The CCB approval did not clearly specify documentation as a required implementation component
The installation contractor was responsible for updating commissioning documentation and failed to do so
The change request form did not include a checklist for all affected project documents

answers.text: The project manager viewed the change implementation as complete upon equipment installation and failed to verify all specified deliverables
The CCB approval did not clearly specify documentation as a required implementation component
The installation contractor was responsible for updating commissioning documentation and failed to do so
The change request form did not include a checklist for all affected project documents

remediation.coreLogic: Change implementation includes ALL specified actions, not just physical work. The CCB explicitly required updated documentation. The project manager is responsible for ensuring complete implementation, including documentation updates, before considering the change closed.
remediation.pmiMindset: Implementation is complete only when all specified actions are finished. Documentation is not an afterthought—it is an integral part of project deliverables. The project manager must verify all aspects of change implementation.
remediation.theTrap: The CCB clearly specified documentation requirements. The contractor cannot be responsible for project management documentation. While checklists help, the project manager remains accountable for verifying complete implementation.

questions.scenario: A project manager is preparing performance reports for the monthly review meeting. The Earned Value Management data shows: CPI = 0.89, SPI = 1.12, and the project has completed 45% of the planned work at a cost of $2.2M against a budget of $2.45M. The project manager calculated EAC using three different formulas based on the assumptions of future performance. Last month, the CCB approved a change request that added $300,000 to the budget and extended the schedule by 6 weeks. The performance reports still reflect the original baseline of $5.2M and 18-month duration, showing a cost variance of -$250,000.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST CRITICAL issue with the performance reporting?
questions.correctAnswer: Performance reports must use the updated baseline to show accurate variances, as the original baseline no longer reflects project reality
distractors: The EAC calculations should use only one formula to avoid confusion among stakeholders
The CPI and SPI thresholds for triggering corrective action have not been defined in the reporting template
The cost variance should be calculated as a percentage rather than an absolute dollar amount

answers.text: Performance reports must use the updated baseline to show accurate variances, as the original baseline no longer reflects project reality
The EAC calculations should use only one formula to avoid confusion among stakeholders
The CPI and SPI thresholds for triggering corrective action have not been defined in the reporting template
The cost variance should be calculated as a percentage rather than an absolute dollar amount

remediation.coreLogic: Once a change is approved and baselines are updated, all performance measurement must use the new baseline. Reporting against an obsolete baseline produces meaningless variance data. The $250K variance shown does not exist because the budget increased by $300K.
remediation.pmiMindset: Measure against current baselines. Historical comparison is valuable, but variance must be calculated from the current approved baseline. Reporting that ignores approved changes misleads stakeholders about project health.
remediation.theTrap: EAC formulas and thresholds are secondary to baseline accuracy. The variance calculation method is correct, but the baseline is wrong. The issue is not measurement technique but using the wrong reference point.

questions.scenario: A project manager receives a request from a senior engineer to modify the welding procedure specification to use a different filler metal. The engineer states that the new material has better availability and will reduce welding time by 15%. The project manager asks the engineer to submit a formal change request. The engineer objects, stating that this is a technical decision within their authority and does not need change control board approval. The project manager reviews the project management plan, which specifies that changes to approved technical procedures require CCB approval if they affect quality, cost, or schedule baselines.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST approach for the project manager?
questions.correctAnswer: Require a formal change request with impact analysis on quality, cost, and schedule before CCB review, as technical procedures are part of the approved baseline
distractors: Allow the engineer to proceed with the change since they are the technical expert and the change improves efficiency
Ask the quality manager to evaluate whether the filler metal substitution affects quality standards
Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the engineer has authority to make technical substitutions

answers.text: Require a formal change request with impact analysis on quality, cost, and schedule before CCB review, as technical procedures are part of the approved baseline
Allow the engineer to proceed with the change since they are the technical expert and the change improves efficiency
Ask the quality manager to evaluate whether the filler metal substitution affects quality standards
Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the engineer has authority to make technical substitutions

remediation.coreLogic: Configuration control extends to technical specifications and procedures. Even beneficial changes require formal analysis and approval when they affect baselined requirements. The process exists not to block improvements but to validate that they don't introduce unintended consequences.
remediation.pmiMindset: Process discipline applies to positive changes too. Good ideas still need impact analysis. Technical expertise does not override change control authority. The project manager enforces the process for all baseline changes.
remediation.theTrap: Asking quality management bypasses the change control process. Escalation is unnecessary when the project management plan already specifies the procedure. Allowing the change undermines the entire change control system.

questions.scenario: A project manager has organized change requests into three priority categories: Critical, High, and Medium. The change control board meets weekly and typically reviews 5-8 requests per meeting. Stakeholders have complained that they cannot determine when their submitted changes will be reviewed, as the review order appears arbitrary. The project manager maintains detailed tracking of each request's status but does not publish the queue sequence or estimated review dates. The current backlog is 42 requests, with 12 categorized as Critical and 18 as High priority.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT improvement to change status communication?
questions.correctAnswer: Publish a change request queue showing expected review dates based on priority and CCB meeting capacity
distractors: Increase the frequency of CCB meetings to twice weekly to reduce the backlog
Reject changes that are not categorized as Critical to focus resources on high-priority requests
Require stakeholders to attend CCB meetings to get real-time status on their submitted changes

answers.text: Publish a change request queue showing expected review dates based on priority and CCB meeting capacity
Increase the frequency of CCB meetings to twice weekly to reduce the backlog
Reject changes that are not categorized as Critical to focus resources on high-priority requests
Require stakeholders to attend CCB meetings to get real-time status on their submitted changes

remediation.coreLogic: Change requesters deserve visibility into when their requests will be reviewed. Uncertainty creates frustration and drives stakeholders to bypass the formal process. A published queue with expected dates manages expectations and demonstrates respect for stakeholder submissions.
remediation.pmiMindset: Service to stakeholders includes predictable process transparency. People should not have to guess when their requests will be addressed. The change control process should feel responsive, not opaque.
remediation.theTrap: More meetings don't fix the transparency problem. Rejecting medium-priority changes creates stakeholder resistance. Requiring attendance is impractical for large stakeholder groups and doesn't provide advance notice.

questions.scenario: A project manager has received CCB approval for three change requests: adding a security system ($120K, 4 weeks), upgrading electrical service ($180K, 6 weeks), and expanding parking capacity ($90K, 3 weeks). All three changes require permits from the municipal government. The project manager issues work authorization for the security system immediately and submits the permit application. For the electrical upgrade, the project manager waits until the security system permit is approved before submitting the electrical permit application, stating that this ensures the changes are implemented sequentially and avoids overwhelming the municipal reviewers.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST evaluation of this implementation approach?
questions.correctAnswer: The approach unnecessarily delays implementation; approved changes should proceed in parallel unless dependencies require sequential processing
distractors: The approach is sound because municipal reviewers may reject multiple applications from the same project
The project manager should combine all three changes into a single permit application to streamline the review process
The changes should be implemented in order of lowest cost to highest cost to build momentum and demonstrate success

answers.text: The approach unnecessarily delays implementation; approved changes should proceed in parallel unless dependencies require sequential processing
The approach is sound because municipal reviewers may reject multiple applications from the same project
The project manager should combine all three changes into a single permit application to streamline the review process
The changes should be implemented in order of lowest cost to highest cost to build momentum and demonstrate success

remediation.coreLogic: Once changes are approved, implementation should proceed efficiently unless dependencies require sequencing. Artificial serial processing delays benefits. The three changes are independent; the electrical permit timeline does not depend on the security permit. Parallel processing optimizes schedule.
remediation.pmiMindset: Execute approved changes without delay. Self-imposed constraints waste time and defer value delivery. The project manager removes barriers, not creates them.
remediation.theTrap: Municipal reviewers are accustomed to multiple permit applications from construction projects. Combining into one application may not be possible if the changes affect different systems. Cost is not a valid sequencing criterion without dependency justification.

questions.scenario: During a project execution phase, a team member identifies that the approved material specification for pipe insulation is no longer manufactured. The vendor recommends an equivalent substitute with identical thermal properties. The team member makes the substitution and documents it in the daily work log, noting that the change has no impact on project objectives. Two months later, during a quality audit, the auditor flags the substitution as an unapproved change to the baselined specification. The project manager argues that this was a minor technical adjustment within the team's discretion and did not require formal change control.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST ACCURATE assessment of this situation?
questions.correctAnswer: The substitution was an unapproved configuration change that bypassed change control, regardless of whether impact was minimal
distractors: The team member exercised appropriate judgment by making a technically equivalent substitution that maintained project quality
The daily work log documentation constitutes sufficient record-keeping for minor material substitutions
The auditor is being overly rigid; the project manager should request a waiver for technical substitutions under a specified cost threshold

answers.text: The substitution was an unapproved configuration change that bypassed change control, regardless of whether impact was minimal
The team member exercised appropriate judgment by making a technically equivalent substitution that maintained project quality
The daily work log documentation constitutes sufficient record-keeping for minor material substitutions
The auditor is being overly rigid; the project manager should request a waiver for technical substitutions under a specified cost threshold

remediation.coreLogic: Configuration status accounting requires all changes to baselined items to be processed through change control. Equivalent substitutions still constitute changes to approved specifications. The process exists to document changes, not to prevent them. Team members do not have unilateral authority to modify baselined specifications.
remediation.pmiMindset: No exceptions to change control for baseline items. The process is the process, regardless of how minor the change appears. What if the substitute material later proves incompatible with other components? The audit trail is broken.
remediation.theTrap: Good intentions and technical equivalence do not override process requirements. Daily logs are not change control documentation. The auditor is correctly enforcing configuration management.

questions.scenario: A project manager is analyzing a change request that would reduce the project timeline by 8 weeks through schedule compression. The request proposes adding three technical resources and authorizing overtime for the critical path activities. The cost impact analysis shows a budget increase of $165,000. The change request includes the sponsor's signature indicating support. However, the project manager notices that the request does not include any analysis of how schedule compression affects risk, particularly the risk of rework due to rushed technical work. The project manager has not yet submitted the request to the CCB.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action before submitting the request to the CCB?
questions.correctAnswer: Require a complete impact analysis including risk assessment before the CCB reviews the request
distractors: Submit the request to the CCB with the current analysis and note that risk assessment can be completed if the change is approved
Approve the change conditionally based on the sponsor's support and direct the team to begin resource mobilization
Reject the change request as incomplete and return it to the requester for revision

answers.text: Require a complete impact analysis including risk assessment before the CCB reviews the request
Submit the request to the CCB with the current analysis and note that risk assessment can be completed if the change is approved
Approve the change conditionally based on the sponsor's support and direct the team to begin resource mobilization
Reject the change request as incomplete and return it to the requester for revision

remediation.coreLogic: Change impact analysis must be comprehensive before CCB review. Schedule compression inherently increases risk. The CCB cannot make informed decisions without risk analysis. The project manager ensures complete analysis reaches decision-makers, not minimal or incomplete information.
remediation.pmiMindset: Decision quality depends on analysis completeness. The CCB deserves full information to evaluate trade-offs. Sponsor support does not replace the need for proper analysis. Rushing incomplete analysis to the CCB wastes their time.
remediation.theTrap: Submitting incomplete analysis forces the CCB to request more information, delaying the process. Conditional approval bypasses the CCB's authority. Rejection is premature when the requirement is for more analysis, not a change decision.

questions.scenario: A project manager uses a change log spreadsheet to track change requests. The log includes fields for request ID, description, submitter, date, status, cost impact, and schedule impact. During a stakeholder meeting, a department head asks why their change request was rejected, as they believe the cost impact was underestimated. The project manager refers to the log, which shows a cost impact of $50,000 and a status of Rejected. The department head states that they provided detailed calculations showing the cost would only be $30,000, but those calculations are not attached to the change request. The project manager realizes that supporting documentation for changes is scattered across email, file folders, and the project management system.
questions.questionText: What is the MOST IMPORTANT improvement to the change control tracking system?
questions.correctAnswer: Implement a centralized change repository where all supporting documentation is linked to each change request
distractors: Require all change request submitters to copy the project manager on all change-related correspondence
Add a notes field to the change log to capture key information from supporting documentation
Schedule a meeting with the department head to discuss the specific rejected change and clarify the cost calculation

answers.text: Implement a centralized change repository where all supporting documentation is linked to each change request
Require all change request submitters to copy the project manager on all change-related correspondence
Add a notes field to the change log to capture key information from supporting documentation
Schedule a meeting with the department head to discuss the specific rejected change and clarify the cost calculation

remediation.coreLogic: Change tracking requires complete context, not just summary fields. When supporting documentation is scattered, the CCB cannot review full information, and stakeholders cannot understand decisions. A centralized repository linking all documents to each change ensures transparency and auditability.
remediation.pmiMindset: Information accessibility drives good decisions. The change control system must preserve the complete context for every request. Stakeholders deserve to see that their full analysis was considered, not just a number in a spreadsheet.
remediation.theTrap: Copying the project manager on emails continues the scattered documentation problem. Notes fields cannot capture complete supporting analysis. Individual meetings don't fix the systemic issue.

questions.scenario: A Product Owner for a machine learning project requests that a new data preprocessing algorithm be added immediately, citing competitive pressure. The team is two days into a two-week sprint with capacity fully committed to existing backlog items. The Product Owner argues this is a "critical" change that cannot wait for the next sprint planning. Velocity has been stable for six sprints.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Explain that the change will be added to the product backlog and prioritized by the Product Owner for the next sprint planning, as sprint scope is protected during active iterations
distractors: Call an emergency sprint planning meeting to replan the current sprint and accommodate the new algorithm
Ask the team to work overtime to implement the algorithm while maintaining their current sprint commitments
Immediately add the item to the current sprint backlog and remove the lowest priority item to make room

answers.text: Explain that the change will be added to the product backlog and prioritized by the Product Owner for the next sprint planning, as sprint scope is protected during active iterations
Call an emergency sprint planning meeting to replan the current sprint and accommodate the new algorithm
Ask the team to work overtime to implement the algorithm while maintaining their current sprint commitments
Immediately add the item to the current sprint backlog and remove the lowest priority item to make room

remediation.coreLogic: Agile protects sprint scope once committed. Changes flow through the product backlog and are addressed in future sprint planning. This preserves focus, predictability, and sustainable pace.
remediation.pmiMindset: Servant leadership protects the team from disruption. The Product Owner prioritizes what gets built; the team commits to what they can complete in a timebox. Mid-sprint changes undermine empiricism.
remediation.theTrap: Emergency replanning or scope swapping seems responsive but destabilizes sprint goals, reduces velocity predictability, and violates the timebox contract.

questions.scenario: A Scrum team is preparing for sprint review when a key stakeholder discovers that a requested regulatory compliance change was not included in the completed increment. The Product Owner approved the change three weeks ago and it was added to the product backlog with high priority. The stakeholder is frustrated and questions the transparency of the development process.
