remediation.pmiMindset: If one channel fails, try another. Be proactive, not passive-aggressive (logging the failure later).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** is extremely risky (rework). **Distractor 1** is likely to annoy without getting results.

questions.scenario: The software team needs a test environment to validate their code. The infrastructure team (predictive) says the environment won't be ready for 6 weeks. The software team is blocked *now*.
questions.questionText: What is a creative intervention strategy?
questions.correctAnswer: Investigate checking out a cloud-based temporary environment (virtualization) to unblock the team while waiting for the physical infrastructure.
distractors: Tell the software team to write code without testing it for 6 weeks.
Demand the infrastructure team work weekends to finish in 3 weeks.
Pause the software project for 6 weeks.

answers.text: Investigate checking out a cloud-based temporary environment (virtualization) to unblock the team while waiting for the physical infrastructure.
Tell the software team to write code without testing it for 6 weeks.
Demand the infrastructure team work weekends to finish in 3 weeks.
Pause the software project for 6 weeks.

remediation.coreLogic: A blocker requires a workaround. Modern tech (cloud/virtual) often provides alternatives to physical impediments.
remediation.pmiMindset: Problem Solving. Don't accept the 'No.' Find a 'How.'
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** creates massive technical debt. **Distractor 3** is Project Management failure.

questions.scenario: The Scrum Master is observed assigning tasks to developers during the Daily Standup to ensure everyone stays busy.
questions.questionText: Why is this an impediment to agile performance?
questions.correctAnswer: It violates the principle of self-organization and prevents the team from taking ownership of their work.
distractors: It makes the standup take longer than 15 minutes.
It relieves the burden on the team, which is actually helpful.
It confuses the role of the Product Owner.

answers.text: It violates the principle of self-organization and prevents the team from taking ownership of their work.
It makes the standup take longer than 15 minutes.
It relieves the burden on the team, which is actually helpful.
It confuses the role of the Product Owner.

remediation.coreLogic: The SM is a Servant Leader, not a Command-and-Control manager. Assigning tasks destroys the team's ability to self-manage and creates a bottleneck.
remediation.pmiMindset: Empower the team. Trust them to pull work.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 2** sounds nice but cripples the team's growth (learned helplessness).

questions.scenario: The Change Control Board (CCB) meets only once a month. The project is generating 5-6 necessary change requests per week, leading to a massive backlog and work stoppages while waiting for approval.
questions.questionText: What should the Project Manager propose?
questions.correctAnswer: Propose a tiered governance model where low-impact changes can be approved by the PM/Sponsor, while only high-impact changes go to the monthly CCB.
distractors: Ask the team to implement changes without approval and document them later.
Stop submitting change requests and handle everything as 'maintenance.'
Request the CCB meets every single day.

answers.text: Propose a tiered governance model where low-impact changes can be approved by the PM/Sponsor, while only high-impact changes go to the monthly CCB.
Ask the team to implement changes without approval and document them later.
Stop submitting change requests and handle everything as 'maintenance.'
Request the CCB meets every single day.

remediation.coreLogic: The governance process itself is the impediment (too slow). The solution is to tailor the governance (tiers/delegation) to match the project's velocity.
remediation.pmiMindset: Tailor the process to the project. Governance should enable work, not block it.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** is likely unrealistic for executives. **Distractor 1** is a compliance violation.

questions.scenario: The team's Kanban board is cluttered. There are 50 items in "In Progress" for a team of 5 people. Cycle time is increasing.
questions.questionText: What intervention should the PM/Agile Coach apply?
questions.correctAnswer: Work with the team to establish and enforce WIP (Work In Progress) Limits to force finishing before starting.
distractors: Add more columns to the board to spread the cards out.
Hire more people to work on the 50 items.
Remove the "In Progress" column and just have To Do and Done.

answers.text: Work with the team to establish and enforce WIP (Work In Progress) Limits to force finishing before starting.
Add more columns to the board to spread the cards out.
Hire more people to work on the 50 items.
Remove the "In Progress" column and just have To Do and Done.

remediation.coreLogic: High WIP = Context Switching = Slow Delivery. The specific agile tool for this is WIP Limits. "Stop Starting, Start Finishing."
remediation.pmiMindset: Process improvement. Visualize the flow and limit WIP to improve throughput/cycle time.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 2** (Adding people) to a chaotic process usually makes it slower (Brooks' Law).

questions.scenario: A Functional Manager keeps pulling a critical resource from your project to work on operational "fires." This has happened 3 times this month, causing schedule slippage.
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** way to resolve this?
questions.correctAnswer: Meet with the Functional Manager to negotiate a resource agreement (e.g., dedicated hours) or agree on a formal backup plan for when fires occur.
distractors: Complain to the resource that they need to learn to say no.
Hiding the resource in a conference room so they can't be found.
Immediately escalate to the CEO to punish the Functional Manager.

answers.text: Meet with the Functional Manager to negotiate a resource agreement (e.g., dedicated hours) or agree on a formal backup plan for when fires occur.
Complain to the resource that they need to learn to say no.
Hiding the resource in a conference room so they can't be found.
Immediately escalate to the CEO to punish the Functional Manager.

remediation.coreLogic: This is a resource negotiation issue. The Functional Manager has a valid need (fires), but so do you. Collaborative negotiation (Win-Win) is needed to find coverage that works for both.
remediation.pmiMindset: Engage with the person who has the authority (Functional Manager). Don't blame the resource (D1).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** is a "nuclear" escalation that destroys relationships.

questions.scenario: You discover that a junior engineer is adding detailed ornamentation to a housing project that was not in the specs, thinking it will "delight the customer." This is consuming time and materials.
questions.questionText: What action must be taken?
questions.correctAnswer: Stop the unauthorized work immediately (Gold Plating), explain the issue to the engineer, and inspect the work to ensure it meets requirements.
distractors: Allow the work to continue since it adds value and customer satisfaction.
submit a change request to retroactively approve the ornamentation.
Charge the engineer for the wasted materials.

answers.text: Stop the unauthorized work immediately (Gold Plating), explain the issue to the engineer, and inspect the work to ensure it meets requirements.
Allow the work to continue since it adds value and customer satisfaction.
submit a change request to retroactively approve the ornamentation.
Charge the engineer for the wasted materials.

remediation.coreLogic: Gold Plating is a waste and a scope violation. It must be stopped. Value is defined by the customer/requirements, not the engineer's opinion.
remediation.pmiMindset: Deliver what was promised. No more, no less.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** sounds "customer centric" but is actually "project failure centric" (budget/schedule overrun).

questions.scenario: During a Sprint Review, stakeholders seem disengaged and don't ask questions. They simple nod and say "looks good."
questions.questionText: Why is this an impediment?
questions.correctAnswer: Lack of active feedback creates the risk of the "Illusion of Agreement," where the team builds the wrong product that will be rejected later.
distractors: It hurts the team's feelings and lowers morale.
It makes the meeting end too early.
It prevents the Scrum Master from calculating velocity.

answers.text: Lack of active feedback creates the risk of the "Illusion of Agreement," where the team builds the wrong product that will be rejected later.
It hurts the team's feelings and lowers morale.
It makes the meeting end too early.
It prevents the Scrum Master from calculating velocity.

remediation.coreLogic: Agile relies on feedback loops. comprehensive silence is a danger signal (Zombie Stakeholders). It implies checking a box, not validating value.
remediation.pmiMindset: Engagement is crucial. Silence != Success.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** matters, but the *business* risk (building the wrong thing) is the primary concern.

questions.scenario: An audit reveals that the project team has been skipping the required data privacy steps to save time. This is a severe compliance breach.
questions.questionText: What is the project manager's obligation?
questions.correctAnswer: Immediately halt the affected processes, log the compliance issue, and initiate a root cause analysis and remediation plan.
distractors: Note the issue and ask the team to try better next month.
Cover it up to avoid fines for the organization.
Ask the legal department to waive the requirement.

answers.text: Immediately halt the affected processes, log the compliance issue, and initiate a root cause analysis and remediation plan.
Note the issue and ask the team to try better next month.
Cover it up to avoid fines for the organization.
Ask the legal department to waive the requirement.

remediation.coreLogic: Compliance is mandatory. "Skipping steps" indicates a process failure. You must Stop, Fix, and Comply.
remediation.pmiMindset: Ethics and Responsibility. Never hide violations (D2). Never ignore them (D1).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 2** violates the PMI Code of Ethics.

questions.scenario: A key architect, who was identified as a 'critical resource risk,' suddenly resigns to join a competitor. The risk response plan called for 'job shadowing,' but this was never implemented due to time constraints.
questions.questionText: What is the **FIRST** action the PM must take?
questions.correctAnswer: Log the resignation in the Issue Log, assess the impact on the schedule, and immediately escalate the need for a replacement.
distractors: Update the risk register to show that the mitigation strategy failed.
Ask the architect to stay for 2 more months.
Implement the job shadowing plan now during the architect's notice period.

answers.text: Log the resignation in the Issue Log, assess the impact on the schedule, and immediately escalate the need for a replacement.
Update the risk register to show that the mitigation strategy failed.
Ask the architect to stay for 2 more months.
Implement the job shadowing plan now during the architect's notice period.

remediation.coreLogic: The risk has occurred (Issue). The planned response wasn't done. The new reality requires immediate Issue Management (Log -> Analyze -> Act). Attempting the failed mitigation (Shadowing) might be part of the solution, but logging and assessing impact comes first to understand the gap.
remediation.pmiMindset: Manage reality. If you missed the mitigation, you are in issue management mode. Assess the damage first.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** is good, but might not be possible (2 weeks notice vs complex job?). **Distractor 1** is admin.

questions.scenario: The team reports that the codebase has become "spaghetti code," making every new feature take twice as long to build.
questions.questionText: How should this impediment be handled?
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledge this as Technical Debt and work with the Product Owner to allocate capacity in the next Sprint to refactor the code.
distractors: Tell the team to just work harder to overcome the complexity.
Create a separate "Refactoring Project" run by a different team.
Ignore the issue as it doesn't deliver direct customer value.

answers.text: Acknowledge this as Technical Debt and work with the Product Owner to allocate capacity in the next Sprint to refactor the code.
Tell the team to just work harder to overcome the complexity.
Create a separate "Refactoring Project" run by a different team.
Ignore the issue as it doesn't deliver direct customer value.

remediation.coreLogic: Technical Debt is a massive impediment to speed (Velocity). It must be paid down. The mechanism is to treat refactoring as work (PBI) and prioritize it.
remediation.pmiMindset: Sustainable agility requires high quality. Ignoring debt freezes progress.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** focuses only on short-term features, leading to long-term failure.

questions.scenario: Your project has a hardware team (Waterfall) and a software team (Agile). The hardware team is frustrated because the software team "won't commit to a fixed date" for the firmware. The software team is frustrated that hardware "won't allow iteration."
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** conflict resolution step?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a joint workshop to map the dependencies and agree on "Interface Milestones" where the two methodologies connect.
distractors: Force the software team to adopt waterfall to match the hardware team.
Force the hardware team to adopt agile sprints.
Keep the teams separated and act as the sole messenger between them.

answers.text: Facilitate a joint workshop to map the dependencies and agree on "Interface Milestones" where the two methodologies connect.
Force the software team to adopt waterfall to match the hardware team.
Force the hardware team to adopt agile sprints.
Keep the teams separated and act as the sole messenger between them.

remediation.coreLogic: This is a "Methodology Clash." Neither side is wrong. They need a "Bridge." Interface Milestones allow Waterfall to have its dates and Agile to have its flexibility in between.
remediation.pmiMindset: Hybrid requires integration points. Facilitate agreement on *how* to interact (Working Agreement).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1 & 2** assume one way is right. **Distractor 3** creates a bottleneck (PM).

questions.scenario: A project relies on imported steel. The exchange rate fluctuates wildly, causing the cost to spike by 20% today. This exceeds the cost baseline but is within the management reserve.
questions.questionText: What is the process to handle this?
questions.correctAnswer: This is an Issue; submit a change request to use the Management Reserve to cover the unforeseen cost spike.
distractors: Use the Contingency Reserve since this is a project risk.
Cut scope immediately to save the money.
Ask the vendor for a discount.

answers.text: This is an Issue; submit a change request to use the Management Reserve to cover the unforeseen cost spike.
Use the Contingency Reserve since this is a project risk.
Cut scope immediately to save the money.
Ask the vendor for a discount.

remediation.coreLogic: Contingency Reserve is for *Identified* risks. Management Reserve is for *Unidentified* risks (Unknown Unknowns). Since the scenario implies this was not a specific risk with a plan, Management Reserve is the source, requiring a Change Request.
remediation.pmiMindset: Follow the money rules. Management Reserve = Change Request.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** is for *known* risks.

questions.scenario: A new agile team is in the "Storming" phase. Team members are arguing about how long the standup should be and who should update the board.
questions.questionText: How should the Scrum Master intervene?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a team session to create a "Team Charter" or "Working Agreement" where the team decides their own ground rules.
distractors: Decide the rules for them to stop the arguing.
Report the behavior to the functional managers.
Cancel the standups until they can behave professionally.

answers.text: Facilitate a team session to create a "Team Charter" or "Working Agreement" where the team decides their own ground rules.
Decide the rules for them to stop the arguing.
Report the behavior to the functional managers.
Cancel the standups until they can behave professionally.

remediation.coreLogic: Storming is normal. The exit from Storming is Norming. Norming requires agreed-upon rules (Charter). The team must create them to own them.
remediation.pmiMindset: Facilitate self-organization. Don't dictate (D1).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** fixes the immediate noise but prevents the team from maturing.

questions.scenario: Half the team is in New York, and half is in London. The London team complains that they are always excluded from ad-hoc decisions made by the NY team in the hallway.
questions.questionText: What is the **MOST** effective intervention?
questions.correctAnswer: Establish a "Remote-First" communication policy: All decisions must be documented in the chat/project tool, even if people are co-located.
distractors: Move everyone to London.
Tell the London team to wake up earlier to be on the calls.
Assign a "London Ambassador" in NY to take notes.

answers.text: Establish a "Remote-First" communication policy: All decisions must be documented in the chat/project tool, even if people are co-located.
Move everyone to London.
Tell the London team to wake up earlier to be on the calls.
Assign a "London Ambassador" in NY to take notes.

remediation.coreLogic: The impediment is "Proximity Bias." The intervention is to level the playing field. If one person is remote, the whole meeting/decision process should be treated as remote.
remediation.pmiMindset: Inclusion. Policies that protect the distributed team members.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** creates a bottleneck. **Distractor 2** puts the burden on the victim.

questions.scenario: A vendor claims a deliverable is complete. The project team claims it is incomplete. The contract is ambiguous on this specific point.
questions.questionText: What is the **preferred** resolution method?
questions.correctAnswer: Negotiate a solution with the vendor (e.g., a small change order or compromise) to avoid litigation and keep the project moving.
distractors: Immediately stop payment and sue the vendor.
Accept the incomplete deliverable to avoid conflict.
Require the vendor to finish it for free or be blacklisted.

answers.text: Negotiate a solution with the vendor (e.g., a small change order or compromise) to avoid litigation and keep the project moving.
Immediately stop payment and sue the vendor.
Accept the incomplete deliverable to avoid conflict.
Require the vendor to finish it for free or be blacklisted.

remediation.coreLogic: When contracts are ambiguous, Negotiation (ADR) is preferred over Litigation (which kills the project schedule/budget). Collaboration/Compromise is needed.
remediation.pmiMindset: Litigation is a failure. Negotiate first.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** is the "Nuclear" option. **Distractor 2** is "Smoothing" (Lose-Win).

questions.scenario: The Product Owner is attending the Daily Standup and constantly interrupting developers to ask for detailed status updates and ETA.
questions.questionText: What should the Scrum Master do?
questions.correctAnswer: Talk to the Product Owner privately and explain that the Standup is for the team's synchronization, not for status reporting.
distractors: Publicly silence the Product Owner during the meeting.
Cancel the standup since it is not productive.
Change the meeting format to a status report to satisfy the Product Owner.

answers.text: Talk to the Product Owner privately and explain that the Standup is for the team's synchronization, not for status reporting.
Publicly silence the Product Owner during the meeting.
Cancel the standup since it is not productive.
Change the meeting format to a status report to satisfy the Product Owner.

remediation.coreLogic: This is an Anti-Pattern. The SM acts as a shield/coach. Correcting the PO validates the team's self-organization. Doing it privately is respectful (Conflict Management).
remediation.pmiMindset: Protect the team's process. Coach stakeholders.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** humiliates the PO (relationship damage). **Distractor 3** capitulates.

questions.scenario: The Scope Baseline has been changed 15 times in 2 months via formal Change Requests. The team is confused about what the current requirements are.
questions.questionText: What should the Project Manager do?
questions.correctAnswer: Pause to re-baseline the project documents and hold a "Re-Kickoff" meeting to align everyone on the current state (v15).
distractors: Freeze the scope and reject all future changes.
Tell the team to check the change log if they are confused.
Ask the Sponsor to stop approving changes.

answers.text: Pause to re-baseline the project documents and hold a "Re-Kickoff" meeting to align everyone on the current state (v15).
Freeze the scope and reject all future changes.
Tell the team to check the change log if they are confused.
Ask the Sponsor to stop approving changes.

remediation.coreLogic: Excessive change creates "Configuration Management" chaos. The reassessment needed is a cleanup/realignment (Re-baseline/Re-kickoff).
remediation.pmiMindset: Confusion is a risk. Clarity is the PM's job. When the dust settles, ensure everyone looks at the same map.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** is not realistic if business needs change. **Distractor 2** is lazy management.

questions.scenario: During integration, it is discovered that the Agile software component uses a data format incompatible with the Predictive legacy system. This risk was missed during planning.
questions.questionText: What is the action?
questions.correctAnswer: Log the issue, analyze the cost/time to build an adapter (workaround), and submit a change request.
distractors: Update the Risk Register.
Blame the Agile team for not checking the legacy specs.
Force the legacy team to change their database.

answers.text: Log the issue, analyze the cost/time to build an adapter (workaround), and submit a change request.
Update the Risk Register.
Blame the Agile team for not checking the legacy specs.
Force the legacy team to change their database.

remediation.coreLogic: Missed risk = Issue. You need a technical solution (Adapter) and a management solution (Change Request for time/money).
remediation.pmiMindset: Focus on the solution (Adapter) and the governance (CR).
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** is too late. **Distractor 2** is non-productive.

questions.scenario: In the Retrospective, the team enters a "blame cycle," pointing fingers at the tester for missing bugs. The atmosphere is hostile.
questions.questionText: How should the facilitator intervene?
questions.correctAnswer: Intervene to enforce the "Prime Directive" (Retrospectives are blameless) and shift the focus to "System/Process" failures rather than person failures.
distractors: Agree that the tester needs more training.
End the meeting to cool down.
Remove the tester from the room.

answers.text: Intervene to enforce the "Prime Directive" (Retrospectives are blameless) and shift the focus to "System/Process" failures rather than person failures.
Agree that the tester needs more training.
End the meeting to cool down.
Remove the tester from the room.

remediation.coreLogic: Psychological Safety is the foundation of Agile. Blaming destroys it. The facilitator must pivot the conversation: "What in our process allowed the bug to escape?" not "Why did YOU miss it?"
remediation.pmiMindset: Failures are system failures. Protect the team's safety.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** validates the blame.

questions.scenario: A stakeholder demands to see the prototype immediately. It is only 80% done and looks "ugly" (unfinished UI), though the logic works.
questions.questionText: What is the risk of showing it now, and what should the PM do?
questions.correctAnswer: Risk: The stakeholder may lose confidence due to the rough appearance. Action: Set expectations clearly ("This is a wireframe, ignore the colors") before showing it.
distractors: Refuse to show it until it is 100% perfect.
Show it without comment and hope they understand.
Spend 2 weeks polishing the UI before showing it (delaying feedback).

answers.text: Risk: The stakeholder may lose confidence due to the rough appearance. Action: Set expectations clearly ("This is a wireframe, ignore the colors") before showing it.
Refuse to show it until it is 100% perfect.
Show it without comment and hope they understand.
Spend 2 weeks polishing the UI before showing it (delaying feedback).

remediation.coreLogic: Managing expectations is the intervention. Hiding it (D1) builds mistrust. Showing it without context (D2) risks "The demo effect" (they hate the color and ignore the logic).
remediation.pmiMindset: Transparency + Context. "It's a draft."
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 3** is Gold Plating/Delay.

questions.scenario: The team consistently fails to finish User Stories because "Testing takes too long at the end of the sprint."
questions.questionText: What should be reassessed?
questions.correctAnswer: Reassess the "Definition of Done." It might be too ambitious for the sprint length, or the team needs TDD/Automation to shift testing left.
distractors: Make the sprint longer.
Remove testing from the Definition of Done.
Hire a manager to test for them.

answers.text: Reassess the "Definition of Done." It might be too ambitious for the sprint length, or the team needs TDD/Automation to shift testing left.
Make the sprint longer.
Remove testing from the Definition of Done.
Hire a manager to test for them.

remediation.coreLogic: Consistently failing DoD means the process is broken. You need to Shift Left (Test earlier) or automate. reassessing the workflow is key.
remediation.pmiMindset: Build quality in. Detect problems early.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 2** kills quality. **Distractor 1** hides inefficiency.

questions.scenario: The PMO requires a "Green/Yellow/Red" status report. The Agile team refuses, saying "We don't use traffic lights, we use velocity."
questions.questionText: What is the PM's role?
questions.correctAnswer: Translation. The PM must map the Agile metrics (Burnup/Velocity) to the PMO's language (RAG status) to satisfy governance without disrupting the team.
distractors: Force the team to use Traffic Lights.
Tell the PMO they are outdated.
Ignore the PMO request.

answers.text: Translation. The PM must map the Agile metrics (Burnup/Velocity) to the PMO's language (RAG status) to satisfy governance without disrupting the team.
Force the team to use Traffic Lights.
Tell the PMO they are outdated.
Ignore the PMO request.

remediation.coreLogic: The PM is the bilingual translator in Hybrid. You translate "Velocity Trend" into "Schedule Status (Green/Red)."
remediation.pmiMindset: Protect the team from admin, but satisfy governance. Bridge the gap.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 2** is career suicide.

questions.scenario: A concrete pour was identified as a risk ("Rain could ruin the finish"). It didn't rain, but the concrete cracked due to extreme heat (Unidentified Risk).
questions.questionText: What is the action?
questions.correctAnswer: Log the issue, execute the workaround (remove/pour again), and submit a change request for the cost (Management Reserve).
distractors: Use the Contingency Reserve.
Blame the contractor.
Leave the crack since it's cosmetic.

answers.text: Log the issue, execute the workaround (remove/pour again), and submit a change request for the cost (Management Reserve).
Use the Contingency Reserve.
Blame the contractor.
Leave the crack since it's cosmetic.

remediation.coreLogic: Unidentified risk = Management Reserve. It is an Issue now. Quality cannot be compromised (D3).
remediation.pmiMindset: Fix it. Follow the change process for the funding.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** is for *identified* risks (rain). This was heat.

questions.scenario: The Design team works one sprint ahead of the Dev team. The Dev team complains that by the time they code the designs, the designs are outdated or missing details, and the designers are busy with the "next" sprint.
questions.questionText: What is the intervention?
questions.correctAnswer: Integrate the designers into the Cross-Functional Team so they design and code in the *same* sprint (Collaborative design).
distractors: Increase the lead time to 2 sprints.
Document the designs more thoroughly.
Tell the developers to just guess.

answers.text: Integrate the designers into the Cross-Functional Team so they design and code in the *same* sprint (Collaborative design).
Increase the lead time to 2 sprints.
Document the designs more thoroughly.
Tell the developers to just guess.

remediation.coreLogic: "Silos" (Design vs Dev) create handoff waste. Agile promotes Cross-Functional Teams. Moving from "waterfall in sprints" (staggered) to "swarming" (same sprint) removes the impediment.
remediation.pmiMindset: Break down silos. One Team.
remediation.theTrap: **Distractor 1** increases the lag and the problem.

questions.scenario: A project manager is leading a large-scale infrastructure project. During a site walkthrough, the site engineer mentions that the soil composition in Sector 4 looks slightly different than the geological survey indicated, but they haven't started digging there yet. The project is currently on schedule, but special foundation equipment would be needed if the soil is unstable.
questions.questionText: What is the **FIRST** action the project manager should take?
questions.correctAnswer: Document the potential soil discrepancy in the risk register as a new risk.
distractors: Halting work in Sector 4 immediately to perform a new geological survey.
Allocate contingency reserves to rent the special foundation equipment just in case.
Instruct the site engineer to proceed with excavation to verify the soil conditions.

answers.text: Document the potential soil discrepancy in the risk register as a new risk.
Halting work in Sector 4 immediately to perform a new geological survey.
Allocate contingency reserves to rent the special foundation equipment just in case.
Instruct the site engineer to proceed with excavation to verify the soil conditions.

remediation.coreLogic: The potential discrepancy is an uncertainty (a risk), not an issue yet. The first step in the risk process is to **Identify** and document it in the Risk Register so it can be analyzed. Taking action (surveys, renting equipment) before documenting and analyzing is premature.
remediation.pmiMindset: Identify -> Analyze -> Plan Response. Do not act without a plan.
remediation.theTrap: 'Halting work' feels safe but is an overreaction to an unverified observation. 'Allocating reserves' is jumping to a solution (Accept/Mitigate) without analysis.

questions.scenario: An agile team is developing a fintech application. For the past three sprints, the risk burndown chart has remained flat, despite the team completing user stories. The product owner is concerned that technical debt is accumulating, but the developers argue they are meeting velocity targets.
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** way for the project lead to address this situation?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a risk audit during the next retrospective to validate if risk mitigation tasks are being executed.
distractors: Increase the sprint velocity target to force the team to clear more work, including risks.
Reset the risk burndown baseline to match the current velocity trends.
Assign the product owner to prioritize risk reduction stories at the top of the backlog.

answers.text: Facilitate a risk audit during the next retrospective to validate if risk mitigation tasks are being executed.
Increase the sprint velocity target to force the team to clear more work, including risks.
Reset the risk burndown baseline to match the current velocity trends.
Assign the product owner to prioritize risk reduction stories at the top of the backlog.

remediation.coreLogic: A flat risk burndown indicates that risk exposure is not decreasing. This often means risk responses are not being done. A **risk audit** (or focused retrospective discussion) is needed to understand *why* the process is failing before changing priorities.
remediation.pmiMindset: Monitor metrics; if they deviate, investigate the cause (Audit) before acting.
remediation.theTrap: 'Prioritize risk stories' assumes the PO isn't doing their job; the problem might be technical or process-related. 'Increase velocity' is coercive and dangerous.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project has a hardware component (managed predictively) and a software interface (managed agilely). A high-probability risk regarding the hardware vendor's API stability has just been triggered. The pre-planned response was to deploy a middleware simulation tool, but the agile team claims they can simply "code around it" in the next sprint.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager proceed?
questions.correctAnswer: Execute the pre-planned response (deployment of the simulation tool) while evaluating the agile team's proposal as a secondary response.
distractors: Allow the agile team to code around the issue and cancel the simulation tool deployment to save costs.
Halt the hardware workstream until the agile team demonstrates their solution works.
Escalate the disagreement to the project sponsor for a final decision on the technical approach.

answers.text: Execute the pre-planned response (deployment of the simulation tool) while evaluating the agile team's proposal as a secondary response.
Allow the agile team to code around the issue and cancel the simulation tool deployment to save costs.
Halt the hardware workstream until the agile team demonstrates their solution works.
Escalate the disagreement to the project sponsor for a final decision on the technical approach.

remediation.coreLogic: When a risk is triggered, the **planned response** should be executed unless there is a compelling reason not to. The agile team's idea is unproven. The specific "Correct" action ensures the agreed-upon mitigation happens immediately, while still being open to optimization.
remediation.pmiMindset: Follow the plan when a trigger occurs. Do not abandon the plan for an unverified idea in the heat of the moment.
remediation.theTrap: 'Allow key team to code around' is appealing to Agile flexibility, but risky if it fails (the risk is already triggered).

questions.scenario: A project manager is presenting risk analysis results to the steering committee. The Monte Carlo simulation shows an 80% confidence level that the project will cost $1.2M, but the current budget is capped at $1.0M (which has only a 40% confidence level). The sponsor asks, "How much contingency do we need to be safe?"
questions.questionText: What is the **MOST ACCURATE** response based on the simulation data?
questions.correctAnswer: Request the difference between the P80 value ($1.2M) and the current budget ($1.0M) as contingency.
distractors: Explain that the P50 value is the industry standard for specific contingency requests.
Request the difference between the pessimistic (P100) estimate and the current budget to ensure 100% safety.
Advise that the project scope must be reduced by 20% to align with the $1.0M budget cap.

answers.text: Request the difference between the P80 value ($1.2M) and the current budget ($1.0M) as contingency.
Explain that the P50 value is the industry standard for specific contingency requests.
Request the difference between the pessimistic (P100) estimate and the current budget to ensure 100% safety.
Advise that the project scope must be reduced by 20% to align with the $1.0M budget cap.

remediation.coreLogic: "Safe" usually implies a high confidence level like P80 or P90 (as per the guide). Contingency calculation using Monte Carlo is typically P(Target) - P(Current/Mean). Here, bridging the gap to P80 ($1.2M) requires adding $200k.
remediation.pmiMindset: Use data (P80) to drive reserve discussions. Honesty about confidence levels is key.
remediation.theTrap: 'P100' or 'Pessimistic' is usually too expensive/unrealistic (gold plating reserves). 'Reducing scope' is a valid option but doesn't answer the specific question about *contingency amount*.

questions.scenario: During a collaborative risk workshop, an agile team identifies that the new facial recognition library they plan to use might not support the required framerate. The team is arguing about the probability of this failure: some say "very likely," others say "rare."
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** action to resolve this uncertainty?
questions.correctAnswer: Schedule a "Spike" story in the next sprint to test the library's performance and determine the actual risk.
distractors: Use Planning Poker to vote on the risk probability and take the average.
Assign the Scrum Master to research the library vendor's documentation and provide a ruling.
Avoid the risk by selecting a different library that the team is more familiar with.

answers.text: Schedule a "Spike" story in the next sprint to test the library's performance and determine the actual risk.
Use Planning Poker to vote on the risk probability and take the average.
Assign the Scrum Master to research the library vendor's documentation and provide a ruling.
Avoid the risk by selecting a different library that the team is more familiar with.

remediation.coreLogic: In Agile, when technical uncertainty exists, the best analysis method is empirical: run an experiment (a **Spike**). Guessing (even via voting) is inferior to testing.
remediation.pmiMindset: Reduce uncertainty through experimentation/Spikes in adaptive environments.
remediation.theTrap: 'Planning Poker' is for sizing effort, not determining risk probability (though similar techniques can be used, a Spike is *better* logic). 'Avoid' is premature before validation.

questions.scenario: A project has a critical dependency: the hardware team (Predictive) must deliver prototypes before the software team (Agile) can finalize the drivers. The hardware delivery is at risk of a 2-week delay. This delay falls within the project's overall buffer but exceeds the software team's sprint boundary.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager report this status?
questions.correctAnswer: Report the delay to the software lead immediately to discuss backlog reprioritization, while noting it is currently within the project's critical path buffer.
distractors: Report the project as "Red" to all stakeholders because a cross-team dependency is missed.
Wait to report the delay until it consumes the project buffer and impacts the critical path.
Direct the hardware team to crash the schedule to meet the original date, avoiding the communication need.

answers.text: Report the delay to the software lead immediately to discuss backlog reprioritization, while noting it is currently within the project's critical path buffer.
Report the project as "Red" to all stakeholders because a cross-team dependency is missed.
Wait to report the delay until it consumes the project buffer and impacts the critical path.
Direct the hardware team to crash the schedule to meet the original date, avoiding the communication need.

remediation.coreLogic: Even if the *project* buffer absorbs the delay, the *Agile team's* plan is impacted immediately (sprint boundary). Transparency is key. You must communicate to the affected party (Software) so they can adapt.
remediation.pmiMindset: Transparency and active stakeholder engagement. Don't hide "Yellow" risks just because they aren't "Red" yet.
remediation.theTrap: 'Wait to report' allows the Agile team to waste time. 'Report Red' is alarmist if the project buffer handles it.

questions.scenario: A project manager is drafting the Risk Management Plan for a government compliance project. The sponsor indicates that the organization has "zero tolerance" for any data privacy breaches but is willing to accept moderate schedule variance to ensure security.
questions.questionText: How should this guidance primarily affect the Risk Management Plan?
questions.correctAnswer: Set the risk threshold for "Privacy" impact to the lowest possible level and define "Avoid" as the mandatory strategy for any privacy risks.
distractors: allocate the largest portion of the contingency reserve to Schedule risks since they are more likely to be accepted.
Remove "Schedule" from the Risk Breakdown Structure to focus entirely on Privacy.
Assign the Project Sponsor as the owner of all schedule-related risks.

answers.text: Set the risk threshold for "Privacy" impact to the lowest possible level and define "Avoid" as the mandatory strategy for any privacy risks.
allocate the largest portion of the contingency reserve to Schedule risks since they are more likely to be accepted.
Remove "Schedule" from the Risk Breakdown Structure to focus entirely on Privacy.
Assign the Project Sponsor as the owner of all schedule-related risks.

remediation.coreLogic: The Risk Management Plan defines **Thresholds** and **Appetite**. "Zero tolerance" means the threshold for action is zero/very low, and the strategy for threats exceeding that threshold must be robust (Avoid/Mitigate heavily).
remediation.pmiMindset: Translate stakeholder appetite into specific plan parameters (Thresholds).
remediation.theTrap: 'Allocate reserves to Schedule' misinterprets the guidance; you need reserves for Privacy (to preventing breach), or maybe you don't need schedule reserves because variance is accepted? It's ambiguous. Setting the *threshold* is the direct planning action.

questions.scenario: An agile team identifies a risk that the third-party payment gateway might deprecate an API they are using. They decide to build an abstraction layer to insulate their code. This work is estimated at 13 story points.
questions.questionText: Where should this risk response be primarily recorded and tracked?
questions.correctAnswer: As a story or task in the Product Backlog/Risk Backlog, prioritized against other value-delivery work.
distractors: In the Impediment Log, assigned to the Scrum Master to resolve.
In a separate offline Risk Register spreadsheet managed by the product owner.
In the Retrospective notes as an improvement item for the next release.

answers.text: As a story or task in the Product Backlog/Risk Backlog, prioritized against other value-delivery work.
In the Impediment Log, assigned to the Scrum Master to resolve.
In a separate offline Risk Register spreadsheet managed by the product owner.
In the Retrospective notes as an improvement item for the next release.

remediation.coreLogic: In Agile, risk responses that require team work (like building an abstraction layer) must be part of the **Backlog**. They compete for capacity like any other feature.
remediation.pmiMindset: If it's work, it goes in the Backlog. Don't hide work in offline registers.
remediation.theTrap: 'Impediment Log' is for blockers *stopping* current work, not future risks requiring dev effort. 'Separate spreadsheet' breaks visibility (the "Hidden Factory" anti-pattern).

questions.scenario: During a brainstorming session for a hybrid construction-software project, the software team leads identify "Supply Chain Delay" as a risk. The construction lead interrupts, saying, "That's not a risk; that's just how the industry works right now. Delays are guaranteed."
questions.questionText: How should the project manager handle this assertion?
questions.correctAnswer: Log "Supply Chain Delay" as a Fact/Assumption or Issue in the assumption log/issue log, and ask the team to identify risks related to *managing* that delay.
distractors: Agree and remove it from the discussion since risks must be uncertain.
Keep it in the Risk Register but mark the Probability as 100%.
Record it as a "High" impact risk and assign the construction lead to Mitigate it.

answers.text: Log "Supply Chain Delay" as a Fact/Assumption or Issue in the assumption log/issue log, and ask the team to identify risks related to *managing* that delay.
Agree and remove it from the discussion since risks must be uncertain.
Keep it in the Risk Register but mark the Probability as 100%.
Record it as a "High" impact risk and assign the construction lead to Mitigate it.

remediation.coreLogic: Risks are *uncertain*. If something is "guaranteed," it is an **Issue**, a **Fact**, or a **Constraint**. The PM should move it to the appropriate log (Issue/Assumption) and then ask "What risks arise *because* of this fact?"
remediation.pmiMindset: Distinguish between Risk (Uncertainty) and Issue/Fact (Certainty). Probability 100% = Issue.
remediation.theTrap: 'Mark probability 100%' is technically an issue. Better to manage it as an issue/constraint than clutter the risk register.

questions.scenario: A project risk regarding "Vendor Insolvency" was identified with a "Transfer" strategy (purchasing a surety bond). Six months into the project, the vendor declares bankruptcy. The project manager contacts the surety company to claim the bond.
questions.questionText: What action must the Project Manager take **simultaneously**?
questions.correctAnswer: Log the event in the Issue Log and initiate the fallback plan (e.g., engaging the pre-qualified backup vendor).
distractors: Update the Risk Register to set the probability of Vendor Insolvency to 0%.
Perform a Monte Carlo analysis to determine the cost impact of the bankruptcy.
Request the Sponsor to release Management Reserves to cover the cost of a new vendor.

answers.text: Log the event in the Issue Log and initiate the fallback plan (e.g., engaging the pre-qualified backup vendor).
Update the Risk Register to set the probability of Vendor Insolvency to 0%.
Perform a Monte Carlo analysis to determine the cost impact of the bankruptcy.
Request the Sponsor to release Management Reserves to cover the cost of a new vendor.

remediation.coreLogic: When a risk occurs, it becomes an **Issue**. You must log it. Also, "claiming the bond" recovers money (Strategy: Transfer), but you still need a vendor to *do the work*. Initiation of the fallback/backup plan is the execution step.
remediation.pmiMindset: Risk -> Occurs -> Issue Log + Response Execution.
remediation.theTrap: 'Management Reserves' is wrong because this was an *identified* risk (known-unknown), so Contingency Reserves (or the Bond payout) should cover it.

questions.scenario: A key stakeholder is anxious about the project's progress and sends daily emails asking about specific risks. This is distracting the team. The Scrum Master notes that the stakeholder has access to the project dashboard, but rarely looks at it.
questions.questionText: What is the **MOST EFFECTIVE** solution?
questions.correctAnswer: Review the Information Radiator (dashboard) with the stakeholder to ensure it displays risk status clearly, and establish a regular cadence for risk review discussions.
distractors: Restrict the stakeholder's access to the team to prevent distraction.
Assign the product owner to reply to the daily emails with a manual risk report.
Create a detailed weekly risk report document specifically for this stakeholder.

answers.text: Review the Information Radiator (dashboard) with the stakeholder to ensure it displays risk status clearly, and establish a regular cadence for risk review discussions.
Restrict the stakeholder's access to the team to prevent distraction.
Assign the product owner to reply to the daily emails with a manual risk report.
Create a detailed weekly risk report document specifically for this stakeholder.

remediation.coreLogic: Agile promotes **Information Radiators**. If a stakeholder isn't using them, the solution is coaching/alignment, not creating manual overhead (reports) or blocking them. The dashboard might need to be improved to show *Risk* specifically if that's their worry.
remediation.pmiMindset: Pull communication (Radiators) > Push communication. Stakeholder Engagement > Exclusion.
remediation.theTrap: 'Weekly report' creates waste (extra docs). 'Restrict access' harms engagement.

questions.scenario: In a hybrid project, the "Architecture" team is running behind. This increases the risk that the "Integration" phase (scheduled to start in 2 weeks) will fail. The Risk Register lists "Schedule Slippage" as a risk with a trigger of "Architecture not complete by Oct 1st." Today is Oct 2nd, and Architecture is 90% done.
questions.questionText: What is the **Project Manager's** immediate obligation?
questions.correctAnswer: Declare the risk triggered, update the risk status to "Realized/Issue," and implement the planned contingency actions.
distractors: Wait another week since 90% is close enough to completion to avoid panic.
Create a new risk for "Integration Failure" and Assess its probability.
Use Management Reserve to hire more architects to finish the last 10%.

answers.text: Declare the risk triggered, update the risk status to "Realized/Issue," and implement the planned contingency actions.
Wait another week since 90% is close enough to completion to avoid panic.
Create a new risk for "Integration Failure" and Assess its probability.
Use Management Reserve to hire more architects to finish the last 10%.

remediation.coreLogic: The trigger (Oct 1st deadline) has passed. Stick to the discipline of the plan. If the trigger is hit, the risk is realized (or the contingency is activated). Subjectively "waiting" defeats the purpose of defining triggers.
remediation.pmiMindset: Discipline in execution. Trigger = Action.
remediation.theTrap: 'Wait another week' is the "Optimism Bias."

questions.scenario: During the execution of a risk response (Strategy: Mitigate), the team discovers that the mitigation steps (adding an extra cooling fan) create a noise level that exceeds regulatory limits. This noise issue was not previously identified.
questions.questionText: What is this new issue called, and how should it be handled?
questions.correctAnswer: It is a **Secondary Risk**. It should be documented in the Risk Register and analyzed to determine a response.
distractors: It is a **Residual Risk**. It should be accepted since the primary risk is resolved.
It is a **Workaround**. The team should document it in the issue log.
It is a **Scope Creep**. The PM should reject the fan installation to maintain requirements.

answers.text: It is a **Secondary Risk**. It should be documented in the Risk Register and analyzed to determine a response.
It is a **Residual Risk**. It should be accepted since the primary risk is resolved.
It is a **Workaround**. The team should document it in the issue log.
It is a **Scope Creep**. The PM should reject the fan installation to maintain requirements.

remediation.coreLogic: A **Secondary Risk** is a risk that arises as a direct result of implementing a risk response. It must be managed like any other risk (ID -> Analyze -> Plan).
remediation.pmiMindset: Definitions: Residual (leftover) vs. Secondary (newly created).
remediation.theTrap: 'Residual' is wrong (that's the heat remaining, not the new noise). 'Scope Creep' is wrong; this is a side effect of necessary work.

questions.scenario: A daily standup reveals that three developers are blocked because the test server is down. This server instability has happened twice this week. The Scrum Master removes the impediment for the day.
questions.questionText: What should the Project Lead/Agile Coach do next regarding **risk management**?
questions.correctAnswer: Identify this pattern as a systemic risk ("Server Instability") and facilitate a Root Cause Analysis to prevent recurrence.
distractors: Continue to treat it as an impediment each day and trust the Scrum Master to fix it.
Accept the risk as part of the project environment and add a buffer to the sprint.
Escalate to the IT department that they are failing the project.

answers.text: Identify this pattern as a systemic risk ("Server Instability") and facilitate a Root Cause Analysis to prevent recurrence.
Continue to treat it as an impediment each day and trust the Scrum Master to fix it.
Accept the risk as part of the project environment and add a buffer to the sprint.
Escalate to the IT department that they are failing the project.

remediation.coreLogic: When an issue recurs ("twice this week"), it is no longer just an impediment; it is a **Risk** or a systemic problem. The role of the PM/Coach is to move from reactive (fixing it today) to proactive (Root Cause Analysis/Risk Mgmt).
remediation.pmiMindset: Pattern matching. Recurrence = Systemic Risk -> Solve Root Cause.
remediation.theTrap: 'Continue to treat as impediment' is reactive inefficient firefighting.

questions.scenario: A project uses a predictive schedule for regulatory approvals (Phase 1) and Scrum for development (Phase 2). The regulatory approval process has a high variance: it could take 1 month or 6 months. Agile development cannot start until approval is granted.
questions.questionText: Which quantitative analysis tool is **MOST** suitable for estimating the project start date?
questions.correctAnswer: Three-Point Estimating (PERT) or Monte Carlo Simulation to model the probability distribution of the approval duration.
distractors: Velocity Analysis based on the regulator's past performance.
Decision Tree Analysis to choose between different regulators.
Pareto Charting to identify the causes of delays.

answers.text: Three-Point Estimating (PERT) or Monte Carlo Simulation to model the probability distribution of the approval duration.
Velocity Analysis based on the regulator's past performance.
Decision Tree Analysis to choose between different regulators.
Pareto Charting to identify the causes of delays.

remediation.coreLogic: When duration is uncertain (1 to 6 months), **Probability Distributions** (Beta/Triangular) via PERT or Monte Carlo provide the confidence intervals needed.
remediation.pmiMindset: Tool selection. Uncertainty in duration = Simulation/PERT.
remediation.theTrap: 'Velocity' applies to *team work*, not external regulatory waits. 'Decision Tree' is for choosing *paths*, not estimating *duration*.

questions.scenario: A project manager creates a "Watch List" for low-priority risks. During a monthly review, a risk on the Watch List ("Material costs increase by 5%") is found to have changed. The impact has increased significantly due to new tariffs, pushing its Risk Score above the mitigation threshold defined in the plan.
questions.questionText: What is the **FIRST** step the PM should take?
questions.correctAnswer: Move the risk from the Watch List to the active Risk Register and develop a response plan (e.g., Mitigate).
distractors: Immediately execute the contingency reserve to cover the cost difference.
Accept the risk because it was originally low priority.
Escalate the risk to the sponsor since tariffs are external.

answers.text: Move the risk from the Watch List to the active Risk Register and develop a response plan (e.g., Mitigate).
Immediately execute the contingency reserve to cover the cost difference.
Accept the risk because it was originally low priority.
Escalate the risk to the sponsor since tariffs are external.

remediation.coreLogic: Risk management is dynamic. If a Watch List item grows (Monitor), it must be promoted to the active list and treated according to the Risk Management Plan's thresholds (which now require Mitigation).
remediation.pmiMindset: Monitoring includes reprioritization. Watch list -> Active list.
remediation.theTrap: 'Execute reserve' skips the planning step (can we Mitigate/Avoid first?).

questions.scenario: During Sprint Planning, the team identifies that a complex user story depends on an external API that has no documentation. The team suggests estimating it at 20 story points to be safe.
questions.questionText: How should the Agile Project Manager coach the team to handle this risk?
questions.correctAnswer: Coach the team to create a "Spike" (timeboxed investigation) to research the API first, rather than committing to a large, uncertain estimate.
distractors: Accept the 20-point estimate and add it to the Sprint Backlog.
Create a Risk Register entry and assign the Product Owner to mitigate it.
Remove the story from the sprint until the external vendor provides documentation.

answers.text: Coach the team to create a "Spike" (timeboxed investigation) to research the API first, rather than committing to a large, uncertain estimate.
Accept the 20-point estimate and add it to the Sprint Backlog.
Create a Risk Register entry and assign the Product Owner to mitigate it.
Remove the story from the sprint until the external vendor provides documentation.

remediation.coreLogic: Large estimates due to "unknowns" signal High Risk. In Agile, we attack risk early with knowledge. A **Spike** buys information. Committing to 20 points of "guessing" is poor planning.
remediation.pmiMindset: Agile: Failing fast / Learning first. High uncertainty -> Spike.
remediation.theTrap: 'Accept 20 points' bloats the sprint with risk. 'Remove story' delays value without a plan to solve it.

questions.scenario: A project has a potential $50,000 opportunity (early completion bonus) if the team can finish Phase 1 two weeks early. However, achieving this requires paying $10,000 for expedited shipping of materials.
questions.questionText: Which quantitative analysis supports the decision to pay for shipping?
questions.correctAnswer: Expected Monetary Value (EMV). If the probability of finishing early with the materials is >20%, the investment may be worth it (Cost basis analysis).
distractors: Sensitivity Analysis to see if shipping costs impact the bottom line.
Root Cause Analysis of the schedule delay.
Qualitative Risk Assessment of the shipping vendor.

answers.text: Expected Monetary Value (EMV). If the probability of finishing early with the materials is >20%, the investment may be worth it (Cost basis analysis).
Sensitivity Analysis to see if shipping costs impact the bottom line.
Root Cause Analysis of the schedule delay.
Qualitative Risk Assessment of the shipping vendor.

remediation.coreLogic: This is a "Enhance/Exploit" decision. You need numeric comparison (Cost vs. Benefit). EMV allows you to compare the sure cost (-$10k) against the probability-weighted benefit (+$50k * P).
remediation.pmiMindset: Business value decisions (ROI) drive Risk Response.
remediation.theTrap: 'Sensitivity' shows *impact* but doesn't help with the Go/No-Go decision as directly as EMV.

questions.scenario: A project manager is using a Probability and Impact Matrix. Risk A has a probability of 0.9 and an impact of $1,000 (Impact Score 0.1). Risk B has a probability of 0.1 and an impact of $1,000,000 (Impact Score 0.9). The Matrix puts Risk A in "Low" (Green) and Risk B in "Medium" (Yellow).
questions.questionText: Why might the project manager decide to prioritize Risk B despite its low probability?
questions.correctAnswer: Because the impact ($1M) might exceed the organization's risk capacity or threaten project survival, overriding the standard PxI score.
distractors: Because low probability risks are harder to detect and therefore more dangerous.
Because the Probability-Impact Matrix is flawed and should not be used for financial risks.
Because Risk A is a "High Probability" risks which means it should be treated as an Issue, not a risk.

answers.text: Because the impact ($1M) might exceed the organization's risk capacity or threaten project survival, overriding the standard PxI score.
Because low probability risks are harder to detect and therefore more dangerous.
Because the Probability-Impact Matrix is flawed and should not be used for financial risks.
Because Risk A is a "High Probability" risks which means it should be treated as an Issue, not a risk.

remediation.coreLogic: The PxI Matrix is a guide, but "Catastrophic Impact" (even with low probability) often gets special handling (e.g., insurance/Avoidance). If an impact kills the company, EMV implies it's low, but Utility Theory (Survival) says it's High.
remediation.pmiMindset: Context (Risk Capacity/Appetite) > Raw Math.
remediation.theTrap: 'Risk A is an Issue' -> 90% is high, but not 100% (Issue). 'Matrix is flawed' -> It's limited, not flawed.

questions.scenario: An agile team is starting a project with high regulatory compliance requirements. The organization usually requires a detailed Risk Register approved by the PMO. The team feels this is "bureaucratic waste."
questions.questionText: How should the Agile Project Lead approach the Risk Management Plan?
questions.correctAnswer: Adapt the process: Agree to maintain the required compliance data (the "what") but use Agile artifacts (e.g., Risk tags in the Backlog, Information Radiators) to capture it (the "how"), ensuring PMO needs are met without slowing the team.
distractors: Direct the team to fill out the standard PMO spreadsheet every Friday to ensure compliance.
Ask the PMO to waive the requirement because Agile projects do not use Risk Registers.
Secretly maintain the register yourself so the team doesn't have to worry about it.

answers.text: Adapt the process: Agree to maintain the required compliance data (the "what") but use Agile artifacts (e.g., Risk tags in the Backlog, Information Radiators) to capture it (the "how"), ensuring PMO needs are met without slowing the team.
Direct the team to fill out the standard PMO spreadsheet every Friday to ensure compliance.
Ask the PMO to waive the requirement because Agile projects do not use Risk Registers.
Secretly maintain the register yourself so the team doesn't have to worry about it.

remediation.coreLogic: Compliance is a mandatory requirement (Constraint). You cannot ignore it. However, you should tailor the *implementation* to fit the Agile context (Adaptation).
remediation.pmiMindset: Hybrid/Tailoring. Satisfy governance + Maintain agility.
remediation.theTrap: 'Secretly maintain' creates a single point of failure and hides risk from the team. 'Waive' is unrealistic for compliance.

questions.scenario: A project manager notices that the "Number of Open Risks" has stayed constant at 15 for the last three months, even though the project is progressing through phases.
questions.questionText: What does this metric **MOST LIKELY** indicate about the risk management process?
questions.correctAnswer: The team may be failing to close obsolete risks or identify new ones effectively (stale data).
distractors: The risk management process is stable and effective.
The project is low-risk because the number isn't increasing.
The team is effectively using the "Avoid" strategy for all new risks.

answers.text: The team may be failing to close obsolete risks or identify new ones effectively (stale data).
The risk management process is stable and effective.
The project is low-risk because the number isn't increasing.
The team is effectively using the "Avoid" strategy for all new risks.

remediation.coreLogic: Risks should evolve. Some close, new ones open. A static number suggests the register is not being reviewed or updated (Zombie risks).
remediation.pmiMindset: Risk Management is dynamic/active. Stagnation = Failure.
remediation.theTrap: 'Stable' sounds good, but in risk, 'Static' usually means 'Ignored'.

questions.scenario:
You are analyzing a risk involving the potential failure of a cooling pump.
- Risk A (Pump Failure): 50% Prob, $100k Impact.
- If Pump Fails, there is a 20% chance the backup system also fails (Secondary Risk B), causing $500k additional damage.
questions.questionText: What is the total Expected Monetary Value (EMV) of this risk scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: $60,000. (Risk A: $50k) + (Risk B: 0.5 * 0.2 * $500k = $10k). Wait. Risk B only happens if Risk A happens.

answers.text: $60,000. (Risk A: $50k) + (Risk B: 0.5 * 0.2 * $500k = $10k). Wait. Risk B only happens if Risk A happens.

remediation.pmiMindset: Decision Tree / EVM logic. Multiply probabilities along the path.
remediation.theTrap: Calculating Risk B as independent (0.2 * 500k = 100k) + Risk A (50k) = 150k. But Risk B is *conditional* on A.

questions.scenario: A project manager gathers experts to identify risks for a nuclear plant upgrade. The experts are located globally and there is a concern that dominant personalities might sway the group's opinion.
questions.questionText: Which identification technique is **BEST** suited for this situation?
questions.correctAnswer: Delphi Technique.
distractors: Brainstorming.
Nominal Group Technique.
Root Cause Analysis.

answers.text: Delphi Technique.
Brainstorming.
Nominal Group Technique.
Root Cause Analysis.

remediation.coreLogic: The **Delphi Technique** is designed specifically for anonymous, consensus-building expert input, preventing "Bandwagon effect" or dominant personalities from biasing the result. It also handles distributed experts well (originally via mail/survey).
remediation.pmiMindset: Choose the tool based on constraints (Distributed + Bias concern = Delphi).
remediation.theTrap: 'Brainstorming' is vulnerable to groupthink. 'Nominal Group' is good for voting but requires meeting (usually).

questions.scenario: A major risk (flood damage) has occurred. The response plan (Active Acceptance - Contingency Reserve) was executed efficiently. The project is back on track, but the Contingency Reserve is now depleted by 50%.
questions.questionText: What is the **most critical** communication action the PM must take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the Risk Report to reflect the reduced reserve and the exposure of remaining risks, and communicate this to the Sponsor.
distractors: Request immediate replenishment of the reserve from the client.
Hide the reserve depletion until the next phase gate to avoid alarming stakeholders.
Archive the risk as "Closed" and remove it from future status reports.

answers.text: Update the Risk Report to reflect the reduced reserve and the exposure of remaining risks, and communicate this to the Sponsor.
Request immediate replenishment of the reserve from the client.
Hide the reserve depletion until the next phase gate to avoid alarming stakeholders.
Archive the risk as "Closed" and remove it from future status reports.

remediation.coreLogic: When reserves are burned, the project's *protection* against future risks drops. This changes the project's risk profile. The Sponsor needs to know that the "insurance" is half-gone properly.
remediation.pmiMindset: Transparency. Reserve analysis is part of Monitoring.
remediation.theTrap: 'Immediate replenishment' might not be needed if remaining risks are low (Check analysis first). 'Hide' is unethical.

questions.scenario: An Agile team identifies a risk: "Knowledge Silo - Only one developer knows the legacy code." If they get sick, velocity stops.
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** Opportunity-focused or Mitigation response?
questions.correctAnswer: Pair Programming or Mob Programming on legacy tasks (Mitigate/Enhance knowledge sharing).
distractors: Send the expert to a training course (Transfer).
Create detailed documentation (Mitigate - but often lower value/stale).
Hire a backup consultant to stand by (Active Accept).

answers.text: Pair Programming or Mob Programming on legacy tasks (Mitigate/Enhance knowledge sharing).
Send the expert to a training course (Transfer).
Create detailed documentation (Mitigate - but often lower value/stale).
Hire a backup consultant to stand by (Active Accept).

remediation.coreLogic: **Pair Programming** is a classic Agile strategy to break silos (Mitigate key person risk). It spreads knowledge immediately.
remediation.pmiMindset: Agile prefers "Genchi Genbutsu" / Real-time knowledge sharing over documentation or hiring.
remediation.theTrap: 'Documentation' is the traditional fix, but often fails in Agile (becomes outdated). Pairing is the active culture fix.

questions.scenario: A project manager uses a Tornado Diagram to analyze risk sensitivity. The diagram shows "Steel Price Fluctuation" at the top with a wide bar ($200k range) and "Permit Delay" at the bottom with a narrow bar ($10k range).
questions.questionText: What is the **primary interpretation** of this chart?
questions.correctAnswer: Steel Price Fluctuation has the highest potential impact on the project outcome and requires the most detailed monitoring/response.
distractors: Steel Price Fluctuation has the highest probability of occurring.
Permit Delay is a negligible risk and should be removed from the register.
The project budget will definitely increase by $200k.

answers.text: Steel Price Fluctuation has the highest potential impact on the project outcome and requires the most detailed monitoring/response.
Steel Price Fluctuation has the highest probability of occurring.
Permit Delay is a negligible risk and should be removed from the register.
The project budget will definitely increase by $200k.

remediation.coreLogic: A **Tornado Diagram** (Sensitivity Analysis) sorts risks by the *magnitude* of their impact (variance). The top bar is the most sensitive variable (Greatest Impact). It does not show probability, only range of outcome.
remediation.pmiMindset: Focus effort on the "Vital Few" variables that drive variance (the top of the tornado).
remediation.theTrap: 'Highest Probability' is a common misconception; Tornado charts assume the risk happens and show the *spread* of impact.

questions.scenario: An agile team is about to start a high-stakes release. The Project Lead asks the team to "Imagine we have failed 3 months from now. The release was a disaster. What went wrong?"
questions.questionText: What is this technique called and what is its purpose?
questions.correctAnswer: Pre-mortem; it helps overcome cognitive bias (Optimism) to identify hidden threats before they happen.
distractors: Post-mortem; it helps document lessons learned for future projects.
Root Cause Analysis; it finds the single source of failure.
Retrospective; it reviews the team's process improvement.

answers.text: Pre-mortem; it helps overcome cognitive bias (Optimism) to identify hidden threats before they happen.
Post-mortem; it helps document lessons learned for future projects.
Root Cause Analysis; it finds the single source of failure.
Retrospective; it reviews the team's process improvement.

remediation.coreLogic: A **Pre-mortem** is a specific psychological safety tool used *before* an event (hence "Pre") to safely visualize failure. This triggers the brain to find glossed-over risks.
remediation.pmiMindset: Proactive identification using psychological techniques.
remediation.theTrap: 'Post-mortem' and 'Retrospective' happen *after* the fact. This scenario is prospective ("Imagine we have failed").

questions.scenario:
Reviewing a dashboard:
- Predictive Stream (Hardware): "Green" (On track).
- Agile Stream (Software): "Red" (Blocked by hardware specs).
The Project Manager realizes the hardware team didn't update their status to reflect that the specs were incomplete, masking the risk to the software team.
questions.questionText: What is the **root cause** of this monitoring failure?
questions.correctAnswer: Lack of integrated risk monitoring; the hardware team viewed "success" as completing tasks, ignoring the "definition of done" required for the dependent software team.
distractors: The Agile team is being too demanding regarding specifications.
The dashboard software is broken and not updating in real-time.
The Risk Register was missing a "Scope Creep" risk.

answers.text: Lack of integrated risk monitoring; the hardware team viewed "success" as completing tasks, ignoring the "definition of done" required for the dependent software team.
The Agile team is being too demanding regarding specifications.
The dashboard software is broken and not updating in real-time.
The Risk Register was missing a "Scope Creep" risk.

remediation.coreLogic: In Hybrid, the "hand-offs" are the highest risk points. Monitoring failed because the Predictive team measured "Task Done" instead of "Value Available to Next Stream." Integrated monitoring must track dependencies.
remediation.pmiMindset: Systems Thinking. Optimization of the part (Hardware Green) destroyed the whole (Software Red).
remediation.theTrap: Blaming the Agile team or the software tool ignores the *process/governance* failure of siloed status reporting.

questions.scenario: A critical machine breaks down. This specific failure was *not* in the Risk Register. To keep the project moving, the site foreman rents a manual replacement machine for 3 days.
questions.questionText: What is the rent of the manual machine classified as?
questions.correctAnswer: A **Workaround** (response to an unidentified issue/risk).
distractors: A Contingency Plan (planned response).
A Fallback Plan (response if contingency fails).
A Risk Mitigation (measures taken before risk occurs).

answers.text: A **Workaround** (response to an unidentified issue/risk).
A Contingency Plan (planned response).
A Fallback Plan (response if contingency fails).
A Risk Mitigation (measures taken before risk occurs).

remediation.coreLogic: Since the risk was *not* identified, there could be no *planned* response (Contingency/Fallback). An unplanned response to an issue is a **Workaround**.
remediation.pmiMindset: Definitions: Workaround = Unplanned response to an issue.
remediation.theTrap: 'Mitigation' is proactive. This is reactive.

questions.scenario: An agile team is building a feature based on a new, unproven algorithm. They commit to a "Fail Fast" approach. In Sprint 2, the algorithm fails to scale to the necessary data volume.
questions.questionText: What is the **BEST** next step for the Product Owner and Team?
questions.correctAnswer: Pivot immediately: Accept the failure as "Risk Avoidance" (we avoided building the full feature on bad tech) and prioritize the alternative solution in the Backlog.
distractors: Extend the sprint by 2 weeks to force the algorithm to work.
Mark the sprint as a failure and reprimand the team for poor technical choices.
Move the failed story to the next sprint and keep trying the same approach.

answers.text: Pivot immediately: Accept the failure as "Risk Avoidance" (we avoided building the full feature on bad tech) and prioritize the alternative solution in the Backlog.
Extend the sprint by 2 weeks to force the algorithm to work.
Mark the sprint as a failure and reprimand the team for poor technical choices.
Move the failed story to the next sprint and keep trying the same approach.

remediation.coreLogic: "Fail Fast" is a risk strategy. Finding out early (Sprint 2) is a success, not a failure. It saves money. The correct execution is to **Process the Learning** (Pivot) rather than falling into the "Sunk Cost Fallacy" (Distractors 1 & 3).
remediation.pmiMindset: Agile treats failure as learning/risk reduction. Sunk Cost Fallacy is the enemy.
remediation.theTrap: 'Mark sprint as failure' punishes the team for doing exactly what they should (finding limits early).

questions.scenario: A program has three sub-projects: Construction (Predictive, Cost-focused), Software (Agile, Speed-focused), and Marketing (Hybrid). Each PM is using different scales for "High Risk" (one uses $, one uses hours, one uses 1-5 score).
questions.questionText: What must the Program Manager do to ensure effective risk governance?
questions.correctAnswer: Standardize the Risk Scales (or create a translation matrix) in the Program Risk Management Plan so risks can be aggregated and compared across the program.
distractors: Dictate that all projects must use Agile Risk Burndown charts.
Allow each project to maximize its own autonomy; no programm-level view is needed.
Convert all risks to "Hours Delay" since time is the only common factor.

answers.text: Standardize the Risk Scales (or create a translation matrix) in the Program Risk Management Plan so risks can be aggregated and compared across the program.
Dictate that all projects must use Agile Risk Burndown charts.
Allow each project to maximize its own autonomy; no programm-level view is needed.
Convert all risks to "Hours Delay" since time is the only common factor.

remediation.coreLogic: To manage risk at a governance/program level, you need a "Common Currency." One team's "High" (5 days slip) might be another team's "Low." Standardization enables meaningful aggregation.
remediation.pmiMindset: Governance requires normalization of data for decision making.
remediation.theTrap: 'Convert to Hours' might miss Cost risks (Marketing budget). 'autonomy' prevents program oversight.

questions.scenario: A company wants to bid on a massive international infrastructure project but lacks the local regulatory expertise, which is a "High Impact" theat. They decide to form a Joint Venture with a local firm.
questions.questionText: Which Risk Response Strategy does this represent?
questions.correctAnswer: **Start/Share**. Wait. For a *Threat*, it is **Sharing**? No.
distractors: Transfer (Used for threats, usually involving insurance or liability shifts).
Mitigate (Used for threats to reduce probability).
Enhance (Used to increase probability alone, not with a partner).

answers.text: **Start/Share**. Wait. For a *Threat*, it is **Sharing**? No.
Transfer (Used for threats, usually involving insurance or liability shifts).
Mitigate (Used for threats to reduce probability).
Enhance (Used to increase probability alone, not with a partner).

remediation.coreLogic: Forming a partnership/Joint Venture is the textbook definition of the **Share** strategy for Opportunities. You voluntarily give up some equity/benefit to a partner to ensure you can capture the opportunity at all.
remediation.pmiMindset: Risk pairs: Third-party involvement for Opportunity = Share. Third-party for Threat = Transfer.
remediation.theTrap: 'Transfer' is for threats (negative). 'Mitigate' reduces the bad; Sharing confirms the good.

questions.scenario: The Product Backlog has 50 items. Item A (Value: $10k, Risk: Low) is at the top. Item B (Value: $10k, Risk: Very High - if it fails, the architecture needs a redo) is at the bottom.
questions.questionText: What logic should the Agile Project Manager use to suggest reordering?
questions.correctAnswer: Move Item B to the top ("Risk-Adjusted Prioritization"). Tackling high-risk/high-dependency items early reduces overall project risk exposure (failing fast).
distractors: Keep Item A at the top to secure the "Quick Win" and build morale.
Split Item B into smaller parts and scatter them throughout the backlog to dilute the risk.
Remove Item B until the architecture is proven stable by other items.

answers.text: Move Item B to the top ("Risk-Adjusted Prioritization"). Tackling high-risk/high-dependency items early reduces overall project risk exposure (failing fast).
Keep Item A at the top to secure the "Quick Win" and build morale.
Split Item B into smaller parts and scatter them throughout the backlog to dilute the risk.
Remove Item B until the architecture is proven stable by other items.

remediation.coreLogic: In Agile, we prioritize by Value *and* Risk. High Risk items should be done **early** (Architecture Spikes, etc.). Leaving a "Architectural Redo" risk for the end of the project is waterfall thinking and dangerous.
remediation.pmiMindset: Front-load Risk. Risk Reduction = Value Organization.
