Schedule all project meetings at the same time and force the resource to delegate their attendance.
Request a second resource from the functional manager so each team has its own dedicated person.

remediation.coreLogic: PMs must protect shared resources from overload and context switching through optimized communication norms.
remediation.pmiMindset: Protect the team's time by optimizing the communication system rather than just adding more head count.
remediation.theTrap: Just picking a meeting leads to information silos and missed alignment across the hybrid project.

questions.scenario: The Project Manager wants to increase autonomy. Currently, the team needs approval for any technical decision taking more than four hours.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST way for the Project Manager to empower the team?
questions.correctAnswer: Increase "Decision Rights" by allowing any technical decision that doesn't impact project triple constraints.
distractors: Tell the team that they can now take eight hours to make a decision before needing approval.
Delegate all technical decisions to the most senior member and have them approve everyone else's work.
Remove all approval requirements and tell the team to "do what they think is best."

answers.text: Increase "Decision Rights" by allowing any technical decision that doesn't impact project triple constraints.
Tell the team that they can now take eight hours to make a decision before needing approval.
Delegate all technical decisions to the most senior member and have them approve everyone else's work.
Remove all approval requirements and tell the team to "do what they think is best."

remediation.coreLogic: Empowerment involves control over how to work. Motivators like autonomy should be increased within safe guardrails.
remediation.pmiMindset: Give the team clear guardrails (the triple constraints) and then let them drive within those boundaries.
remediation.theTrap: Removing all rules is a recipe for scope and budget chaos rather than healthy empowerment.

questions.scenario: The team discovers an API they were planning to use is deprecated and will shut down in two weeks.
questions.questionText: How should the Project Manager (Scrum Master) solve this problem?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate an immediate triage session with the team and Product Owner to re-prioritize and address the risk.
distractors: Tell the team to keep working on current stories and deal with the shutdown when it actually happens.
Cancel the sprint and spend the next two weeks researching alternative APIs.
Instruct the team to work overtime to finish all stories using the deprecated API before it shuts down.

answers.text: Facilitate an immediate triage session with the team and Product Owner to re-prioritize and address the risk.
Tell the team to keep working on current stories and deal with the shutdown when it actually happens.
Cancel the sprint and spend the next two weeks researching alternative APIs.
Instruct the team to work overtime to finish all stories using the deprecated API before it shuts down.

remediation.coreLogic: Remove or escalate impediments to restore flow. When a risk occurs, it is an issue requiring an immediate impact assessment.
remediation.pmiMindset: Agile PMs adapt the plan in real-time when major impediments are discovered. Collaboration with the PO is essential.
remediation.theTrap: Working overtime doesn't solve the long-term technical debt and is an unsustainable practice.

questions.scenario: Team members are spending 10% of their week filling out forms for a complex Work Authorization System. They complain it is "Bureaucracy."
questions.questionText: What should the Project Manager do to establish clearer and more efficient roles?
questions.correctAnswer: Review the Work Authorization process and streamline it to focus only on high-risk or high-cost tasks.
distractors: Tell the team the forms are a mandatory part of compliance and they must continue to fill them out.
Eliminate the Work Authorization System entirely to increase the team's velocity and morale.
Hire a "Project Administrator" to fill out all the forms for the team so they can focus on technical work.

answers.text: Review the Work Authorization process and streamline it to focus only on high-risk or high-cost tasks.
Tell the team the forms are a mandatory part of compliance and they must continue to fill them out.
Eliminate the Work Authorization System entirely to increase the team's velocity and morale.
Hire a "Project Administrator" to fill out all the forms for the team so they can focus on technical work.

remediation.coreLogic: Run the system so work keeps flowing. Streamlining is a continuous improvement move for organizational processes.
remediation.pmiMindset: Servant leaders remove waste (non-value-added work) from the team's process to improve overall efficiency.
remediation.theTrap: Hiring an admin adds cost without fixing the underlying inefficient process that creates the waste.

questions.scenario: A project manager is leading a multi-million dollar infrastructure project in a residential area. During the execution phase, a local community group that was not previously identified starts a social media campaign to halt the project, citing environmental concerns and disruption. The project manager needs to address this immediately to prevent reputational damage and potential legal delays.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action the project manager should take?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the stakeholder register and perform a salience model analysis to determine the group's power, legitimacy, and urgency.
distractors: Issue a public statement on social media addressing the environmental concerns to neutralize the opposition.
Request the project sponsor to use their political influence to negotiate with the community leaders.
Review the communications management plan to identify why this group was missed during the planning phase.

answers.text: Update the stakeholder register and perform a salience model analysis to determine the group's power, legitimacy, and urgency.
Issue a public statement on social media addressing the environmental concerns to neutralize the opposition.
Request the project sponsor to use their political influence to negotiate with the community leaders.
Review the communications management plan to identify why this group was missed during the planning phase.

remediation.coreLogic: When a new stakeholder is identified, the absolute first step in the PMI mindset is to document them in the Stakeholder Register and analyze their impact. The Salience Model is particularly useful here as it assesses legitimacy and urgency, which are high for community groups.
remediation.pmiMindset: Analysis always precedes action. Before communicating or escalating, the PM must understand the stakeholder's profile.
remediation.theTrap: Issuing a public statement is a reactive "execution" step that might happen later, but without analysis, the message may be misaligned or inflammatory.

questions.scenario: During a sprint review, a high-power stakeholder who rarely attends sessions expresses frustration that a specific feature they expected is not in the current increment. The Product Owner explains that the feature was deprioritized two sprints ago due to technical constraints. The stakeholder remains dissatisfied and claims they were never informed of this change.

questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a discussion between the Product Owner and the stakeholder to align on the backlog prioritization process and invite them to future refinement sessions.
distractors: Update the stakeholder engagement plan to include a weekly personal briefing for this specific high-power stakeholder.
Review the definition of done with the stakeholder to explain why the feature could not be completed as originally planned.
Advise the Product Owner to reprioritize the feature for the next sprint to maintain stakeholder satisfaction.

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion between the Product Owner and the stakeholder to align on the backlog prioritization process and invite them to future refinement sessions.
Update the stakeholder engagement plan to include a weekly personal briefing for this specific high-power stakeholder.
Review the definition of done with the stakeholder to explain why the feature could not be completed as originally planned.
Advise the Product Owner to reprioritize the feature for the next sprint to maintain stakeholder satisfaction.

remediation.coreLogic: In Agile, stakeholders should be active participants. If a high-power stakeholder is surprised, it indicates a failure in collaborative engagement. Inviting them to refinement and aligning on the process addresses the root cause of the "surprise."
remediation.pmiMindset: Engagement in Agile is about collaboration and transparency, not just reporting. The PM acts as a facilitator to bridge gaps between the team and business.
remediation.theTrap: Weekly briefings are a "predictive" push-communication fix that doesn't solve the underlying issue of the stakeholder not being part of the agile loop.

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing a digital transformation project that uses a predictive approach for hardware deployment and an agile approach for software development. The hardware vendor is consistently meeting milestones, but the internal software team is struggling with shifting requirements from a resistant department head who controls the end-user resources.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager prioritize the engagement with the department head according to the Stakeholder Cube?
questions.correctAnswer: Classify the department head as a Priority Risk due to high power and resistant attitude, and initiate a root-cause discovery meeting.
distractors: Map the department head to the "Keep Satisfied" quadrant and provide more detailed hardware deployment reports.
Escalate the resistance to the project sponsor to ensure the end-user resources are made available as per the charter.
Use the "Reciprocity" influence tactic by helping the department head with their own internal metrics first.

answers.text: Classify the department head as a Priority Risk due to high power and resistant attitude, and initiate a root-cause discovery meeting.
Map the department head to the "Keep Satisfied" quadrant and provide more detailed hardware deployment reports.
Escalate the resistance to the project sponsor to ensure the end-user resources are made available as per the charter.
Use the "Reciprocity" influence tactic by helping the department head with their own internal metrics first.

remediation.coreLogic: The Stakeholder Cube adds "Attitude" to the Power/Interest grid. A high-power, resistant stakeholder is a "Priority Risk" that requires direct engagement and root-cause analysis to convert or neutralize their impact.
remediation.pmiMindset: Resistance is often a symptom of unmanaged fear or loss of control. The PM must address the human element directly before escalating.
remediation.theTrap: Escalation is a last resort. The PM should first try to understand and resolve the resistance.

questions.scenario: A global project includes stakeholders from four different countries. questions.correctAnswer: Analyze the communication needs and cultural preferences of each region and update the communications management plan with tailored engagement methods.
distractors: Implement a standardized, detailed reporting template for all regions to ensure consistency in feedback.
Schedule separate virtual meetings for each region to prevent one group from dominating the other.
Issue a project directive requiring all stakeholders to use a specific technical requirements template during meetings.

answers.text: Analyze the communication needs and cultural preferences of each region and update the communications management plan with tailored engagement methods.
Implement a standardized, detailed reporting template for all regions to ensure consistency in feedback.
Schedule separate virtual meetings for each region to prevent one group from dominating the other.
Issue a project directive requiring all stakeholders to use a specific technical requirements template during meetings.

remediation.coreLogic: Global stakeholders require tailored communication based on culture and preference (e.g., high-context vs low-context). Standardizing often fails if it doesn't account for these nuances.
remediation.pmiMindset: Effective communication is about the receiver's needs. The PM must adapt the plan to the stakeholders, not force the stakeholders into a rigid plan.
remediation.theTrap: Standardizing (Distractor 1) sounds efficient but ignores the cultural reasons for the vague feedback or technical dominance.

questions.scenario: A newly formed agile team is struggling to gain the trust of a traditional "command-and-control" manager who is the primary stakeholder. questions.correctAnswer: Invite the manager to the sprint reviews to see working software and use the "Trust Equation" by demonstrating reliability and lowering self-orientation.
distractors: Politely ask the manager to stop attending the daily standups as they are for the team only, per agile principles.
Create a separate weekly dashboard for the manager that translates agile velocity into individual productivity metrics.
Ask the project sponsor to reinforce the agile mindset with the manager to ensure they stop interfering with the team.

answers.text: Invite the manager to the sprint reviews to see working software and use the "Trust Equation" by demonstrating reliability and lowering self-orientation.
Politely ask the manager to stop attending the daily standups as they are for the team only, per agile principles.
Create a separate weekly dashboard for the manager that translates agile velocity into individual productivity metrics.
Ask the project sponsor to reinforce the agile mindset with the manager to ensure they stop interfering with the team.

remediation.coreLogic: Building trust requires demonstrating reliability (delivering software) and intimacy (understanding their concerns), while lowering self-orientation. Sprint reviews provide the best venue for this "show, don't tell" approach.
remediation.pmiMindset: Influence without authority relies on rapport and social proof. Demonstrating value builds more trust than quoting rules.
remediation.theTrap: Excluding the manager (Distractor 1) will likely increase their anxiety and decrease trust, even if it follows the "letter" of agile.

questions.scenario: A project to implement a new ERP system is facing conflicting requirements. The Finance Director requires deep audit trails for every transaction, while the Sales VP demands a streamlined, "one-click" checkout process that bypasses several verification steps. Both stakeholders are high-power and high-interest.
questions.questionText: What should the project manager do FIRST to optimize alignment?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a joint session to surface the underlying interests and identify potential trade-offs or middle-ground solutions.
distractors: Prioritize the Finance Director's requirements as they are tied to legal compliance and organizational governance.
Update the risk register to include the potential for scope creep and stakeholder dissatisfaction.
Refer the conflict to the project sponsor for a final decision on which requirement takes precedence.

answers.text: Facilitate a joint session to surface the underlying interests and identify potential trade-offs or middle-ground solutions.

Refer the conflict to the project sponsor for a final decision on which requirement takes precedence.

remediation.coreLogic: Alignment starts with understanding "Why." Facilitation helps stakeholders move from "Positions" (one-click vs audit trail) to "Interests" (speed vs compliance), where creative solutions are found.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM is a facilitator. Resolving conflict at the source is always preferred over escalation or unilateral decision-making.
remediation.theTrap: Choosing one side (Distractor 1) based on compliance is tempting, but ignores the need for alignment and user adoption.

questions.scenario: During a transition from a predictive to a hybrid model, the project team realizes that an informal "expert" in the legacy system has been discouraging the end-users from adopting the new software. This expert was not listed in the initial stakeholder register.

distractors: Formally invite the expert to join the project team as a Subject Matter Expert (SME) to neutralize their opposition.

Request the change management team to create a targeted communication plan to correct the misinformation being spread.

answers.text: Add the expert to the stakeholder register and use the "Snowball" technique to identify any other missing influencers they might know.

remediation.theTrap: Inviting them as an SME (Distractor 1) is a specific engagement strategy that might be correct later, but identification and broader analysis must come first.

questions.scenario: A stakeholder who was previously "Neutral" has moved to "Resistant" after a major project milestone was delayed. This stakeholder is an influential department head whose support is critical for the next phase. The project manager needs to update the stakeholder engagement plan.
questions.questionText: Which action should the project manager include in the updated plan?
questions.correctAnswer: Schedule a 1:1 meeting to perform a root-cause diagnosis of the shift in attitude and identify specific "What's In It For Me" (WIIFM) benefits for the next phase.
distractors: Increase the frequency of automated status reports sent to this stakeholder to ensure they have more data on project progress.
Re-map the stakeholder on the Power/Interest grid to a lower interest quadrant to reflect their current disengagement.
Invite the stakeholder to the steering committee meetings so they can see the project's strategic importance from the sponsor's perspective.

answers.text: Schedule a 1:1 meeting to perform a root-cause diagnosis of the shift in attitude and identify specific "What's In It For Me" (WIIFM) benefits for the next phase.

Re-map the stakeholder on the Power/Interest grid to a lower interest quadrant to reflect their current disengagement.

remediation.pmiMindset: Engagement is active. More reports (Distractor 1) rarely solve resistance; human connection and value alignment do.
remediation.theTrap: Moving them to a lower interest quadrant (Distractor 2) is incorrect because their resistance usually implies their interest (negative) has actually increased or remained high.

questions.scenario: An agile team is working on a public-facing application. A regulatory body has just issued new data privacy guidelines that must be met within the next three months. The project manager needs to assess how this affects the stakeholder landscape.
questions.questionText: According to the Salience Model, how should this regulatory body be classified?
questions.correctAnswer: Definitive, because they possess power, legitimacy, and an urgent deadline.
distractors: Dominant, because they have formal authority and a legitimate right to influence the project.
Dangerous, because they have the power to halt the project and an urgent timeframe.
Dependent, because they require the project team to advocate for the new privacy guidelines within the organization.

answers.text: Definitive, because they possess power, legitimacy, and an urgent deadline.
Dominant, because they have formal authority and a legitimate right to influence the project.
Dangerous, because they have the power to halt the project and an urgent timeframe.
Dependent, because they require the project team to advocate for the new privacy guidelines within the organization.

remediation.coreLogic: A regulator with a deadline has Power (authority), Legitimacy (legal right), and Urgency (3-month window). This combination makes them "Definitive" stakeholders—the highest priority.
remediation.pmiMindset: The Salience Model is used to prioritize attention. Definitive stakeholders require immediate and high-level engagement.
remediation.theTrap: "Dangerous" (Distractor 2) is for stakeholders with Power and Urgency but lacking Legitimacy (e.g., a group using coercion). Regulators are legitimate.

questions.scenario: A project manager is using a RACI matrix to clarify roles for a hybrid project. There is confusion about who should be consulted versus who should just be informed regarding software release dates. Several functional managers are upset because they found out about a release through a general company newsletter.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager correct this communication gap?
questions.correctAnswer: Review the RACI matrix and communication plan to ensure that stakeholders needing "Consulted" status are receiving interactive communication before decisions are finalized.
distractors: Update the RACI matrix to change all functional managers from "Informed" to "Accountable" for release decisions.
Increase the frequency of the company newsletter to ensure it reaches the functional managers faster.
Implement a "Push" communication strategy for all stakeholders on the RACI matrix to ensure no one is missed.

answers.text: Review the RACI matrix and communication plan to ensure that stakeholders needing "Consulted" status are receiving interactive communication before decisions are finalized.
Update the RACI matrix to change all functional managers from "Informed" to "Accountable" for release decisions.
Increase the frequency of the company newsletter to ensure it reaches the functional managers faster.
Implement a "Push" communication strategy for all stakeholders on the RACI matrix to ensure no one is missed.

remediation.coreLogic: "Consulted" (C) requires two-way, interactive communication *before* a decision. "Informed" (I) is one-way communication *after*. The managers are upset because they were treated as "I" when they felt they should be "C."
remediation.pmiMindset: The RACI matrix is a tool for setting communication expectations. Mismatches between RACI and actual engagement cause conflict.
remediation.theTrap: Making everyone "Accountable" (Distractor 1) violates the "one A per task" rule and creates more confusion.

questions.scenario: In an agile project, a key stakeholder from the marketing department has stopped attending the bi-weekly sprint reviews. distractors: Send the stakeholder a detailed technical transcript of the sprint reviews so they can catch up on their own time.
Remind the stakeholder that attendance at sprint reviews is a mandatory requirement for all agile project participants.
Create a separate, less technical monthly marketing briefing to replace their need for attending sprint reviews.

answers.text: Work with the Product Owner to tailor the sprint review agenda to include a "value summary" that highlights strategic brand alignment.

Remind the stakeholder that attendance at sprint reviews is a mandatory requirement for all agile project participants.
Create a separate, less technical monthly marketing briefing to replace their need for attending sprint reviews.

remediation.coreLogic: Agile engagement should be tailored to provide value to the participant. If a stakeholder finds it too technical, the solution is to adjust the "Demo" or "Review" to include the strategic context they need.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM/Scrum Master must protect the feedback loop. If the loop is broken (stakeholder leaves), the PM must fix the loop, not bypass it with separate meetings.
remediation.theTrap: Separate briefings (Distractor 3) create silos and violate the "transparency and direct collaboration" principle of agile.

questions.scenario: During a steering committee meeting, the project manager realizes that the Operations Director and the Finance Director have fundamentally different views on the project's success criteria. Expert judgment from a neutral third-party consultant to decide which priority is more important for the organization.

answers.text: Multi-criteria decision analysis to objectively weigh the priorities and facilitate a consensus on the best path forward.

Expert judgment from a neutral third-party consultant to decide which priority is more important for the organization.

remediation.coreLogic: When stakeholders have conflicting priorities, an objective tool like Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) helps move the conversation from "I want this" to "How do these options score against our shared goals?"
remediation.pmiMindset: Facilitating a decision is better than making one or asking the sponsor to make one. Tools provide the structure for that facilitation.
remediation.theTrap: Using the charter (Distractor 1) might just highlight the conflict rather than resolving it, as the charter likely contains the very ambiguity causing the issue.

questions.scenario: A project manager is taking over an agile team that has a history of friction with a senior executive. The executive believes the team is "hidden in a black box" and doesn't trust their progress. The team feels the executive is "micromanaging" and doesn't understand agile.

distractors: Increase "Credibility" by providing the executive with the team's certifications and historical velocity data from previous projects.
Decrease "Self-Orientation" by telling the executive that the team's only goal is to make the executive look good to the board.
Increase "Reliability" by inviting the executive to the daily standups so they can see exactly what every person is doing every day.

answers.text: Increase "Intimacy" by having a 1:1 with the executive to understand their personal fears and "Reliability" by delivering a small, high-value feature immediately.
Increase "Credibility" by providing the executive with the team's certifications and historical velocity data from previous projects.
Decrease "Self-Orientation" by telling the executive that the team's only goal is to make the executive look good to the board.
Increase "Reliability" by inviting the executive to the daily standups so they can see exactly what every person is doing every day.

remediation.coreLogic: Trust is built by lowering self-orientation and increasing intimacy (safety/understanding) and reliability (follow-through). A 1:1 for understanding fears plus a quick win addresses both the human and performance gaps.
remediation.pmiMindset: Rapport and empathy (intimacy) are often the missing links in technical projects. Delivering value (reliability) proves the mindset works.
remediation.theTrap: Micromanagement (Distractor 3) is usually a symptom of low trust; inviting them to the standup might actually worsen the team's friction and the executive's urge to control.

questions.scenario: A project manager is analyzing the stakeholder register and notes that a key regulator's influence has shifted from "Informal" to "Formal" due to a new legislation change. The regulator now has the power to stop the project if certain environmental standards are not met.

distractors: The Project Charter to include the new environmental standards as a high-level constraint.

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing a software rollout. During a pilot phase, several users express that they feel "overwhelmed" by the new interface and are secretly reverting to their old spreadsheets. This sentiment was not captured in the recent "satisfactory" survey results.

distractors: Send out a more detailed survey to all users to quantify the extent of the "spreadsheet reversion" problem.

Update the stakeholder register to mark the end-users as "Resistant" and inform the project sponsor of the adoption risk.

answers.text: Conduct "Active Listening" sessions with a small group of pilot users to understand the "Intimacy" gap and update the training plan.

Update the stakeholder register to mark the end-users as "Resistant" and inform the project sponsor of the adoption risk.

questions.scenario: A project manager is assigned to a project that is already in the execution phase. Review the project contract to identify the names of the vendor representatives and add them to the register.

remediation.theTrap: Contacting customers immediately (Distractor 2) might be premature if the PM hasn't yet analyzed their power, interest, or specific needs.

questions.scenario: A Product Owner in an agile project is consistently prioritizing features that benefit one specific department, causing dissatisfaction among stakeholders from other departments. The team is starting to feel the tension during sprint reviews.

questions.scenario: A project manager needs to influence a senior manager who is skeptical about a new project methodology. The project manager knows that this senior manager highly respects the opinion of the Chief Technology Officer (CTO), who is a vocal supporter of the new approach.

Consistency and Authority.

questions.scenario: An agile project is halfway through its timeline. A key stakeholder who was previously "Supportive" has stopped responding to emails and has missed the last three Sprint Reviews. answers.text: Conduct a 1:1 "Resistance Diagnosis" to understand if the withdrawal is due to competing priorities or a change in their perceived project value.

questions.scenario: A project manager is leading a project that involves a significant environmental impact. A local NGO (Non-Governmental Organization) is demanding a seat on the steering committee. Definitive, as their ability to launch legal challenges gives them high power over the project's success.
Demanding, as they have high urgency but no legitimate or formal power to influence the project's governance.

answers.text: Dependent, as they have legitimacy and urgency but lack formal power, and they may need to be paired with a sponsor to ensure their voice is heard.

questions.scenario: A project manager is facilitating a workshop to define "Success" for a new community park. The local residents want more green space, while the city council wants more revenue-generating facilities like a paid parking lot and a cafe.

Inform the residents that the city council provides the funding and therefore their requirements for revenue must come first.
Propose a 50/50 split of the land between green space and revenue-generating facilities as a fair compromise.

questions.scenario: A project manager is working with an agile team. A key stakeholder is consistently unhappy with the demos, saying "That's not what I meant" even though the team followed the user story exactly. The team is getting frustrated and trust is eroding.

Increase the frequency of the demos to every three days to catch the "That's not what I meant" earlier.

answers.text: Facilitate a session to "Define Done" and create visual prototypes or wireframes during backlog refinement to ensure shared mental models.

questions.scenario: A project manager is managing a project with high political sensitivity. A new CEO has just been appointed, and they have publicly questioned the project's strategic value. The project manager needs to update the engagement strategy.
questions.questionText: Which action is MOST consistent with the "Pillars of Trust"?
questions.correctAnswer: Schedule a briefing with the CEO to demonstrate "Radical Transparency" regarding project challenges and "Credibility" through data-backed progress.
distractors: Ask the project sponsor to talk to the CEO and defend the project's value on the project manager's behalf.
Send the CEO a comprehensive list of all completed milestones to prove the project's success to date.
Update the risk register to include "Executive Opposition" and wait for the CEO to request a formal update.

answers.text: Schedule a briefing with the CEO to demonstrate "Radical Transparency" regarding project challenges and "Credibility" through data-backed progress.
Ask the project sponsor to talk to the CEO and defend the project's value on the project manager's behalf.
Send the CEO a comprehensive list of all completed milestones to prove the project's success to date.
Update the risk register to include "Executive Opposition" and wait for the CEO to request a formal update.

remediation.coreLogic: Radical Transparency (sharing bad news as fast as good) builds credibility. A direct briefing to address concerns with data is the best way to earn trust from a skeptic.
remediation.pmiMindset: Don't hide. Be proactive and transparent when trust is at risk.
remediation.theTrap: Using the sponsor (Distractor 1) might solve the immediate problem but doesn't build the PM's own relationship or trust with the new CEO.

questions.scenario: A project manager is coordinating a project with a large number of "Informed" stakeholders on the RACI matrix. These stakeholders are complaining that they are receiving too many emails and are missing important updates.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST way to optimize this communication?
questions.correctAnswer: Implement a "Pull" communication strategy, such as an internal project portal or dashboard, where stakeholders can access updates at their own convenience.
distractors: Change all "Informed" stakeholders to "Consulted" so they feel more involved in the project decisions.
Create a weekly "Executive Summary" email that replaces all other individual updates for these stakeholders.
Use a "Push" communication strategy by sending a daily SMS alert with a link to the most critical update.

answers.text: Implement a "Pull" communication strategy, such as an internal project portal or dashboard, where stakeholders can access updates at their own convenience.
Change all "Informed" stakeholders to "Consulted" so they feel more involved in the project decisions.
Create a weekly "Executive Summary" email that replaces all other individual updates for these stakeholders.
Use a "Push" communication strategy by sending a daily SMS alert with a link to the most critical update.

remediation.coreLogic: "Pull" communication is best for large groups who need information but are suffering from "Push" overload. It empowers them to get what they need when they need it.
remediation.pmiMindset: Communication efficiency is key. More communication is not always better; targeted and accessible communication is.
remediation.theTrap: A weekly summary (Distractor 2) is a good "Push" fix, but a "Pull" strategy is more scalable and customizable for a "large number" of stakeholders.

questions.scenario: An agile team is working on a high-visibility product. A key stakeholder from the legal department is consistently late in providing approvals for content, which is causing bottlenecks in the sprint. The legal stakeholder says they are overwhelmed with other work and that "agile doesn't respect the time needed for thorough review."
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager (Scrum Master) to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Invite the legal stakeholder to the backlog refinement sessions to identify upcoming legal needs early and build a "Buffer" into the Definition of Ready.
distractors: Escalate the bottleneck to the project sponsor to ensure that legal approvals are prioritized by the legal department head.
Suggest that the team proceed with the content deployment and address any legal feedback as "technical debt" in the next sprint.
Assign a team member to act as a "Legal Liaison" to manually follow up with the legal department every day until approvals are granted.

answers.text: Invite the legal stakeholder to the backlog refinement sessions to identify upcoming legal needs early and build a "Buffer" into the Definition of Ready.
Escalate the bottleneck to the project sponsor to ensure that legal approvals are prioritized by the legal department head.
Suggest that the team proceed with the content deployment and address any legal feedback as "technical debt" in the next sprint.
Assign a team member to act as a "Legal Liaison" to manually follow up with the legal department every day until approvals are granted.

remediation.coreLogic: Integrating "slow" stakeholders into the agile process (Refinement) and adjusting the "Definition of Ready" ensures that the team doesn't start work that they can't finish due to external dependencies.
remediation.pmiMindset: Collaboration and "Working Together" are better than escalation. Respect the stakeholder's constraints by involving them earlier in the flow.
remediation.theTrap: Bypassing legal (Distractor 2) is a massive compliance risk and violates the core principle of legitimate stakeholder engagement.

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing a hospital wing construction project (predictive) and the implementation of a new patient management system (agile). The nursing staff is excited about the new wing but resistant to the software, fearing it will add to their administrative burden.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager optimize alignment between these two project components?
questions.correctAnswer: Highlight the "Integrated Value" by showing how the software automates data entry in the new wing, reducing physical movement and administrative time.
distractors: Separate the communication plans for the construction and the software to avoid confusing the nursing staff with too much information.
Focus the nursing staff's attention on the construction of the new wing and delay the software training until the building is complete.
Tell the nursing staff that the software is a mandatory requirement from the hospital board and is not open for negotiation.

answers.text: Highlight the "Integrated Value" by showing how the software automates data entry in the new wing, reducing physical movement and administrative time.
Separate the communication plans for the construction and the software to avoid confusing the nursing staff with too much information.
Focus the nursing staff's attention on the construction of the new wing and delay the software training until the building is complete.
Tell the nursing staff that the software is a mandatory requirement from the hospital board and is not open for negotiation.

remediation.coreLogic: Alignment in hybrid projects often requires showing how the different parts complement each other to provide a "Higher Value" (WIIFM). Connecting the new wing (positive) with the software (feared) helps bridge the engagement gap.
remediation.pmiMindset: Look for synergies. The PM's role is to integrate the various project outcomes into a cohesive value proposition for the stakeholders.
remediation.theTrap: Separating the plans (Distractor 1) might hide the benefits that one part of the project provides to the other, missing an opportunity for alignment.

questions.scenario: A project manager is struggling to get the commitment of a functional manager who controls a critical resource. The functional manager has ignored several requests for a meeting. The project manager learns that the functional manager is under immense pressure to meet their own departmental production targets.
questions.questionText: Which influence tactic based on Cialdini's principles would be MOST effective here?
questions.correctAnswer: Reciprocity: Offer to adjust the project schedule to avoid the functional manager's peak production window in exchange for the resource commitment later.
distractors: Scarcity: Inform the functional manager that if the resource is not committed now, the project will lose its funding and their department will lose out on the benefits.
Authority: Have the project sponsor send a formal memo to the functional manager demanding the resource as per the project charter.
Liking: Send the functional manager a gift or a positive email about their department's performance to build rapport before asking again.

answers.text: Reciprocity: Offer to adjust the project schedule to avoid the functional manager's peak production window in exchange for the resource commitment later.
Scarcity: Inform the functional manager that if the resource is not committed now, the project will lose its funding and their department will lose out on the benefits.
Authority: Have the project sponsor send a formal memo to the functional manager demanding the resource as per the project charter.
Liking: Send the functional manager a gift or a positive email about their department's performance to build rapport before asking again.

remediation.coreLogic: "Give before you get." By addressing the functional manager's pain point (production targets), the PM builds an obligation and trust (Reciprocity), making it easier to get the commitment.
remediation.pmiMindset: Influence is about understanding the other person's context. Solving their problem is the fastest way to solve yours.
remediation.theTrap: Authority (Distractor 3) might get the resource but will likely destroy the long-term relationship and cause passive-aggressive resistance later.

questions.scenario: An agile team has identified a "Dangerous" stakeholder according to the Salience Model. This stakeholder is a former project manager who was fired from the current project and is now spreading rumors to the executive board about the team's "lack of discipline."
questions.questionText: What is the project manager's (Scrum Master's) BEST course of action?
questions.correctAnswer: Document the rumors in the Stakeholder Register and work with the Product Owner to provide the executive board with objective, data-backed evidence of the team's progress.
distractors: Directly confront the former project manager and threaten legal action for defamation to stop the rumors.
Ignore the rumors and trust that the team's high-quality output during the sprint reviews will eventually speak for itself.
Request the project sponsor to issue a formal gag order preventing the former project manager from contacting any project stakeholders.

answers.text: Document the rumors in the Stakeholder Register and work with the Product Owner to provide the executive board with objective, data-backed evidence of the team's progress.
Directly confront the former project manager and threaten legal action for defamation to stop the rumors.
Ignore the rumors and trust that the team's high-quality output during the sprint reviews will eventually speak for itself.
Request the project sponsor to issue a formal gag order preventing the former project manager from contacting any project stakeholders.

remediation.coreLogic: Dangerous stakeholders (Power + Urgency, no Legitimacy) must be "Contained" or "Neutralized" with objective data. Providing the board with facts before the rumors take root protects the team.
remediation.pmiMindset: Manage the risk. A dangerous stakeholder is a risk to project reputation. Use transparency and evidence as your primary defense.
remediation.theTrap: Ignoring the rumors (Distractor 2) allows the "Dangerous" stakeholder to control the narrative at the executive level.

questions.scenario: During a phase-gate review, it becomes clear that the project's output, while meeting all technical specifications, does not satisfy the original business need of the marketing department because the market conditions have shifted during the 12-month development cycle.
questions.questionText: What is the project manager's MOST important responsibility in this situation?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a "Realignment Session" with Marketing and the Sponsor to evaluate if the remaining project scope should be changed to meet the new market reality.
distractors: Defend the project team's performance by showing that all requirements in the original scope statement were met on time and on budget.
Close the project immediately as it no longer provides the intended value to the organization.
Update the stakeholder engagement plan to include more frequent marketing reviews for the next project phase.

answers.text: Facilitate a "Realignment Session" with Marketing and the Sponsor to evaluate if the remaining project scope should be changed to meet the new market reality.
Defend the project team's performance by showing that all requirements in the original scope statement were met on time and on budget.
Close the project immediately as it no longer provides the intended value to the organization.
Update the stakeholder engagement plan to include more frequent marketing reviews for the next project phase.

remediation.coreLogic: The PM's ultimate goal is Value Delivery. If alignment is lost due to external changes, the PM must facilitate a reassessment of the project's direction to ensure it remains relevant.
remediation.pmiMindset: "Meeting requirements" is not enough if the value is gone. The PM must be a business partner who proactively addresses misalignment with strategic goals.
remediation.theTrap: Defending the team (Distractor 1) ignores the business failure and prioritizes "Output" over "Outcome."

questions.scenario: A project manager is leadng a hybrid project. The executive team is used to a predictive "RAG" (Red-Amber-Green) status report, but the development team is providing "Burn-up" and "Velocity" charts. The executives are frustrated that they can't tell if the project is "on track."
questions.questionText: How should the project manager execute the engagement strategy for the executives?
questions.correctAnswer: Create a "Hybrid Dashboard" that maps agile progress (velocity/burndown) to predictive milestones and uses the RAG status as a summary indicator.
distractors: Train the executives on how to read burn-up charts and velocity metrics to help them transition to an agile mindset.
Require the development team to stop using agile metrics and start providing traditional Gantt chart updates for the executive reports.
Use the "Authority" principle by asking the Agile PMO to mandate that executives accept agile reporting formats.

answers.text: Create a "Hybrid Dashboard" that maps agile progress (velocity/burndown) to predictive milestones and uses the RAG status as a summary indicator.
Train the executives on how to read burn-up charts and velocity metrics to help them transition to an agile mindset.
Require the development team to stop using agile metrics and start providing traditional Gantt chart updates for the executive reports.
Use the "Authority" principle by asking the Agile PMO to mandate that executives accept agile reporting formats.

remediation.coreLogic: Engagement requires meeting stakeholders where they are. In a hybrid environment, the PM must "translate" agile data into the language of the business (Predictive milestones/RAG) to maintain trust and visibility.
remediation.pmiMindset: Tailor communication. The goal is clarity for the stakeholder, not forcing them to learn new methodologies if it hinders their ability to govern.
remediation.theTrap: Training the executives (Distractor 1) is a long-term goal but doesn't solve the immediate need for clear status reporting during a high-stakes project.

questions.scenario: A project manager is performing stakeholder identification for a new international airport expansion. They have identified the government, the airlines, and the construction firms. However, they are concerned about "Shadow" stakeholders who might emerge later.
questions.questionText: Which technique is MOST likely to uncover these shadow stakeholders?
questions.correctAnswer: Using the "Snowball" technique by asking the government representatives: "Who else should we be talking to that might be impacted by this expansion?"
distractors: Reviewing the organizational charts of the airlines to identify all relevant department heads.
Conducting a brainstorming session with the project team and the construction SMEs.
Using a standardized stakeholder template provided by the PMO for large-scale infrastructure projects.

answers.text: Using the "Snowball" technique by asking the government representatives: "Who else should we be talking to that might be impacted by this expansion?"
Reviewing the organizational charts of the airlines to identify all relevant department heads.
Conducting a brainstorming session with the project team and the construction SMEs.
Using a standardized stakeholder template provided by the PMO for large-scale infrastructure projects.

remediation.coreLogic: The "Snowball" technique is specifically designed to uncover those stakeholders who aren't on the official lists but have informal power or interest (e.g., local environmental groups or historical societies).
remediation.pmiMindset: Continuous identification. The PM must go beyond the obvious and the formal to find the hidden influencers in the project ecosystem.
remediation.theTrap: Templates (Distractor 3) are good for "known-knowns" but often miss the unique, informal "shadow" stakeholders of a specific project.

questions.scenario: An agile team has lost trust in their Product Owner because the Product Owner frequently changes their mind about priorities mid-sprint. The team feels their work is being wasted and their velocity is dropping.
questions.questionText: What is the FIRST action the project manager (Scrum Master) should take to rebuild trust and influence the Product Owner?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a retrospective with the Product Owner and the team to analyze the impact of mid-sprint changes and "Commit" to a stable sprint backlog.
distractors: Update the team charter to include a rule that no changes are allowed once a sprint has started.
Escalate the Product Owner's behavior to the Agile Coach or the Product Management department head.
Advise the team to ignore the Product Owner's mid-sprint requests and only work on the items committed during sprint planning.

answers.text: Facilitate a retrospective with the Product Owner and the team to analyze the impact of mid-sprint changes and "Commit" to a stable sprint backlog.
Update the team charter to include a rule that no changes are allowed once a sprint has started.
Escalate the Product Owner's behavior to the Agile Coach or the Product Management department head.
Advise the team to ignore the Product Owner's mid-sprint requests and only work on the items committed during sprint planning.

remediation.coreLogic: Rebuilding trust starts with "Intimacy" (understanding the Product Owner's pressure) and "Reliability" (creating a process everyone follows). A retrospective is the standard agile forum for this.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM/Scrum Master is a coach and facilitator. Addressing the behavior and its impact (Waste/Low Velocity) is the first step toward change.
remediation.theTrap: Mandating rules (Distractor 1) without a collaborative discussion often leads to further friction rather than genuine trust and alignment.

questions.scenario: A project manager is managing a hybrid project to launch a new eco-friendly product line. The "Sustainability Officer" wants the packaging to be 100% biodegradable (high cost), while the "Procurement Manager" wants to use recycled plastic (low cost) to meet budget targets.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST way for the project manager to optimize alignment among these stakeholders?
questions.correctAnswer: Use "Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis" to evaluate both options against project goals (Cost, ESG metrics, Market Appeal) and facilitate a shared decision.
distractors: Choose the recycled plastic option as the project is currently over budget and the procurement manager has more formal power.
Ask the project sponsor to choose the option that best aligns with the company's long-term strategic vision.
Suggest a hybrid packaging solution that uses both materials, even if it increases the complexity of the manufacturing process.

answers.text: Use "Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis" to evaluate both options against project goals (Cost, ESG metrics, Market Appeal) and facilitate a shared decision.
Choose the recycled plastic option as the project is currently over budget and the procurement manager has more formal power.
Ask the project sponsor to choose the option that best aligns with the company's long-term strategic vision.
Suggest a hybrid packaging solution that uses both materials, even if it increases the complexity of the manufacturing process.

remediation.coreLogic: Objective analysis (MCDA) helps move stakeholders from emotional positions to data-backed decisions. It ensures that both "Cost" and "ESG" (Environmental, Social, Governance) are weighed fairly.
remediation.pmiMindset: Facilitate, don't dictate. Providing a structured way to compare options helps stakeholders reach alignment themselves.
remediation.theTrap: Simply splitting the difference (Distractor 3) might lead to a "lose-lose" situation where the cost is high and the sustainability goal is not fully met.

questions.scenario: A high-power stakeholder from a partner organization has become "Resistant" because they feel they were not consulted on a major technical decision. The project manager's engagement plan currently classifies them as "Keep Satisfied."
questions.questionText: What should the project manager do FIRST to update the engagement strategy?
questions.correctAnswer: Move the stakeholder to the "Manage Closely" quadrant in the stakeholder register and schedule a 1:1 "Active Listening" session to address the perceived exclusion.
distractors: Update the RACI matrix to change the stakeholder's role from "Informed" to "Consulted" for all future technical decisions.
Send the stakeholder a formal apology letter signed by the project sponsor to acknowledge the oversight.
Review the communications management plan to see where the breakdown in communication occurred during the technical decision process.

answers.text: Move the stakeholder to the "Manage Closely" quadrant in the stakeholder register and schedule a 1:1 "Active Listening" session to address the perceived exclusion.
Update the RACI matrix to change the stakeholder's role from "Informed" to "Consulted" for all future technical decisions.
Send the stakeholder a formal apology letter signed by the project sponsor to acknowledge the oversight.
Review the communications management plan to see where the breakdown in communication occurred during the technical decision process.

remediation.coreLogic: When a high-power stakeholder becomes resistant due to exclusion, their "Interest" (negative) has effectively increased. They must be moved to "Manage Closely" and engaged directly to restore trust.
remediation.pmiMindset: Engagement is dynamic. If a strategy fails (they become resistant), you must analyze the failure and adjust the "Intensity" of the engagement.
remediation.theTrap: Apologizing (Distractor 2) is a good gesture, but doesn't change the underlying strategy or address the stakeholder's need for future involvement.

questions.scenario: An agile team is working on a project with a very large number of end-users (over 100,000). The project manager needs to prioritize feedback from these users.
questions.questionText: According to the Salience Model, how should the project manager classify a small but vocal group of users who are using social media to demand a specific feature "immediately"?
questions.correctAnswer: Demanding, as they have high urgency but lack formal power and legitimacy compared to the broader user base.
distractors: Dangerous, as their social media presence could cause significant reputational damage to the project.
Dependent, as they rely on the project manager to advocate for their specific feature within the agile team.
Latent, as they have low interest and low power until they are triggered by a project delay.

answers.text: Demanding, as they have high urgency but lack formal power and legitimacy compared to the broader user base.
Dangerous, as their social media presence could cause significant reputational damage to the project.
Dependent, as they rely on the project manager to advocate for their specific feature within the agile team.
Latent, as they have low interest and low power until they are triggered by a project delay.

remediation.coreLogic: High Urgency + No Power + No Legitimacy (in terms of representative authority) = "Demanding." These stakeholders are "loud" but shouldn't necessarily drive the product roadmap.
remediation.pmiMindset: Prioritize based on attributes. Don't let the "loudest" voice dictate priorities if they don't have the power or legitimacy to do so.
remediation.theTrap: Calling them "Dangerous" (Distractor 1) is tempting due to the "reputational damage" mention, but Dangerous requires Power (the actual ability to stop the project), which a small user group lacks.

questions.scenario: A project manager is coordinating a project that includes a mix of "High-Context" and "Low-Context" cultures. The Low-Context stakeholders are frustrated that meetings are too long and indirect, while the High-Context stakeholders feel that the Low-Context stakeholders are "rude" and "too aggressive" in their emails.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST way to optimize stakeholder communication in this scenario?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the communications management plan to include "Cultural Norms" guidelines, using indirect communication for relationship-building and direct communication for technical tasks.
distractors: Standardize all project communications to be "Low-Context" (direct and explicit) to ensure there is no ambiguity in requirements or deadlines.
Separate the project teams by culture so that they can communicate in their preferred styles and then have a "Cultural Lead" translate between them.
Tell both groups that the project uses a "Global Standard" of communication and that they need to adapt to a neutral, professional style.

answers.text: Update the communications management plan to include "Cultural Norms" guidelines, using indirect communication for relationship-building and direct communication for technical tasks.
Standardize all project communications to be "Low-Context" (direct and explicit) to ensure there is no ambiguity in requirements or deadlines.
Separate the project teams by culture so that they can communicate in their preferred styles and then have a "Cultural Lead" translate between them.
Tell both groups that the project uses a "Global Standard" of communication and that they need to adapt to a neutral, professional style.

remediation.coreLogic: Effective global communication requires "Biculturalism" or adaptation. Using the right style for the right task (Relationship vs Task) respects both cultural preferences and improves engagement.
remediation.pmiMindset: Empathy and adaptation. The PM must recognize cultural differences as a communication barrier and actively plan to overcome them through tailoring.
remediation.theTrap: Standardizing to Low-Context (Distractor 1) might alienate the High-Context stakeholders and destroy the "Intimacy" (trust) needed for collaboration.

questions.scenario: A project manager needs to get the "Buy-in" of a skeptical CFO for a project that has a high upfront cost but long-term strategic benefits. The CFO is known for being very conservative and focused on short-term quarterly results.
questions.questionText: Which action based on the "Trust Equation" would most likely influence the CFO?
questions.correctAnswer: Increase "Credibility" by presenting a detailed, third-party ROI analysis and lower "Self-Orientation" by acknowledging the CFO's concern about short-term cash flow.
distractors: Increase "Intimacy" by taking the CFO out to lunch and building a personal relationship before discussing the project.
Increase "Reliability" by showing the CFO that the project team has never missed a budget target in the last three years.
Increase "Credibility" by showing the CFO the CEO's signed endorsement of the project's strategic value.

answers.text: Increase "Credibility" by presenting a detailed, third-party ROI analysis and lower "Self-Orientation" by acknowledging the CFO's concern about short-term cash flow.
Increase "Intimacy" by taking the CFO out to lunch and building a personal relationship before discussing the project.
Increase "Reliability" by showing the CFO that the project team has never missed a budget target in the last three years.
Increase "Credibility" by showing the CFO the CEO's signed endorsement of the project's strategic value.

remediation.coreLogic: For a skeptical financial stakeholder, Credibility (data/expertise) and low Self-Orientation (showing you understand *their* constraints, like cash flow) are the most powerful trust-builders.
remediation.pmiMindset: Address the "Skepticism" at its root. For a CFO, the root is usually risk and data. Acknowledging their constraints proves you are a partner, not just a requester.
remediation.theTrap: CEO endorsement (Distractor 3) is "Authority," which helps, but doesn't build "Trust" in the PM's ability to manage the financial risk.

questions.scenario: During a retrospective, the agile team expresses that they feel "monitored" by the Product Owner, who attends the daily standups and takes detailed notes on what each person says. The team's trust in the Product Owner is declining, and they are becoming less transparent during the meetings.
questions.questionText: What is the project manager's (Scrum Master's) BEST action?
questions.correctAnswer: Coach the Product Owner on the purpose of the daily standup (team synchronization, not status reporting) and suggest they observe without taking individual notes.
distractors: Ask the Product Owner to stop attending the daily standups entirely to give the team "breathing room" and restore transparency.
Advise the team that the Product Owner has a right to know the status of the project and that they should be more professional in their communication.
Update the team charter to include a rule that no notes are allowed to be taken during the daily standup sessions.

answers.text: Coach the Product Owner on the purpose of the daily standup (team synchronization, not status reporting) and suggest they observe without taking individual notes.
Ask the Product Owner to stop attending the daily standups entirely to give the team "breathing room" and restore transparency.
Advise the team that the Product Owner has a right to know the status of the project and that they should be more professional in their communication.
Update the team charter to include a rule that no notes are allowed to be taken during the daily standup sessions.

remediation.coreLogic: The Scrum Master's role is to protect the team's agile environment. Coaching the PO on the *intent* of the ceremony (collaboration, not surveillance) addresses the root cause of the trust erosion.
remediation.pmiMindset: Facilitate and coach. Correcting the behavior while maintaining the relationship between the team and the PO is the goal.
remediation.theTrap: Excluding the PO (Distractor 1) might solve the immediate tension but misses the opportunity to align the PO's behavior with agile principles.

questions.scenario: A project manager is leadng a hybrid project for a new medical device. The "Quality Assurance" stakeholder has a "Resistant" attitude because they believe the agile software development approach will bypass necessary safety testing.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager re-map this stakeholder's engagement strategy using the Stakeholder Cube?
questions.correctAnswer: Identify them as a "Priority Risk" (High Power, High Interest, Resistant) and involve them directly in defining the "Definition of Done" to include safety gates.
distractors: Map them as "Keep Satisfied" (High Power, Low Interest) and send them weekly reports on the completed safety tests.
Identify them as a "Danger Zone" stakeholder (High Power, Low Interest, Resistant) and ask the project sponsor to neutralize their concerns.
Map them as "Monitor" (Low Power, Low Interest) since the software team has its own internal QA process.

answers.text: Identify them as a "Priority Risk" (High Power, High Interest, Resistant) and involve them directly in defining the "Definition of Done" to include safety gates.
Map them as "Keep Satisfied" (High Power, Low Interest) and send them weekly reports on the completed safety tests.
Identify them as a "Danger Zone" stakeholder (High Power, Low Interest, Resistant) and ask the project sponsor to neutralize their concerns.
Map them as "Monitor" (Low Power, Low Interest) since the software team has its own internal QA process.

remediation.coreLogic: A QA lead for a medical device has High Power (can stop the launch) and High Interest. If they are Resistant, they are a "Priority Risk." Inclusion in the "Definition of Done" addresses their fear of bypassed testing.
remediation.pmiMindset: Resistance from a legitimate authority (QA) should be addressed by increasing their involvement, not by bypassing or neutralizing them.
remediation.theTrap: "Danger Zone" (Distractor 2) is for stakeholders who are resistant and powerful but have *low* interest (e.g., they don't care about the project's success, just their own power). QA has high interest.

questions.scenario: A project manager is facilitating a session to align the expectations of the "Customer" and the "Internal Development Team." The Customer expects a "Premium" product with all possible features, while the Team's budget and timeline only allow for a "Basic" functional version.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST "No Surprises" action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Explicitly "Surface and Align" the expectations by facilitating a trade-off discussion between features, cost, and time, and documenting the agreed-upon scope.
distractors: Deliver the "Basic" version on time and on budget, and then manage the customer's disappointment during the final project handover.
Ask the project team to work overtime to deliver as many "Premium" features as possible to meet the customer's high expectations.
Request the project sponsor to increase the budget so that the "Premium" product can be delivered as the customer expects.

answers.text: Explicitly "Surface and Align" the expectations by facilitating a trade-off discussion between features, cost, and time, and documenting the agreed-upon scope.
Deliver the "Basic" version on time and on budget, and then manage the customer's disappointment during the final project handover.
Ask the project team to work overtime to deliver as many "Premium" features as possible to meet the customer's high expectations.
Request the project sponsor to increase the budget so that the "Premium" product can be delivered as the customer expects.

remediation.coreLogic: "Surface and Align" is the only way to prevent the "That's not what I expected" failure at the end of a project. Early trade-off discussions are critical for expectation management.
remediation.pmiMindset: Proactive alignment. Disappointment is a failure of engagement, even if the "Technical" project was successful. No surprises.
remediation.theTrap: Working overtime (Distractor 2) is a "Heroic" but unsustainable and risky approach that doesn't address the underlying expectation gap.

questions.scenario: An agile project has stakeholders spread across three continents. The project manager notices that stakeholders in Asia rarely speak during the "Open Q&A" sessions of the sprint reviews, while stakeholders in North America dominate the time with questions.
questions.questionText: Which action demonstrates the BEST "Analysis and Tailoring" of communication?
questions.correctAnswer: Use asynchronous feedback tools (like a shared document or poll) to allow the Asian stakeholders to provide input before and after the meeting in their preferred style.
distractors: Direct the Asian stakeholders to be more assertive and ask at least two questions each during the live sprint review sessions.

questions.scenario: A project manager is managing a hybrid project where the software team is consistently outperforming the hardware team. The software team is starting to feel "held back" by the hardware delays and is publicly criticizing the hardware team's work during joint meetings. Trust is breaking down between the teams.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the project manager to build trust and influence these teams?
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a joint "Value Stream Mapping" session to help both teams understand their interdependencies and celebrate "Joint Wins" for integrated milestones.
distractors: Separate the teams into different meeting rooms and manage the communication between them manually to prevent further public criticism.
Reprimand the software team for their unprofessional behavior and remind them that the hardware team is also critical for project success.
Suggest that the hardware team adopts agile practices to help them speed up their delivery and keep pace with the software team.

answers.text: Facilitate a joint "Value Stream Mapping" session to help both teams understand their interdependencies and celebrate "Joint Wins" for integrated milestones.
Separate the teams into different meeting rooms and manage the communication between them manually to prevent further public criticism.
Reprimand the software team for their unprofessional behavior and remind them that the hardware team is also critical for project success.
Suggest that the hardware team adopts agile practices to help them speed up their delivery and keep pace with the software team.

remediation.coreLogic: Building trust between silos requires "Shared Ownership" and "Intimacy" (understanding the other team's constraints). Visualizing the interdependencies (Value Stream) helps teams see themselves as partners.
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM is a bridge-builder. Focus on the "Shared Goal" and "Shared Success" rather than individual team performance or blame.
remediation.theTrap: Reprimanding the software team (Distractor 2) addresses the symptom but not the root cause of the breakdown in trust and understanding.

questions.scenario: A project manager is executing the engagement plan. A mid-level manager who was previously "Unaware" of the project has just discovered that the project will automate 40% of their department's current tasks. They are now "Resistant" and are refusing to provide the project team with the necessary process documentation.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST way to address this resistance?
questions.correctAnswer: Use a "WIIFM" (What's In It For Me) strategy by showing the manager how the project will free up their team for higher-value, more strategic work.
distractors: Document the manager's refusal in the issue log and escalate it to the project sponsor to ensure the documentation is provided.
Update the stakeholder register to move the manager to the "Resistant" category and wait for the department head to intervene.
Inform the manager that the project is an organizational mandate and that their cooperation is required for their annual performance review.

answers.text: Use a "WIIFM" (What's In It For Me) strategy by showing the manager how the project will free up their team for higher-value, more strategic work.
Document the manager's refusal in the issue log and escalate it to the project sponsor to ensure the documentation is provided.
Update the stakeholder register to move the manager to the "Resistant" category and wait for the department head to intervene.
Inform the manager that the project is an organizational mandate and that their cooperation is required for their annual performance review.

remediation.coreLogic: Resistance from fear of loss (status, control, or jobs) is best addressed by highlighting the "New Opportunities" and "Value" (WIIFM) the change brings to the stakeholder.
remediation.pmiMindset: Empathy and value-alignment. Address the "Fear" with a positive "Future State" vision.
remediation.theTrap: Escalation (Distractor 1) or threats (Distractor 3) might get the documentation but will create a "Long-term Enemy" who may sabotage the project later.

questions.scenario: An agile team is working on an internal HR tool. They have identified the HR Director, the IT Lead, and the Finance Manager. questions.questionText: What does this indicate about the project manager's (Scrum Master's) stakeholder identification process?
questions.correctAnswer: A failure to use "Stakeholder Templates" or "Checklists" (like Legal/Compliance/HR) that would have ensured all standard functional stakeholders were identified early.
distractors: A failure to involve the end-users in the initial brainstorming session, as they would have known about the GDPR requirements.
A failure to use the "Salience Model" during the first sprint, which would have identified the Data Privacy Officer as a definitive stakeholder.
Nothing; in agile, stakeholders are identified progressively, and finding the Privacy Officer in sprint two is part of the normal process.
