distractors: This activity is on the critical path and must be monitored daily to prevent any project-wide delays.
This activity can be delayed by 10 days without affecting the next activity in the schedule sequence.
The schedule logic is incorrect because Total Float must always be equal to or less than Free Float.

answers.text: Any delay to this activity will immediately delay its successor, but it won't impact the overall project completion date until it slips more than 10 days.
This activity is on the critical path and must be monitored daily to prevent any project-wide delays.
This activity can be delayed by 10 days without affecting the next activity in the schedule sequence.
The schedule logic is incorrect because Total Float must always be equal to or less than Free Float.

remediation.coreLogic: Free Float is the time an activity can slip without delaying its successor. Total Float is the time it can slip without delaying the project end date. 0 Free Float means the successor is "tight" against this task.
remediation.pmiMindset: Precision in understanding different float types is essential for managing daily schedule trade-offs and resource assignments.
remediation.theTrap: Total Float is often greater than Free Float (Distractor 4 is false). If Total Float > 0, the activity is not on the critical path (Distractor 1).

questions.scenario: During a retrospective, the team identifies that the "Design Review" phase is consistently taking four days, while the actual design work only takes two days. This is causing a significant lag in their sprint cycle.

answers.text: Facilitate a discussion on how to integrate reviews continuously into the design process rather than treating them as a separate phase.
Add two extra days to every design story estimate to account for the review time.
Instruct the designers to work on two stories at once so they are productive during the four-day review period.
Direct the reviewers to finish their work in one day to match the pace of the design team.

questions.scenario: A program manager is coordinating a government contract that requires a monthly progress report using Earned Value Management (Predictive). However, the development team is using Scrum (Agile) and does not track "percent complete" for individual tasks.

Divide the total story points in the sprint by the number of days elapsed to calculate a daily "Earned Value" average.
Report the Planned Value (PV) as the Earned Value (EV) since agile teams are expected to complete their committed sprint backlog.

answers.text: Use the "0/100" rule, where EV is only earned for user stories that meet the "Definition of Done" within the reporting period.
Ask each developer to provide their best estimate of the "percent complete" for their current work-in-progress stories.
Divide the total story points in the sprint by the number of days elapsed to calculate a daily "Earned Value" average.
Report the Planned Value (PV) as the Earned Value (EV) since agile teams are expected to complete their committed sprint backlog.

remediation.pmiMindset: Integrating agile and predictive metrics requires adapting traditional tools (like EVM) to the "value-based" delivery of agile.

questions.scenario: A project manager is using the Critical Chain Method for a new product launch. The team is worried because several individual activities are finishing late, and their "performance bars" are in the red.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager interpret this situation?
questions.correctAnswer: Look at the consumption rate of the "Project Buffer" at the end of the chain; if the buffer is healthy, the project is still on track despite individual task delays.
distractors: Immediately crash the late tasks to move their performance bars back into the green and protect the project schedule.
Re-baseline the individual task dates to reflect the new reality and prevent the team from feeling discouraged.
Switch back to the Critical Path Method, as the team clearly does not understand the concept of buffers.

answers.text: Look at the consumption rate of the "Project Buffer" at the end of the chain; if the buffer is healthy, the project is still on track despite individual task delays.
Immediately crash the late tasks to move their performance bars back into the green and protect the project schedule.
Re-baseline the individual task dates to reflect the new reality and prevent the team from feeling discouraged.
Switch back to the Critical Path Method, as the team clearly does not understand the concept of buffers.

questions.scenario: A project manager is planning a multi-year pharmaceutical trial. The first year involves laboratory testing (Agile), and the second year involves human trials (Predictive milestones). The PM is using historical data from three previous trials to set the schedule.

questions.scenario: An agile team has a "Definition of Ready" that requires all stories to have a confirmed UI mockup before they can be pulled into a sprint. The design team is currently two sprints behind, causing the development team to have an empty sprint backlog.

questions.scenario:

Path C: 14 days

questions.correctAnswer: The new critical path is Path C with a duration of 14 days.
distractors: The new critical path is Path B with a duration of 13 days.

The new critical path is Path B with a duration of 13 days.
The project duration remains 15 days because crashing Path B doesn't affect Path C.
The project duration becomes 12 days as Path A is now the shortest path.

remediation.theTrap: Focusing only on the path you crashed (Distractor 1) and ignoring the rest of the network is a common mistake.

questions.scenario: An agile project is nearing its final release. The Product Owner wants to ensure that the "Product Launch" marketing campaign is perfectly synchronized with the "v1.0" code deployment.

questions.scenario: A project manager is defining the schedule management plan for a project with high uncertainty. The sponsor requests that the schedule include a "Management Reserve."

remediation.pmiMindset: Distinguishing between Contingency Reserves (inside the baseline for known risks) and Management Reserves (outside the baseline for unknown risks) is a key governance concept.
remediation.theTrap: Padding individual tasks (Distractor 1) is a poor practice (Student Syndrome) that leads to wasted time.

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing a multi-year bridge construction project. At the end of month 10, the project status is as follows: Budget at Completion (BAC) is $2,000,000; Planned Value (PV) is $1,000,000; Earned Value (EV) is $800,000; and Actual Cost (AC) is $900,000. The project sponsor is concerned about the project's financial health.
questions.questionText: Which interpretation of the data should the project manager provide to the sponsor?
questions.correctAnswer: The project is over budget and behind schedule, with a cost performance index (CPI) indicating that for every dollar spent, only 89 cents of value is being realized.
distractors: The project is under budget because the actual cost is less than the planned value, but it is behind schedule because the earned value is lower than planned.
The project is on track financially because the cost variance is within a 10% threshold of the total budget at completion.
The project is ahead of schedule because the work performed is nearly half of the total project budget, despite the minor cost overrun.

answers.text: The project is over budget and behind schedule, with a cost performance index (CPI) indicating that for every dollar spent, only 89 cents of value is being realized.
The project is under budget because the actual cost is less than the planned value, but it is behind schedule because the earned value is lower than planned.
The project is on track financially because the cost variance is within a 10% threshold of the total budget at completion.
The project is ahead of schedule because the work performed is nearly half of the total project budget, despite the minor cost overrun.

remediation.coreLogic: CPI = EV / AC = 800,000 / 900,000 = 0.89. SPI = EV / PV = 800,000 / 1,000,000 = 0.80. Since both indices are less than 1.0, the project is both over budget and behind schedule.
remediation.pmiMindset: The project manager must accurately interpret Earned Value Management (EVM) metrics to provide a data-informed status update rather than relying on raw cost comparisons.
remediation.theTrap: Comparing AC to PV is a common mistake; schedule status is determined by comparing EV to PV, and cost status by comparing EV to AC.

questions.scenario: An agile team's velocity has dropped by 15% over the last three iterations. During the retrospective, the team explains that they have been spending significant time onboarding two new developers and dealing with an increase in technical debt in the legacy codebase. The product owner is worried about the upcoming release date.
questions.questionText: What is the best way for the project manager to analyze and act on this information?
questions.correctAnswer: Investigate the velocity trend to confirm if the drop is temporary due to onboarding and facilitate a backlog refinement to address the technical debt.
distractors: Direct the team to increase their effort to restore the previous velocity level and meet the original release commitment.
Remove the two new developers from the team to eliminate the onboarding overhead and immediately restore the velocity.
Inform the product owner that velocity is a vanity metric and should not be used to forecast the release date.

answers.text: Investigate the velocity trend to confirm if the drop is temporary due to onboarding and facilitate a backlog refinement to address the technical debt.
Direct the team to increase their effort to restore the previous velocity level and meet the original release commitment.
Remove the two new developers from the team to eliminate the onboarding overhead and immediately restore the velocity.
Inform the product owner that velocity is a vanity metric and should not be used to forecast the release date.

remediation.coreLogic: A drop in velocity should be investigated for root causes. Onboarding and technical debt are valid reasons for a temporary decrease. Addressing technical debt in the backlog is a proactive way to improve future flow.
remediation.pmiMindset: Data-informed decision-making involves understanding the context behind the numbers. Velocity is a capacity planning tool, not a performance target to be forced.
remediation.theTrap: Forcing a team to work harder ignores the systemic issues like technical debt. Removing members who are already partially onboarded creates further disruption.

questions.scenario: A project uses a hybrid approach with predictive milestones and agile development sprints. The integrated status report shows that while the agile team is meeting their sprint goals, a critical hardware component from a third-party vendor is delayed by four weeks, which will push the final integration phase past the project deadline.
questions.questionText: What is the most appropriate action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Assess the impact of the hardware delay on the project's critical path and facilitate a session with the agile team to identify if some software testing can be performed in a virtual environment.
distractors: Immediately stop the software sprints until the hardware arrives to avoid wasting budget and creating an inventory of "undone" work.
Submit a change request to the sponsor to move the final integration milestone and extend the project end date by exactly four weeks.
Direct the agile team to focus on adding more features to the backlog to provide extra value to the customer while waiting for the hardware.

answers.text: Assess the impact of the hardware delay on the project's critical path and facilitate a session with the agile team to identify if some software testing can be performed in a virtual environment.
Immediately stop the software sprints until the hardware arrives to avoid wasting budget and creating an inventory of "undone" work.
Submit a change request to the sponsor to move the final integration milestone and extend the project end date by exactly four weeks.
Direct the agile team to focus on adding more features to the backlog to provide extra value to the customer while waiting for the hardware.

remediation.coreLogic: In a hybrid environment, the PM must manage the interdependencies between workstreams. The first step is impact analysis followed by identifying workarounds (like virtualization) to maintain momentum.
remediation.pmiMindset: Evaluation before action is essential. PMs should look for ways to mitigate the impact of delays on the critical path before simply extending the timeline.
remediation.theTrap: Stopping work entirely is reactive and ignores potential workarounds. Adding unplanned features (gold plating) increases risk and doesn't address the hardware dependency.

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing the trend of the Cost Performance Index (CPI) over the last four months. The values were 1.05, 1.02, 0.98, and 0.94. The project is currently 50% complete.

questions.correctAnswer: Conduct a root cause analysis to identify the reasons for the deteriorating cost efficiency and implement corrective actions to prevent further budget overruns.

Re-baseline the project's cost baseline immediately to reflect the new spending pattern and avoid showing further negative variances.
Request the sponsor to release the management reserve to cover the projected overrun based on the current CPI.

answers.text: Conduct a root cause analysis to identify the reasons for the deteriorating cost efficiency and implement corrective actions to prevent further budget overruns.
Continue to monitor the project as the average CPI for the last four months is approximately 1.0, indicating the project is currently on budget.
Re-baseline the project's cost baseline immediately to reflect the new spending pattern and avoid showing further negative variances.
Request the sponsor to release the management reserve to cover the projected overrun based on the current CPI.

remediation.coreLogic: A declining trend in CPI over several reporting periods is a significant early warning signal. The PM must investigate the cause before the variance becomes unrecoverable.
remediation.pmiMindset: The trend is more important than a single point in time. Proactive investigation of negative trends allows for effective corrective action.
remediation.theTrap: Averaging the CPI hides the worsening performance. Re-baselining without addressing the root cause just masks the problem.

questions.scenario: In an agile project, the team's burndown chart for the current iteration shows a flat line for the first five days of a ten-day sprint. The team remains optimistic and says they will "catch up" in the second week.

distractors: The team is correctly following the agile principle of "sustainable pace" by not rushing into work in the first half of the sprint.
The burndown chart is not useful until the end of the sprint, so the project manager should wait until the final demo to assess progress.

answers.text: The flat line indicates that no work is being moved to "Done," which could signal a bottleneck or that the user stories are too large; the PM should help the team identify the impediment.
The team is correctly following the agile principle of "sustainable pace" by not rushing into work in the first half of the sprint.
The burndown chart is not useful until the end of the sprint, so the project manager should wait until the final demo to assess progress.
The team is likely working on high-complexity items that will all be completed on the final day, creating a "vertical drop" in the chart.

remediation.coreLogic: A flat burndown line means no story points have been completed. This is a leading indicator of a problem. Waiting until the end of the sprint is reactive and increases the risk of failure.
remediation.pmiMindset: Information radiators should be used for real-time monitoring and intervention. A servant leader helps the team surface and resolve blockers.
remediation.theTrap: Accepting the "we will catch up" excuse without checking for bottlenecks is a common mistake that leads to incomplete sprints.

questions.scenario: During a steering committee meeting for a hybrid project, several stakeholders express confusion about the project's status. Increase the frequency of status meetings to daily sessions where each team lead can explain their charts in detail to the committee.

remediation.pmiMindset: Project managers must synthesize complex data into actionable information for stakeholders. Avoiding information overload is key to effective communication.
remediation.theTrap: Sending executives to raw data tools like Jira usually increases confusion. More data or more meetings do not necessarily lead to better understanding.

questions.scenario: A project's current status is: BAC = $500,000; EV = $150,000; AC = $180,000. A one-time equipment failure caused a significant cost overrun, but all future work is expected to be performed at the originally planned cost efficiency.
questions.questionText: What is the most accurate Estimate at Completion (EAC) for this project?

remediation.coreLogic: When current variances are seen as atypical and future work is expected to follow the plan, the formula is EAC = AC + (BAC - EV). EAC = 180,000 + (500,000 - 150,000) = 180,000 + 350,000 = $530,000.
remediation.pmiMindset: Choosing the correct forecasting formula based on the project context is critical for providing accurate budget expectations.
remediation.theTrap: Using the "typical variance" formula (BAC / CPI) would result in a different value ($600,000), which is incorrect here because the overrun was a "one-time" event.

questions.scenario: An agile project manager notices that while the team is completing their story points every sprint, the number of defects found by the customer during the sprint demo is increasing. The team claims they are meeting their "Definition of Done."

questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate a retrospective to review the current Definition of Done and identify if additional quality gates, such as automated testing or peer reviews, need to be included.

Direct the team to stop developing new features and focus exclusively on fixing all the demo-found defects for the next two iterations.
Instruct the product owner to reject all stories that have any minor defects to force the team to improve their quality.

answers.text: Facilitate a retrospective to review the current Definition of Done and identify if additional quality gates, such as automated testing or peer reviews, need to be included.
Increase the sprint length to allow more time for testing and ensure no defects are delivered to the customer.
Direct the team to stop developing new features and focus exclusively on fixing all the demo-found defects for the next two iterations.
Instruct the product owner to reject all stories that have any minor defects to force the team to improve their quality.

remediation.coreLogic: High defect rates despite meeting "Done" criteria suggest the criteria are inadequate. The PM should use the retrospective to inspect and adapt the quality standards (Definition of Done).
remediation.pmiMindset: Continually assessing the effectiveness of artifacts and standards (like the DoD) is essential for maintaining quality and value delivery.
remediation.theTrap: Increasing sprint length doesn't solve the process problem. Directing work without a retrospective undermines team autonomy and root cause analysis.

questions.scenario: A project manager is using a Cumulative Flow Diagram (CFD) to monitor a hybrid project's workflow. The diagram shows that the "In Progress" band is becoming significantly wider over time, while the "Done" band has a very shallow slope.

questions.correctAnswer: There is a growing bottleneck in the system where work is being started but not finished, leading to increased lead times and a risk to the project deadline.

The project is ahead of schedule because the "In Progress" band shows that a large volume of scope is currently being addressed by the team.
The scope is being effectively managed because the total volume of work (top line of the diagram) is remaining stable.

answers.text: There is a growing bottleneck in the system where work is being started but not finished, leading to increased lead times and a risk to the project deadline.
The team's productivity is increasing because they are able to handle more concurrent work items than at the start of the project.
The project is ahead of schedule because the "In Progress" band shows that a large volume of scope is currently being addressed by the team.
The scope is being effectively managed because the total volume of work (top line of the diagram) is remaining stable.

remediation.coreLogic: In a CFD, a widening "In Progress" band indicates that work is accumulating and not moving to completion. This is a classic indicator of a bottleneck or high work-in-progress (WIP).
remediation.pmiMindset: Flow metrics help identify systemic issues. High WIP is often a leading indicator of project delays and reduced quality.
remediation.theTrap: More work "in progress" is often misinterpreted as higher productivity, but in flow-based systems, it is usually a sign of inefficiency.

Documentation is a secondary artifact; as long as the physical work is correct, the project is considered to be in a healthy status.
The project manager should wait until the project closure phase to update all artifacts to ensure they reflect the final "as-built" state.
The finding indicates that the project budget should be reduced since the team is not spending time on unnecessary paperwork.

remediation.coreLogic: Ensuring artifacts are updated and documented is a key part of project control. Out-of-sync documentation is a major risk for future phases and operations.
remediation.pmiMindset: Artifact management is not "paperwork"; it's essential for maintaining the project's "Source of Truth" and ensuring successful handoff.
remediation.theTrap: Ignoring documentation as long as work is "done" is a common reactive mistake that leads to configuration management chaos.

questions.scenario: An agile project manager is preparing for a mid-release status update with a key stakeholder who prefers high-level visual data. The stakeholder wants to know if the project will deliver the "Mobile Payment" feature set by the end of the next quarter as originally forecasted.

A detailed Gantt chart mapping out every sub-task required for the mobile payment feature over the next three months.

remediation.pmiMindset: PMs must select information radiators that match the stakeholder's level of interest (strategic vs. tactical) and the question being asked.
remediation.theTrap: Stand-up notes and CFDs are too tactical for a release-level "will we be done?" question. Gantt charts are typically avoided for agile delivery due to their brittleness.

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing a hybrid digital transformation project. The steering committee is satisfied with the current "on-time" status based on milestone completions (lagging indicators) but wants to know if there are any emerging risks that could impact the final delivery (leading indicators).
questions.questionText: Which metric should the project manager analyze to provide this proactive insight?
questions.correctAnswer: Requirements churn rate and team morale trends, as high variability in these areas often predicts future schedule slips.
distractors: The number of hours logged by the team last week compared to the original resource plan.

The total budget spent to date compared to the time-phased cost baseline.
The number of completed user stories that have already been accepted by the product owner.

remediation.coreLogic: Leading indicators predict future performance. Requirements churn and team morale are classic leading indicators; high churn suggests future rework, and low morale predicts turnover or quality issues.
remediation.pmiMindset: To be proactive, PMs must look beyond lagging indicators (what happened) and monitor metrics that signal future problems.
remediation.theTrap: Budget spent, hours logged, and accepted stories are all lagging indicators—they tell you what has already occurred, not what is likely to happen next.

questions.scenario: A project's cost performance has been poor, with a CPI of 0.82. The project manager needs to determine the level of efficiency the team must maintain for the remaining work to finish the project exactly at the original budget (BAC).
questions.questionText: Which metric should the project manager calculate to provide this information?
questions.correctAnswer: The To-Complete Performance Index (TCPI) based on the BAC.
distractors: The Estimate at Completion (EAC) using the typical variance formula.
The Cost Variance (CV) to show the current total dollar amount overspent.
The Schedule Performance Index (SPI) to determine if the team can speed up the work.

answers.text: The To-Complete Performance Index (TCPI) based on the BAC.
The Estimate at Completion (EAC) using the typical variance formula.
The Cost Variance (CV) to show the current total dollar amount overspent.
The Schedule Performance Index (SPI) to determine if the team can speed up the work.

remediation.coreLogic: TCPI = (BAC - EV) / (BAC - AC). This formula specifically calculates the required efficiency for the remaining work to hit the target (BAC).
remediation.pmiMindset: TCPI is a powerful evaluation tool for determining the feasibility of project recovery. A TCPI significantly higher than the current CPI suggests that recovery may be unrealistic.
remediation.theTrap: EAC tells you what the project is *likely* to cost, but TCPI tells you the *effort required* to hit a specific target.

questions.scenario: A project manager is analyzing the schedule performance of a data center migration. The Schedule Variance (SV) is -$25,000, and the Schedule Performance Index (SPI) is 0.88. However, the PM notices that all the slipping activities have 15 days of total float.
questions.questionText: What is the true status of the project schedule?
questions.correctAnswer: The project is mathematically behind the plan, but it is not currently at risk of missing the final end date because the delays are on non-critical path activities with sufficient float.
distractors: The project is in critical status because an SPI of 0.88 is a significant deviation that requires immediate schedule compression through crashing.
The project is ahead of schedule because the AC is lower than the PV, indicating that resources are being used more efficiently than planned.
The project manager must submit a change request to be-baseline the schedule immediately to eliminate the negative schedule variance.

answers.text: The project is mathematically behind the plan, but it is not currently at risk of missing the final end date because the delays are on non-critical path activities with sufficient float.
The project is in critical status because an SPI of 0.88 is a significant deviation that requires immediate schedule compression through crashing.
The project is ahead of schedule because the AC is lower than the PV, indicating that resources are being used more efficiently than planned.
The project manager must submit a change request to be-baseline the schedule immediately to eliminate the negative schedule variance.

remediation.coreLogic: EVM metrics (SV/SPI) measure performance against the *planned value*, but they don't account for *float*. A project can be "behind" in value terms without being "late" in calendar terms if the slips occur on non-critical paths.
remediation.pmiMindset: Integrated evaluation requires looking at both EVM data and schedule logic (critical path/float). Don't panic over SPI alone without checking the critical path impact.
remediation.theTrap: Many PMs react to any negative SPI as a crisis. Understanding float allows for "management by exception."

remediation.pmiMindset: The PMB is the "Source of Truth" for performance comparison. It must reflect the actual delivery approach of all workstreams to be an effective evaluation tool.
remediation.theTrap: Forcing agile teams into a detailed waterfall schedule creates a brittle baseline that will be immediately out of date.

questions.scenario: A project manager for a defense contract realizes that several key stakeholders are unable to access the latest "Risk Management Plan" because it is classified as "Confidential" and stored on a secure network that the stakeholders do not have credentials for.
questions.questionText: What should the project manager do to address this artifact accessibility issue?
questions.correctAnswer: Review the security and accessibility requirements with the compliance officer to identify if a redacted or "public" version of the artifact can be created for broader stakeholder use.
distractors: Give the stakeholders the project manager's personal login credentials so they can access the secure network and view the document.
Instruct the stakeholders that they do not need to see the risk management plan and should trust the project manager to manage all project risks.
Post the confidential document on the organization's public intranet to ensure maximum transparency and accessibility for all stakeholders.

answers.text: Review the security and accessibility requirements with the compliance officer to identify if a redacted or "public" version of the artifact can be created for broader stakeholder use.
Give the stakeholders the project manager's personal login credentials so they can access the secure network and view the document.
Instruct the stakeholders that they do not need to see the risk management plan and should trust the project manager to manage all project risks.
Post the confidential document on the organization's public intranet to ensure maximum transparency and accessibility for all stakeholders.

remediation.coreLogic: Accessibility must be balanced with security. The PM should look for formal ways (like redaction or different classification levels) to provide necessary information without violating security rules.
remediation.pmiMindset: Helping ensure accessibility of artifacts includes navigating organizational and security constraints to keep stakeholders informed.
remediation.theTrap: Violating security policies or ignoring stakeholder information needs both lead to poor engagement and compliance risks.

questions.scenario: In an agile project, the project manager notices that the "Escaped Defects" metric has spiked in the last two releases. The team's velocity remains high and they are finishing their sprints on time.
questions.questionText: What does this evaluation tell the PM about the project's true status?
questions.correctAnswer: The project is in a high-risk status because the high velocity is being achieved at the expense of quality, creating technical debt and customer dissatisfaction that will eventually stall progress.
distractors: The project is in an excellent status because velocity is the primary measure of an agile team's success, and defects are a natural part of software development.
The project manager should increase the story point estimates for all future work to allow the team more time to fix the escaped defects.
The "Escaped Defects" metric is a lagging indicator and should be ignored in favor of leading indicators like "team happiness."

answers.text: The project is in a high-risk status because the high velocity is being achieved at the expense of quality, creating technical debt and customer dissatisfaction that will eventually stall progress.
The project is in an excellent status because velocity is the primary measure of an agile team's success, and defects are a natural part of software development.
The project manager should increase the story point estimates for all future work to allow the team more time to fix the escaped defects.
The "Escaped Defects" metric is a lagging indicator and should be ignored in favor of leading indicators like "team happiness."

remediation.coreLogic: Escaped defects are a critical quality signal. High velocity with low quality is "fake progress" that creates a future quality crisis. Quality must be built-in (Definition of Done).
remediation.pmiMindset: Evaluate status using multiple dimensions (speed, quality, value). Never sacrifice quality for the sake of looking good on a velocity chart.
remediation.theTrap: Over-focusing on speed (velocity) without a quality counterbalance is a common failure in agile management.

questions.scenario: A project manager is analyzing a complex data set from a global supply chain project. The data shows that while current deliveries are on track, the lead time for raw materials is increasing by 5% every week. The project manager decides to order early despite the current "on-time" status.
questions.questionText: Which approach to evaluation is the PM demonstrating?
questions.correctAnswer: Data-informed decision-making, where raw data is combined with context and judgment to take proactive action before a variance occurs.
distractors: Data-driven decision-making, where the project manager is blindly following a mathematical model that dictates ordering schedules.
Reactive management, where the project manager is responding to a current delay that has already impacted the project baseline.
Ignoring the data and relying on "gut feel" to make arbitrary changes to the project's procurement plan.

answers.text: Data-informed decision-making, where raw data is combined with context and judgment to take proactive action before a variance occurs.
Data-driven decision-making, where the project manager is blindly following a mathematical model that dictates ordering schedules.
Reactive management, where the project manager is responding to a current delay that has already impacted the project baseline.
Ignoring the data and relying on "gut feel" to make arbitrary changes to the project's procurement plan.

remediation.coreLogic: Data-informed PMs use metrics (lead time trends) to surface problems early, then use judgment to solve them. Ordering early is a proactive response to a leading indicator.
remediation.pmiMindset: The goal is to be data-informed. Use data as a key input but balance it with human insight and project context.
remediation.theTrap: Data-driven management removes human judgment. This PM is clearly using judgment to interpret the trend.

questions.scenario: An agile team is struggling to evaluate their status because a critical third-party integration is a "black box" with no available documentation. The team is unsure if they can meet their release commitment.
questions.questionText: What is the best way for the project manager to tailor the project's artifacts to help evaluate the status?
questions.correctAnswer: Suggest that the team perform a "Technical Spike" and document the findings in a research artifact to reduce uncertainty and provide a data-backed status estimate.
distractors: Instruct the team to guess the integration effort and add a 50% "buffer" to the story point estimate for the integration story.
Create a 100-page formal "Integration Risk Assessment" document and submit it to the Change Control Board for review.
Tell the product owner that the status is "Unknown" and remove the integration story from the release scope immediately.

answers.text: Suggest that the team perform a "Technical Spike" and document the findings in a research artifact to reduce uncertainty and provide a data-backed status estimate.
Instruct the team to guess the integration effort and add a 50% "buffer" to the story point estimate for the integration story.
Create a 100-page formal "Integration Risk Assessment" document and submit it to the Change Control Board for review.

remediation.coreLogic: A spike is a timeboxed research effort used to reduce technical uncertainty. The artifact created (spike report) provides the data needed for status evaluation.
remediation.pmiMindset: Use agile-specific techniques (spikes) to handle uncertainty rather than just adding arbitrary buffers or creating excessive documentation.
remediation.theTrap: Guessing the effort is not data-informed. Formal risk assessments may be too slow for an agile team's needs.

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing a "Risk Heat Map" for a hybrid project. The map shows that the "Data Privacy Compliance" risk has moved from "Low" to "Critical" because of a new AI-related regulation that was just announced.
questions.questionText: What should the project manager do to ensure this artifact correctly reflects the project's status?
questions.correctAnswer: Update the risk register with the new probability and impact data, ensure a response owner is assigned, and communicate the updated status to the steering committee.
distractors: Keep the heat map as it is until the end of the quarter to avoid showing too much volatility to the stakeholders.
Direct the agile team to stop all AI-related development until the legal department provides a final ruling on the new regulation.
Create a separate "AI Risk Log" so the original project heat map remains focused only on traditional project risks.

answers.text: Update the risk register with the new probability and impact data, ensure a response owner is assigned, and communicate the updated status to the steering committee.
Keep the heat map as it is until the end of the quarter to avoid showing too much volatility to the stakeholders.
Direct the agile team to stop all AI-related development until the legal department provides a final ruling on the new regulation.
Create a separate "AI Risk Log" so the original project heat map remains focused only on traditional project risks.

remediation.coreLogic: Control involves ensuring artifacts like the risk register and heat map are updated as soon as new information becomes available. This ensures the status evaluation is current.
remediation.pmiMindset: PMs must maintain a live, transparent view of project risks to support effective decision-making.
remediation.theTrap: Waiting to update the artifacts is a failure of transparency. Stopping work immediately is a premature reaction before impact analysis.

questions.scenario: A project status report shows the following: CPI = 0.95 and SPI = 1.05. The project is currently on the critical path for a high-priority product launch.
questions.questionText: What is the most likely cause of this performance data?
questions.correctAnswer: The project manager is likely "crashing" the schedule (e.g., using overtime or more expensive resources) to stay ahead of the launch deadline, resulting in higher costs.
distractors: The project is performing poorly in both areas because any index not equal to 1.0 indicates a failure in project control.
The team is "gold plating" the product by adding extra features that were not in the original scope, which is increasing both speed and cost.
The project manager is "fast-tracking" the project, which is saving money but increasing the risk of rework and delays.

answers.text: The project manager is likely "crashing" the schedule (e.g., using overtime or more expensive resources) to stay ahead of the launch deadline, resulting in higher costs.
The project is performing poorly in both areas because any index not equal to 1.0 indicates a failure in project control.
The team is "gold plating" the product by adding extra features that were not in the original scope, which is increasing both speed and cost.
The project manager is "fast-tracking" the project, which is saving money but increasing the risk of rework and delays.

remediation.coreLogic: SPI > 1.0 (ahead) and CPI < 1.0 (over budget) is a classic signature of crashing. You are spending money to buy time.
remediation.pmiMindset: PMs must be able to read the "story" behind the metrics to understand the trade-offs being made in project execution.
remediation.theTrap: Fast-tracking usually increases risk but doesn't necessarily increase direct costs as much as crashing (which uses more labor/resources).

questions.scenario: An agile project manager is presenting a "Sprint Burnup Chart" to the customer. The chart shows that while the "Work Completed" line is rising steadily, the "Total Scope" line has also moved up by 20 story points in the last two sprints.
questions.questionText: How should the PM explain this to the customer?
questions.correctAnswer: "The team is delivering value at a stable pace, but the new features you requested have increased the total work, which will impact the final release date if we don't reprioritize."
distractors: "The team is slowing down because the total scope is getting too large for them to manage effectively."
"The project is on track because as long as the work completed line is going up, we are making progress."
"We need to stop the developers from adding their own features to the backlog to prevent this kind of scope creep."

answers.text: "The team is delivering value at a stable pace, but the new features you requested have increased the total work, which will impact the final release date if we don't reprioritize."

"The project is on track because as long as the work completed line is going up, we are making progress."
"We need to stop the developers from adding their own features to the backlog to prevent this kind of scope creep."

remediation.coreLogic: A burnup chart is the best tool for visualizing scope changes alongside progress. The PM must communicate the trade-off between new requests and the original deadline.
remediation.pmiMindset: Transparency about scope and its impact on the schedule is a core responsibility of the agile PM.
remediation.theTrap: Only looking at the "completed" line ignores the "remaining" work, which is the real status concern.

questions.scenario: A project manager is evaluating the effectiveness of the "Lessons Learned Register" after a major phase completion. questions.questionText: What is the most important action for the project manager to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Assess the accessibility and culture around the lessons learned process to identify why teams are not using or contributing to the artifact, and implement a more integrated "peer-sharing" session.
distractors: Direct the team leads to write a 10-page retrospective report on why they failed to follow the organization's standard knowledge management policy.
Hire a "Knowledge Manager" to manually interview every team member every week and update the register on their behalf.
Remove the lessons learned requirement from the project since the teams clearly find it to be of low value for their daily work.

remediation.pmiMindset: Continually assessing and improving the effectiveness of artifacts ensures that the project organization is actually learning and improving.
remediation.theTrap: Forcing compliance through reports doesn't solve the underlying problem that the artifact is perceived as non-valuable or hard to access.

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing the project's S-Curve. The "Earned Value" line has started to flatten out, while the "Actual Cost" line continues to climb at a steep angle.
questions.questionText: What does this trend analysis indicate about the project status?
questions.correctAnswer: The project is experiencing a significant loss in productivity and cost efficiency, where spending is continuing but progress has stalled (potentially due to rework or a major bottleneck).
distractors: The project is entering the "execution" phase where spending is expected to be high and progress is naturally slower than in the planning phase.
The project is ahead of schedule because the high actual cost indicates that the team is working extremely hard to finish the work.
The project is under budget because the Earned Value line is below the Actual Cost line, indicating that we are earning more than we are spending.

The project is under budget because the Earned Value line is below the Actual Cost line, indicating that we are earning more than we are spending.

remediation.coreLogic: On an S-curve, a flattening EV line combined with a rising AC line is a "death spiral" indicator—you're spending money but not getting results. This is a critical status warning.
remediation.pmiMindset: Visual trend analysis of the S-curve provides a powerful integrated view of project health that formulas alone might miss.
remediation.theTrap: The interpretation that the project is under budget when costs exceed value is mathematically backwards.

questions.scenario: An agile team is consistently meeting its velocity targets, but the "First Pass Yield" (percentage of work done correctly the first time) is only 60%. The rest of the team's capacity is being consumed by bug fixes and rework during the sprint.
questions.questionText: How should the project manager reconcile these two metrics?
questions.correctAnswer: Explain that the high velocity is "false progress" because 40% of the team's effort is being wasted on poor-quality work; help the team improve their Definition of Done to increase First Pass Yield.
distractors: Congratulate the team on their high velocity and ignore the rework since agile embraces change and "responding to defects" is part of the process.
Direct the team to stop measuring First Pass Yield as it is a traditional manufacturing metric that doesn't apply to software development.
Increase the team's story point estimates by 40% to account for the expected rework and make the metrics align with the actual effort.

Increase the team's story point estimates by 40% to account for the expected rework and make the metrics align with the actual effort.

remediation.coreLogic: Reconciliation involves looking at the relationship between speed and quality. High velocity with high rework is inefficient. The goal should be "Quality at the Source."
remediation.pmiMindset: PMs must look past "vanity metrics" like raw velocity to understand the true efficiency and value delivery of the team.
remediation.theTrap: Hiding the rework by inflating estimates just masks the systemic quality problem.

questions.scenario: A hybrid project is at its 75% completion point. The predictive phase is green, but the agile team has only delivered 30% of the high-value features in the backlog. The customer is asking if they will get the "Return on Investment" (ROI) promised in the business case.
questions.questionText: What is the most accurate way for the project manager to evaluate this status?
questions.correctAnswer: Perform a "Value-to-Date" analysis, comparing the business value of delivered software features and infrastructure against the original business case assumptions.
distractors: Tell the customer that since the predictive phase is 100% on track, the ROI is guaranteed as long as the hardware is installed on time.
Update the project status to "Green" because 75% of the total project tasks are completed, regardless of the value of those tasks.
Ask the agile team to work overtime to deliver all the remaining features in the backlog, regardless of their priority or value.

remediation.coreLogic: Project evaluation should focus on value delivery, not just task completion. If high-value features are missing, the project's ROI status is at risk even if the schedule looks "on track."
remediation.pmiMindset: The PM should be "value-informed." Metrics should help surface whether the project is still aligned with the business case and delivering the expected benefits.
remediation.theTrap: Raw percent complete metrics are a poor measure of business value, especially in agile/hybrid projects where work is prioritized by value.

questions.scenario: A project manager is presenting a "Variance Report" to the project sponsor. The report shows a $50,000 cost overrun. The sponsor asks, "Is this because of the vendor price increase or the technical integration issues?"
questions.questionText: Where should the project manager have included this information to ensure effective status communication?
questions.correctAnswer: In the "Basis of Variance" section of the status report, which provides the qualitative context and root cause analysis for the quantitative metrics.
distractors: In the "Change Request Form" which is only used to request more money, not to explain why money was spent.
In the "Risk Register" because all past overruns should be tracked as risks that could happen again in the future.
In the "Project Charter" which defines the high-level budget and the reasons why the project was started.

answers.text: In the "Basis of Variance" section of the status report, which provides the qualitative context and root cause analysis for the quantitative metrics.

In the "Project Charter" which defines the high-level budget and the reasons why the project was started.

remediation.coreLogic: Numbers without context are not actionable. A status report must include the "why" (root cause) behind the variances to be meaningful for the sponsor.
remediation.pmiMindset: Communication of status requires integrated reporting—combining quantitative data (the variance) with qualitative analysis (the cause).
remediation.theTrap: The Risk Register is for *future* events; the status report is for *current* and *past* performance.
